-When the first oxygen gets on, the bike frame relaxes and reshapes
-Seats widen and pedaling becomes smooth
-High affinity: remaining oxygen passengers hop on easily
-Functional role: oxygen loading in the lungs
-Illustrates positive cooperativity—one rider makes it easier for the next

Student Takeaways
-think of hemoglobin as a four-seat bike
-T-state = stiff bike → low oxygen affinity → unloading in tissues
-R-state = relaxed bike → high oxygen affinity → loading in lungs
-The first oxygen rider is the hardest to seat
-Once one rider is on, the rest snap into place quickly due to cooperatively

submissions.name: Symeon Moss
submissions.slideRaw: This slide can come after slide 19 (on unannotated slide)
submissions.explanation: I used AI as a design partner for the visual analogy. Note that the AI originally generated a label saying 'Small = Excluded,' which is a common factual hallucination. I have manually corrected the logic in my final slide and script to ensure it accurately reflects that Large proteins are excluded and Small proteins are included, as per Chapter 6 theory.
submissions.notes:
Hook: "If you’re walking through a crowded mall with a group of toddlers, who is going to make it to the exit first? It’s not the toddlers—they’re going to get distracted by every toy store and candy shop along the way."The Science (Left Side): "This is exactly how Size Exclusion Chromatography—also known as Gel Filtration—works. Look at the left side of the slide. We pack a column with porous beads. These pores are like 'molecular doors.' Our Large Proteins (the Red Spheres) are simply too big to fit through those doors. Because they are EXCLUDED, they stay in the 'main hallway' and wash straight through the column."The Analogy (Right Side): "Now look at the right side. Our Small Proteins (the Green Spheres) are like those toddlers. Because they can fit through the doors, they enter the pores of every single bead they encounter. They take a massive 'detour' through the internal volume of the beads. Even though they are smaller, their path is much, much longer."The Bottom Line: "The result is totally counter-intuitive: Bigger proteins are FASTER. In any other type of chromatography or electrophoresis, you might expect small things to move quickly. In SEC, the small proteins get 'lost' in the beads, meaning the heavyweights always win the race to the bottom."

Student Takeaways (The "Bottom Line") Size Exclusion = Gel Filtration: These terms are interchangeable on the exam.The "Exclusion" Rule: Large proteins are EXCLUDED from the pores -> they take the shortest path -> they ELUTE FIRST.The "Inclusion" Rule: Small proteins are INCLUDED in the bead volume -> they take a long, winding path -> they ELUTE LAST.Exam Trap: Do not assume "small = fast." In this specific technique, small is slow because it spends more time 'inside' the stationary phase.

submissions.name: Nathan David
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation:
I addressed a significant Factual Error in the original graphic: the amino group was labeled as the zwitterionic $\text{NH}_3^+$ but was visually modeled with only two hydrogen atoms. My updated version correctly depicts the nitrogen with three hydrogens to accurately represent the protonated state at physiological pH. Additionally, I applied a Visual Overhaul by removing the cramped 'Proteogenic Set' list at the bottom. This reduces cognitive load and visual clutter, allowing students to focus entirely on the slide's primary learning objectives: the general backbone structure and stereochemistry.

This slide should be placed at the very beginning of the Amino Acids lecture. It serves as the foundational definition of what a proteogenic amino acid is before the lecture dives into the specific classifications and functions.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
"Start with the General Structure: at physiological pH, notice the backbone is zwitterionic—the amino group holds a positive charge ($\text{NH}_3^+$) and the carboxyl group is negative ($COO^-$). That central $\alpha$-carbon is chiral, meaning these molecules have stereochemistry. Now, look at synthesis: simple microorganisms can build all 20 of these from scratch. We humans aren't quite as versatile—we only synthesize 11. The remaining 9 are 'essential,' which simply means if you don't eat them, you don't have them."

Student Takeaways:
- Structure & Stereochemistry: At physiological pH, amino acids exist as chiral zwitterions (L-isomers) defined by their unique R-group side chain.
- Synthesis: Microorganisms synthesize all 20 proteogenic amino acids, while humans synthesize only 11; the remaining 9 are "essential" and must be supplied by the diet.

submissions.name: Rachel Huang
submissions.slideRaw: insert after Slide 56 (The "Thermodynamics of Protein Folding" slide).
submissions.explanation:
Why it's better: The current slide deck focuses heavily on diseases of aggregation (e.g., Slide 47 on alpha1-Antitrypsin, Slide 61 on Prions), where misfolded proteins clump together and become toxic ("Gain of Toxic Function"). However, it misses the other half of the story: diseases of degradation ("Loss of Function").

Placement Logic: Slide 56 introduces the concept of the "folding funnel" and energy landscapes. This new slide immediately applies that theory to a real-world example (Cystic Fibrosis), showing students what happens when a protein gets "stuck" in a local energy minimum (a kinetic trap) and is destroyed by the cell’s quality control systems before it can finish folding.
submissions.notes:
Brief Presenter Notes:
The Scenario: Cystic Fibrosis is often caused by the ∆F508 mutation. This doesn't necessarily break the protein's function; it just slows down its folding.
The Mechanism: Because the protein folds too slowly (getting stuck in a "kinetic trap" on the energy landscape), the cell’s quality control mechanism (ERAD - Endoplasmic Reticulum Associated Degradation) tags it as defective.
The Outcome: The proteasome destroys the protein. The patient is sick not because they have a "bad" protein, but because they have no protein at the cell surface. It’s a quality control failure.
Contrast: Contrast this with the Prion/Alzheimer's examples later in the deck (where the protein survives and clumps).

Student Takeaways:
Folding is Time-Sensitive: It’s not enough to reach the native state; you have to reach it fast enough to escape the cell's "trash collectors" (proteasomes).
Two Classes of Failure:
1. Aggregation: Misfolded proteins clump and kill the cell (e.g., Prions, Alzheimer's).
2. Degradation: Misfolded proteins are destroyed, leading to a loss of function (e.g., Cystic Fibrosis).
Key Term: Proteasome (the cellular machine that recycles misfolded proteins).

submissions.name: Kayli Nguyen
submissions.explanation: There is a lot of text, which prevents the student from taking away key points. Thus, it should be simplified and shortened for the key points. I think the marble picture should be removed as this analogy was presented earlier so the point is already across. I also think the gel filtration diagram can be better organized. This position in the slide deck is good. A lot of the slides have a lot of information on them, which can be too much for the student to take in.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
Pore Exclusion: Large molecules are physically blocked from entering the internal pore, forcing them to remain in the surrounding liquid medium.
Volume of Distribution: Small molecules occupy a much larger total volume because they can move into and out of the stationary phase's pores.

Student Takeaways
Speed of Elution: Large molecules elute first because they take the most direct path.
Size Relationship: Small molecules elute last because they travel into the pores, creating a much longer path to the exit.

submissions.name: Angela Kim
submissions.explanation: Students often struggle to visualize "conformational change" and how a microscopic shift leads to a macroscopic change in binding affinity. This slide replaces the abstract protein blobs with a concrete mechanical analogy (a latch system). It visually demonstrates how "tension" in the locked state (T) is physically released by the first binding event, mechanically forcing the other subunits open (R). By placing the mechanical analogy directly next to the binding curves, it cements the link between the mechanism (the gear shift) and the result (the sigmoid curve).
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: "Think of Hemoglobin like a security door with four mechanical latches connected by a central gear. In the T-state, the latches are under tension and locked shut—it's hard to insert the first key (Oxygen). However, once you manage to turn that first key, it rotates the central gear. Snap! This rotation pops the other three latches open (R-state). Now, the remaining keys slide in effortlessly. This 'mechanical advantage' is exactly why we see that steep rise in the graph—the first binding event does the heavy lifting for the rest."

Student Takeaways:

T-State = Tension: The protein is physically constrained (locked), making binding difficult.

Communication is Mechanical: Cooperativity isn't magic; it is a physical transmission of force from one subunit to another.

The "Snap": The transition from T to R is a switch, not a gradual drift, which creates the steep "cooperative" part of the sigmoidal curve.

submissions.name: Nina Breen
submissions.explanation:
Because many people taking this class are premed or pre-dental and will be interacting with drugs in their life post-college, this example of anesthesia not working is a great way to keep students engaged. pH is something that I get confused with because it is hard to apply to a situation that makes sense to me. Thus, by describing how the environment's pH impacts the ability of the drug to work, I now have a concrete example I can think back to to understand why pH matters so much.

should be added after slide 41 or 42
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
Hook: You inject Lidocaine into an infected "hot" tooth, but the patient still feels everything. Why? It's not a bad drug; it's biochemistry. Talking Points:

Healthy Tissue (Left): Lidocaine (pKa 7.9) at pH 7.4. A significant amount is uncharged. It easily crosses the hydrophobic membrane to block the nerve.

Infected Tissue (Right): Bacteria produce acid, dropping pH to ~5.0. Now, pH is far below pKa.

The Mechanism: The drug becomes ~99% protonated (charged). Charged molecules cannot pass through the lipid bilayer.


The Result: The drug bounces off the nerve and is "trapped" outside. This is Ion Trapping. Misconception: The acid doesn't destroy the drug; it just gives it a charge that locks it out.

Student Takeaways
Write down: Ion Trapping: pH determines charge; charge determines permeability. Only uncharged molecules cross membranes.


Memorize: For weak bases: Low pH (Acidic) → Protonated (Charged) → Trapped.

Exam framing: Application: Given a drug's pKa and the pH of two compartments, tell me which side the drug gets trapped on.

submissions.name: Lillianne (Lily) Krakowski
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Visual/Diagram, Better Explanation/Analogy, Missing something important that is in the publisher's slide deck
submissions.explanation: I added the analogy of the "business end" the "regulatory machine" and the "Delivery vehicle" from the speaker notes onto the screen. I thought that the slide was initially too picture heavy and would benefit from the analogy being added to the screen.
submissions.notes:
Hook: We aren't just looking at a protein; we’re looking at a global supply chain. 

Key Point: Oxygen transport scales from atomic chemistry to mechanical regulation to cellular logistics. 

Transition: "Here's our roadmap for the chapter... we’ll move from the site of action to the vehicle that carries it."

Student Study Signals

Bottom line: Function follows scale. The Heme does the work, the Tetramer makes the decisions (allostery), and the RBC provides the bulk transport.

Memorize: 
Heme: Fe^2+ coordination—if it’s Fe^3+, the "Business End" is closed for business.
Tetramer: The T-to-R transition. This is the "on/off" switch for affinity.
RBC: Packaging. 270–300 million Hb molecules per "Vehicle."

submissions.name: William Girard
submissions.explanation: The solvation example image on the slide with the roles of water in biochemistry was drawn incorrectly. The image showed that for both Na+ and Cl- the partial negative oxygen in the water was pointing towards both ions. My new image has clarified this mistake and now has the water molecules correctly facing the dissolved NaCl. The image should replace the current image under #2 solvation on slide 7.
submissions.notes: Many ionic and polar molecules can dissolve in water due to its polarity. The oxygen in water is partially negative due to its higher electronegativity and the two hydrogens are partially positive. Students should take away that water can dissolve ions and polar molecules, which is particularly important for many biological processes.

submissions.name: Simona Hagos
submissions.explanation: My version is better because it creates an analogy that might help students understand the concept of cysteine cross-linking better. It provides a visual, as well as key points, for students to relate to when they learn the material. This should be presented under slide 9 and before slide 10, adding additional helpful content related to cross-linking.
submissions.notes:
Think about cross-linking as a cargo net. 

Structure is Function: A protein isn't just a string; it’s a machine. Cysteines "weld" the machine into the correct shape so it can work.

The Sulfur Connection: Cysteine is unique because it contains a sulfur atom. Two sulfurs find each other and lock together.

Fixed Geometry: Cysteine cross-links turn a flexible string into a predictable, 3D structure.

Heavy-Duty Support: Unlike "weak" interactions (like static electricity), these are covalent bonds—the molecular equivalent of a physical weld or a locked metal clip.

Environmental Shield: These links act like "structural insurance," keeping the protein from unfolding even in harsh environments like the stomach or the bloodstream.

submissions.name: Simona Hagos (redo submission)
submissions.explanation: This version is better because it provides a visual analogy that students can use when studying, while still emphasizing key points. It provides another mechanism for students to remember the idea of cross-linking.
submissions.notes:
Presenter’s Notes
1. The Starting Point (The Floppy Rope)

Hook: "Start by asking: Can you lift a box with a single piece of string? Maybe. Can you lift a ton of cargo with a pile of loose strings? No way."

Concept: Explain that before cross-linking, proteins are in a "Random Coil" state. They are flexible and lack the structure needed to perform specific jobs. The blue dots (SH) are the "open" parts of the clip.

2. The Reaction (The Chemical Trigger)

Mechanism: Focus on Oxidation. For the clip to shut, the protein has to "give up" something—specifically electrons and hydrogen ions (2H + and 2e −).

Nuance: Mention that this usually happens in specific environments (like outside the cell) where oxygen or specific enzymes act as the "mechanic" shutting the clips.

3. The Link (The Locked Carabiner)

Strength: Emphasize that this is a Covalent Bond. Unlike hydrogen bonds (which are like static electricity), this is a physical, chemical "weld."

The "S-S": This is the "Disulfide Bridge." It’s the only way a protein can lock two distant parts of its chain together permanently.

4. The Result (The Structural Grid)

Big Picture: When you have many of these clips, you get a Cargo Net.

Real-World Tie-in: * Antibodies: Use these to stay "Y-shaped" so they can grab viruses.

Hair: Keratin is full of these. A "Perm" involves breaking these clips and re-clipping them in a new shape.

Student Takeaways
Structure = Stability: Without disulfide bonds, many proteins would "unfold" and stop working the moment the temperature changed or the environment got tough.

The Cysteine Specialty: Cysteine is the only amino acid that can form these covalent "bridges." It is the "specialist" in protein architecture.

Chemical Change: You cannot form a disulfide bond without Oxidation (the loss of electrons/hydrogen).

Rigidity: The "Cargo Net" analogy proves that a 3D shape is far stronger and more functional than a 1D string.

submissions.name: Alexis Niemi
submissions.explanation: Presents the differences between monoclonal and polyclonal antibodies in a side-by-side comparison that makes it easier for students to understand. It also includes a simpler image to help students distinguish between the antibodies.The new slide should be placed in chapter 6, slide 36.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
Antigen: A foreign molecule that triggers an immune response and is recognized by antibodies.
Antibody: A protein made by B cells that specifically binds to an antigen.
Monoclonal antibody: Made by a single B cell clone, binds one epitope
Polyclonal antibody: Made by multiple B cells, binds multiple epitopes

Student Takeaways
Monoclonal antibodies are specific and reproducible
Polyclonal antibodies are robust and vary

submissions.name: Irene Wang
submissions.explanation: It should replace the current slide about gout - student nowadays dont really know what it is - almost archaic, this new slide deals with cancer which is more relevant nowadays.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes (Script)
"We've talked about allosteric regulation as a way for cells to efficiently manage their resources. The classic example is Gout, but let's look at a modern, killer application: Cancer.

Normally, your cells are efficient. When they have enough energy (high ATP), ATP binds to an allosteric site on the enzyme PFK-1, which is the gatekeeper of glycolysis. This slows down glucose consumption. It’s negative feedback.

Cancer cells, however, 'hack' this system. This is called the Warburg Effect. Even when oxygen is present, cancer cells bypass this allosteric check. PFK-1 gets locked in its high-activity R-State, and the cell consumes glucose voraciously—up to 200 times faster than a normal cell—fermenting it into lactate to build biomass for rapid division.

Understanding this isn't just academic. It's how we find tumors. FDG-PET scans use a radioactive glucose analog. Because cancer cells are uniquely 'hungry' due to this allosteric hack, they light up on the scan as 'hot spots.' So, the principles of enzyme kinetics you're learning are directly used in clinical oncology every single day."

Student Takeaways
The Warburg Effect: Cancer cells exhibit a high rate of glycolysis and lactate fermentation even in the presence of oxygen.

Allosteric Bypass: The normal feedback inhibition of PFK-1 by ATP is disrupted, keeping the enzyme in its active R-state.

Clinical Relevance: This massive, unregulated glucose uptake is the physiological basis for detecting tumors using FDG-PET imaging.

submissions.name: Adam
submissions.explanation:
This slide improves conceptual clarity by differentiating ΔG (free-energy change) from ΔG (transition state, activation energy) using an analogy of a mountain-tunnel. The original slide content explains the concepts accurately but in a more abstract and wordy way that can be confusing, especially the idea that enzymes speed reactions without changing equilibrium. This visual makes it clear that enzymes lower the activation energy barrier while the start and end energy levels (ΔG) are unchanged. The added clinical hook (statins as transition-state analogs) also reinforces real-world relevance and retention.

This slide should be put immediately after the first introduction of activation energy/ΔG vs ΔG (transition state) and before numerical thermodynamics examples. Other students can establish the correct conceptual framework before seeing the equations.
submissions.notes: Enzymes lower ΔG‡ (activation energy), Enzymes do NOT change ΔG or equilibrium, Thermodynamics = can it happen? Kinetics = how fast does it happen? Enzymes change speed, not destiny

submissions.name: Maisie Page
submissions.explanation: I think this new image should simply replace the other one on the slide. During lecture I noticed it was a ball going up, which felt counterintuitive because usually a ball rolling is used to depict not needing energy. But because its depicting an endergonic reaction, energy is required and the ball could be confusing. I chose a Gondola lift to show how energy is needed to move up, against gravity. I think it partners with the graphic before this slide better as well (the waterfall image).
submissions.notes:
Endergonic = "thermodynamic uphill"
ΔG > 0 → NOT spontaneous → requires energy input
Must be coupled to exergonic reaction (like ATP hydrolysis

student takeaways:
Endergonic = non-spontaneous = requires energy
Cells couple endergonic reactions to ATP hydrolysis

submissions.name: Suryan Athreya
submissions.explanation: The image of original DNA replication isn't perfect of depicting the actual process. It shows an incomplete replication fork that I believe could be improved upon. DNA replication is a highly central topic and should be given attention. The Model that Gemini helped me prepare uses a simple road-building concept that will be easy for students to grasp, but also includes basic enzymes like helices, polymerase, and the idea of Okazaki fragments. This new information with a simple analogy makes this the superior slide to ensure that DNA replication is fully understood. This should replace the simple image of an incomplete replication fork and sandwich on Slide 50 of Chapter 1.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: 1. The Two-Lane System (Semi-Conservative)

The Core: When the highway replicates, the original road is split.

The Detail: Each resulting highway consists of one "original" lane (the dark grey old pavement) and one "new" lane (the light grey fresh concrete). This ensures the genetic "blueprints" are preserved perfectly.

2. The High-Speed Paving Truck (Polymerase)

The Speed: In humans, these trucks add 50 units of pavement per second; in bacteria, it’s a staggering 1,000 units per second.

The Precision: Despite the speed, the truck acts like a "master chef"—it's incredibly accurate, ensuring the "road" is smooth and error-free.

3. Multiple Construction Zones (Replication Forks)

The Efficiency: We don't start at mile zero and go to the end. Instead, we have multiple crews starting at different points along the genome.

The Logic: These multiple Replication Forks are necessary to copy the massive amount of data in a reasonable timeframe.

4. The Protective Guardrails (Telomeres)

The Function: Telomeres are like the plastic tips on shoelaces or guardrails at the end of the road.

The Countdown: Every time the road is paved, these tips get shorter. While the "Telomerase" crew tries to fix them, they eventually wear down, which is the biological basis for aging.

5. The Specialized Machinery

Helicase: The "Plow" that unzips the DNA double helix.

Polymerase: The "Paving Truck" that adds the new bases.

The Assembly Line: Every protein must perform its specific role in a strict sequence to create a flawless product.

6. Building in a Tight Canyon (The Nucleus)

The Constraint: This entire massive construction project happens inside the tiny, crowded nucleus. It is as delicate as building a ship inside a bottle; one wrong move could lead to tangling or breaking.

7. Quality Control (Errors & Cancer)

The Stakes: If the paving truck makes a mistake and the inspectors miss it, those errors become mutations.

The Consequence: Unfixed errors can lead to cancer. The cell's repair system is essentially the factory's "Quality Control" department. 


Student takeaways: 
The "Must-Memorize" Vocabulary

Helicase: The "Plow" that unwinds and unzips the DNA double helix by breaking hydrogen bonds.

DNA Polymerase: The "Paving Truck" that builds the new strand by adding matching bases (A-T, C-G) at high speed.

Replication Fork: The Y-shaped region where the DNA is currently being split and copied.

Semi-Conservative: The rule that every new DNA molecule consists of one original (old) strand and one newly synthesized strand.

Mutation: A permanent error in the DNA sequence that occurs if the polymerase makes a mistake that isn't fixed.

Test Day "Quick Checks"

Is the new DNA 100% new? No, it is semi-conservative (half old, half new).

How does it go so fast? By using multiple forks at once rather than just one.

What is the "builder"? DNA Polymerase.

What is the "unzipper"? Helicase.

submissions.name: Carolyn Beckel
submissions.explanation: End of presentation 1 after organelles explained individually. I always like having all the information on a visual/chart to compare and contrasts differences between organelles, as well as putting them into categories based on function.
submissions.notes:
Notes: 

Compartmentalization: The cell acts as a "factory" where specialized organelles isolate biochemical reactions to increase efficiency and prevent interference.

The Shipping Pipeline: Proteins are manufactured in the Rough ER, refined and "tagged" in the Golgi Complex, and distributed via Vesicles.

Energy & Waste: Mitochondria and Chloroplasts provide the necessary fuel (ATP), while Lysosomes act as the recycling center to digest imported materials.

Logistics (In & Out): Endocytosis (and phagocytosis) brings raw materials in, while Exocytosis exports finished products out of the cell.

Student Takeaway: The eukaryotic cell functions like a factory where organelles serve as specialized departments ensuring all biochemical tasks are isolated and efficient.

submissions.name: Maj Vorsic
submissions.explanation: This new slide replaces the original on chapter 8, slide 12 to provide a conceptual bridge immediately after defining initial velocity. I applied the Aha! Analogy category by transforming the abstract Michaelis-Menten graph into an intuitive coffee shop visual that makes enzyme saturation and Vmax instantly relatable. To ensure bounty quality, I manually corrected the AI-generated garbled text and fixed LaTeX formatting errors to meet the strict standards for technical accuracy and visual clarity.
submissions.notes:
To understand Michaelis-Menten kinetics, imagine a barista is our enzyme. During a "Slow Morning" (Low [S]), the barista is mostly waiting; the reaction rate is low because there aren't enough customers (substrate). As we move into "Rush Hour" (Saturation), the line is out the door. The barista is now working at their absolute "speed limit," or Vmax. At this point, adding more customers won't make the coffee come out any faster because the enzyme is fully occupied.
V0 is the speed of product formation shortly after the reaction begins.

Saturation occurs when all enzyme active sites are occupied by substrate.

Vmax represents the theoretical maximum rate of the reaction under specific conditions.

submissions.name: Liam Slocomb
submissions.slideRaw: Slide number in bottom corner of PDF is 34
submissions.explanation: The original slide has a mistake -- what is supposed to be ADP in the visual equation with chemical structures looks to be AMP. This mistake distracted me during lecture, which drew my attention away from the material, so I felt it would be valuable to fix. As such, I created an accurate ATP + H20 --> ADP + P visual molecular equation in BioRender, then I pasted it into the slide and adjusted the formatting with google slides and Nano Banana. This new slide should remain in the same place as the old slide.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
The "Thermodynamic Downhill": Explain that exergonic reactions represent a "waterfall" in terms of free energy. The products have less free energy than the reactants, making the final state more stable.
Spontaneity vs. Speed: Clarify that while these reactions are "spontaneous" (ΔG<0), this does not necessarily mean they occur quickly. The "hump" in the diagram represents the activation energy; even spontaneous reactions may require a catalyst (like an enzyme) to overcome this barrier at biological speeds.
ATP Hydrolysis Example: Point out the specific chemical reaction provided: 
ATP+H2O→ADP+Pi. 
The standard free energy change (ΔG∘′) is −30.5 kJ/mol, illustrating why ATP is the "universal energy currency".
Lab Context: In a controlled environment like a test tube, these reactions are typically exothermic, meaning the released energy is felt as heat.

Student Takeaways
Core Definition: Exergonic reactions are energy-releasing processes where the change in Gibbs Free Energy is negative (ΔG<0).
Spontaneity: Because they are thermodynamically favorable, these reactions proceed spontaneously, meaning they can occur without a continuous net input of energy.
The ATP Equation: You should be able to recognize and reproduce the ATP hydrolysis equation and its energy output:
Equation: ATP+H2O→ADP+Pi.
Energy: ΔG∘′= −30.5 kJ/mol.
Visual Literacy: On an exam, you must be able to identify an exergonic reaction and interpret energy diagrams.
Key Association: 
Memorize: Exergonic ↔ ΔG < 0 ↔ Spontaneous.

submissions.name: Sailee Naik
submissions.explanation: I think this version provides an analogy to describe why the smaller particles move slower in gel filtration chromatography. It also has a better layout.
submissions.notes:
-Separates proteins by size only using porous beads.

-Beads act like a molecular sieve inside the column.

-Large proteins can’t enter pores → move faster → elute first.

-Small proteins enter pores → delayed → elute last.

-Student takeaway: Bigger molecules come out first because they take a more direct path through the column.

submissions.name: Kate Liang
submissions.explanation: I thought that the way pH Regulation was explained on slide 45 using the arrow chart that was in the original slide was a little confusing. Instead, I had ChatGPT come up with an analogy and created a fun figure to describe the processes occurring, making it much easier to understand and remember.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
“Left side is the tissues: metabolism adds CO₂, which drives CO₂ + H₂O → H₂CO₃ → HCO₃⁻ + H⁺, so pH drops. That extra H⁺ shifts hemoglobin toward releasing O₂—Bohr effect—so O₂ delivery increases where CO₂ is high.
Right side is the lungs: we exhale CO₂, pulling the reaction back upward so H⁺ is consumed and pH rises. Higher pH favors hemoglobin loading O₂, and O₂ binding helps unload H⁺/CO₂ to be exhaled—Haldane effect.”

Student takeaways:
- ↑CO₂ → ↑H⁺ → pH ↓ (bicarbonate buffer shifts right).
- Tissues: low pH / high CO₂ → Bohr effect → Hb releases O₂.
- Lungs: CO₂ exhaled → H⁺ consumed → pH ↑ → Hb loads O₂.
- Haldane effect: O₂ loading in lungs promotes H⁺/CO₂ release → more CO₂ exhalation.
- Buffer chemistry is the link between respiration, pH, and hemoglobin function.

submissions.name: Aneta Kaminski
submissions.explanation: This image is more visually appealing than the original slide because it combines the formal equation with a clear, intuitive visual that makes the concept easier to grasp. For learners like me who understand best by seeing the math worked alongside an example, it helps connect the symbols in the equation to what is actually happening biologically. Instead of just stating that Kd equals L₁/₂, the image shows how that result comes from the equation and what 50% binding looks like in context. Having both the algebra and a concrete example together makes the math feel less abstract and significantly improves understanding.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: This slide introduces the equilibrium dissociation constant and shows why Kd equals the ligand concentration at which half of the receptors are bound. Walk through the equation step by step, emphasizing that at 50% occupancy the concentration of free receptors equals the concentration of bound receptors, which allows the expression to simplify. Use the visual example to reinforce that Kd represents a midpoint of binding, not a count of receptors or ligands.
Student takeaways: Kd is a concentration that reflects binding affinity and corresponds to 50% receptor occupancy. At this point, half the receptors are bound and half are unbound, which is why Kd equals L₁/₂. Understanding this conceptually and mathematically helps interpret binding curves and avoids mixing receptor numbers with concentrations.

submissions.name: Jackson Gayeski
submissions.slideRaw: before slides 31-35 (some information from those slides not included in mine)
submissions.explanation: I found the information from the current slides from 31-35 to be largely carried by the presenter's notes; I also do not find it particularly visually appealing due to their format and "whiteness." I found this to hide the key distinctions of the charged amino acids. So, I designed a slide that summarizes the main ideas of the slides, including the individual molecules, color-coded groupings (to better associate the molecules with their charge) based on charge, and "the special one" (Histidine), and summarizes the main facts about each amino acid in very dense (but short) lines of text. Particularly for Histidine, I tied in the Bhor effect and highlighted that this is a frequent exam question, so students would be more aware.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
Charged residues are the ionic players: they have many roles in metabolic pathways, including binding DNA and catalyzing reactions (can also cause diseases when mutated). Lysine and Arginine-> the positive workhorses. Aspartate and Glutamate-> the negative anchors. But Histidine? Histidine's pKa is 6, close enough to our pH of 7.4 to toggle between charged and neutral, making it a key catalyst amino enzyme, particularly for controlling the binding of hemoglobin to O2 (Bhor effect). 

Student Key takeaways
1. 5 amino acids carry charge-> know which ones carry which charge
2. Know the side chains of each charged amino acid and what roles they embody (generally)
3. Histidine is special because of its pKa near physiological pH (7.4), allowing it to toggle between positive and neutral; it is essential for enzyme catalysis.
4. Clinical connection: Hemoglobin uses Histidine protonation (Bohr effect) to control oxygen affinity; sickle cell disease removes a negative charge (Glu→Val), causing aggregation (shown in later slides)

submissions.name: Sarina Nayak
submissions.explanation: In the original slide, I found the large blurb of text and graph of protein concentration vs. salt concentration to be unhelpful for first learning a new concept. However, the new slide presents a helpful analogy to help students better learn the concept of salting out and is less dense in text, helping students understand visually as well. This slide should be placed after the introduction of the various methods to purify proteins, in place of the current Slide 14.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes

Hook: "Salting out is a 'tug-of-war' for water—add enough salt, and the water molecules will abandon the proteins to swarm the salt instead."

Key Points:
Low Salt (Salting In): Ions shield protein charges, helping them stay dissolved.
High Salt (Salting Out): Salt 'steals' the water's attention, stripping the protein’s hydration shell.
Aggregation: Unprotected proteins collide and stick together, forming a precipitate.
Reagent: Ammonium sulfate is the go-to because it’s highly soluble and stabilizes protein structure.

Preempt Misconception: Salt doesn't just "kill" solubility across the board. It is selective. Different proteins "crash" at different salt percentages, allowing us to fractionate them.

Transition: You’ve crashed your protein out, but now it’s trapped in a salty pellet. How do we get the salt back out?

📚 Student Study Signals

Core Takeaway: Salting out is competitive dehydration. It’s a "crude" purification step used to separate proteins based on their surface hydrophobicity.

Terms to Memorize: Hydration shell, Ionic strength, Ammonium sulfate fractionation.

Exam Framing: * Mechanism: Explain the transition from protein-water interactions to salt-water interactions.

Selectivity: Why does a hydrophobic protein precipitate at a lower salt concentration than a hydrophilic one?

This slide should be presented as number 18 in the lecture 3 slideshow, where the original slide was.
submissions.notes:
- there are 7 ionizable amino acids: arginine, tyrosine, lysine, cysteine, histidine, glutamate and aspartate
-Ionizable side chains affect charge and binding 
- The "Golden" Rule: 
-pH > pKa = Deprotonated form
-pH < pKa = Protonated form

submissions.notes:
"Chapter 7 answers: What makes enzymes so fast? What makes them so specific? How do they actually work?"

Transition: "Let's start with a roadmap of where we're going.”

Student takeaways:
Enzymes are protein catalysts that accelerate reactions without being consumed
This chapter bridges thermodynamics (will it happen?) and kinetics (how fast?)

Memorize: The distinction between thermodynamics and kinetics is fundamental
Exam framing: Conceptual

submissions.name: Logan Kucharski
submissions.explanation:
Original slides introduced Kd through equations and binding curves but lacked an intuitive physical interpretation.

This redesigned slide uses a parking lot analogy to visually demonstrate how Kd represents the ligand concentration at 50% receptor occupancy.

By contrasting weak versus tight binding, students can immediately see why high Kd corresponds to low affinity and low Kd corresponds to high affinity.

The legend explicitly maps the analogy to biochemical terms (ligand and receptor), reinforcing conceptual understanding.
submissions.notes:
Think of receptors as parking spots and ligands as cars.

For weak binding, cars don’t stay easily — you need many ligand molecules before half the receptors are occupied. That’s a high Kd.

For tight binding, only a few ligands are needed to fill half the receptors — that’s a low Kd.

So Kd is simply the ligand concentration at which 50% of receptors are bound, and lower Kd always means stronger affinity.
• Kd is the ligand concentration at 50% receptor occupancy
• High Kd = weak binding
• Low Kd = tight binding
• Kd reflects binding affinity

submissions.name: Natalie Torrence
submissions.explanation: Vo is more similar to poking a hole in the bottom of a bucket. Water immediately rushes out, and there is no gradual increase (that might be seen as a misconception with a race-car analogy), which I think this analogy captures better. It also highlights how the nature of an enzyme as a substrate (the water in the bucket depletes, naturally slows (volume and subsequent pressure decrease). This is more accurate to an enzyme's function because it starts at the highest and gradually slows, while a race car starts slow and then gradually speeds up to its max velocity (acceleration). This "fix" can be put in the sample place in the slide deck (slide 10). Relating this to Vmax you can also add that constantly filling the bucket up with water will increase the pressure of the stream up to a point, however, it will eventually not pour out any faster no matter if you pour more water (ie the substrate in this case) into the bucket.
submissions.notes: Reactions don't accelerate; they decelerate. Just like a draining bucket, the velocity is highest the instant the process begins (Vo).Vmax is determined by the size of the hole, not the amount of water. No matter how much substrate you have, the reaction cannot exceed the physical capacity of the enzyme to process it.

submissions.name: Vishnu Nalluri

submissions.name: Ashley Hwang
submissions.explanation: The new version is better because it explains it in a way that is more quickly and easily understandable- the visual analogy of a1-antitrypsin deficiency, and how it has two impacts from just one mutation (and how those two effects are connected together). This new slide can be used to either replace or supplement the existing slide to help it click better for students.
submissions.notes:
α₁-Antitrypsin (AAT): what it normally does

α₁-Antitrypsin is a protein made in the liver and released into the blood.

Its job:

👉 Travel to the lungs
👉 Block neutrophil elastase

Neutrophil elastase = enzyme that chews up elastic tissue in alveoli.

So normally:

Liver → makes AAT → AAT protects lungs

Think:

AAT = lung bodyguard

⸻

🧬 The mutation (Z mutation)

The slide shows:

Glu342 → Lys

One amino acid changes.

This causes:

❌ AAT misfolds

Misfolded proteins don’t behave normally.

⸻

Problem #1 — Liver disease (gain of toxic function)

Because AAT is made in the liver:
	•	Misfolded AAT gets stuck inside liver cells
	•	It clumps together (aggregates)
	•	Liver cells are damaged

So:

Misfolded AAT accumulates → liver injury

This is why babies or adults can get:
	•	hepatitis
	•	cirrhosis
	•	liver failure

This is a toxic buildup problem.

⸻

Problem #2 — Lung disease (loss of protective function)

Since AAT is trapped in liver cells:

Very little reaches the lungs.

So:
	•	Neutrophil elastase is unchecked
	•	Elastase destroys alveolar walls
	•	Leads to emphysema

This is a missing protection problem.

⸻

Liver:

Misfolded AAT aggregates inside hepatocytes → liver damage
(gain of toxic function)

Lungs:

Not enough AAT in blood → elastase destroys alveoli → emphysema
(loss of normal function)

⸻

Student Takeaways — Bottom Line
	•	α₁-Antitrypsin is made in the liver and protects lungs from elastase.
	•	Z mutation causes AAT to misfold.
	•	Misfolded AAT accumulates in liver cells → liver damage.
	•	AAT is not secreted into blood → lungs lose protection.
	•	Unchecked elastase destroys alveoli → emphysema.
	•	One mutation affects two organs via different mechanisms:
	•	Liver: toxic protein buildup (gain of harmful function)
	•	Lungs: loss of elastase inhibition (loss of normal function)

submissions.name: Jessica Yi
submissions.explanation: This version is better because it uses an analogy that all students will understand, instead of seeing a slide full of sentences (slide 35), which no one will want to read, or a slide full of circles and triangles (slide 36). It uses a baseball glove to easily depict how allosteric inhibition works.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: 
Hook: "Think about your favorite pair of shoes. If I stuck a pebble inside the heel, you wouldn’t just feel it in your heel—your entire walk would change, and your toes would cramp up to compensate. That’s allosteric inhibition: a 'pebble' at the back that ruins the fit at the front."
Explanation: "On the left, we have a normal enzyme. It’s a baseball glove with a deep pocket—our active site—perfectly shaped for the substrate. On the right, an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site on the back. It doesn't block the pocket; it pulls the leather tight, flattening the glove. The pocket vanishes, and the substrate bounces off. The inhibitor never touched the 'ball,' it just broke the tool by changing its shape."

Student takeaways: 
Remote Control: Inhibitors bind to the allosteric site, away from where the action happens.
Shape-Shifting: Binding causes a conformational change—the protein physically warps.
Indirect Block: The active site isn't "clogged"; it’s distorted so the substrate no longer fits.

submissions.name: Caden Cleffi
submissions.slideRaw: Slide 13 "The pH/pKa Rule You'll Use Forever"
submissions.explanation:
The original slide used a seesaw/balance metaphor that was confusing. The improved version replaces it with a clear decision tree flowchart that students can follow step-by-step to predict protonation states.

Problems with the original slide:

The seesaw visual metaphor was not intuitive - students couldn't translate "weight" into molecular behavior
No clear step-by-step process for applying the rule
Missing concrete examples showing how to use the comparison
The "proton flies away" imagery was vague and didn't connect to actual chemistry
Students left understanding there WAS a rule but not HOW to use it

Couldn't predict protonation states at different pH values
Got confused during buffer and titration problems

What the improved version does:

Clear decision tree structure - Shows the exact logical flow: compare pH to pKa → pick a branch → get the answer
Actionable process - Students know exactly what to do: "Compare pH to pKa"
Two concrete examples - Shows the rule in action with carboxyl and amino groups at physiological pH
Color coding - Green = deprotonated, Red = protonated (intuitive and memorable)
Explicit outcomes - States clearly what "protonated" and "deprotonated" mean in parentheses
Bottom banner reinforces the key message - Students leave knowing this ONE rule works everywhere

This improved slide should be placed in the exact same location as the original slide
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
Opening:

This is the single most important decision rule in biochemistry
You'll use this every single day for the rest of the course

The Comparison:
Step one: compare pH to pKa
That's it - just ask yourself: is pH bigger or smaller?

If pH > pKa (Green box):
the environment is MORE basic than the pKa
When it's more basic, the group LOSES its proton
The deprotonated group becomes negatively charged (or neutral if it was already neutral)

If pH < pKa (Red box):
the environment is MORE acidic than the pKa
When it's more acidic, the group KEEPS its proton (it is protonated)
The group stays positively charged (or neutral)

Example 1 - Carboxyl group:
Carboxyl groups have a pKa around 2.3
At physiological pH of 7: pH (7) is way bigger than pKa (2.3), 
Carboxyl group is deprotonated: COO⁻


Example 2 - Amino group:
Amino groups have a pKa around 9.6 
At physiological pH of 7: pH (7) is smaller than pKa (9.6)
So the amino group is protonated: NH₃⁺

Student takeaways:
The pH/pKa comparison predicts protonation state
pH > pKa → group is DEPROTONATED (lost H⁺)
pH < pKa → group is PROTONATED (kept H⁺)
At pH 7: carboxyl groups (pKa ~2.3) are deprotonated (COO⁻)
At pH 7: amino groups (pKa ~9.6) are protonated (NH₃⁺)
This rule applies to ALL ionizable groups in biochemistry

submissions.name: Rob Sullivan
submissions.explanation: I corrected the images to discern a more noticeable difference between low enzyme concentration and high enzyme concentration. I also redid the figure on the left for clarity. Only adding the Km equation and explanations of each variable. I wrote in the definitions as the AI was struggling with spelling.
submissions.notes: Really just slide clarity which focus the eye on important information. feel like that's something this class could benefit from.

submissions.name: Sarah Song
submissions.explanation: The original slide was cluttered with a lot of information that is hard to read. My version is better because it is more readable. This new slide should be presented in the same spot as the original slide.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes (brief speaking points):

This slide links standard free-energy change (ΔG°) with the equilibrium constant (Kₑq).

More exergonic reactions (more negative ΔG°) correspond to a larger Kₑq, meaning products are favored at equilibrium.

More endergonic reactions (more positive ΔG°) correspond to a smaller Kₑq, meaning reactants are favored.

Remember: ΔG° is the free-energy change under standard conditions, while ΔG depends on actual concentrations.

Even if ΔG° is positive, the reaction can still proceed forward if concentrations make ΔG negative.

The table shows how small changes in ΔG° cause large changes in Kₑq because the relationship is exponential.

The conversion box just reminds you of the energy units (J, kJ, cal, kcal) used in thermodynamics.

Student Takeaways:

ΔG° tells you how favorable a reaction is at standard conditions.

Negative ΔG° → large Kₑq → products favored.

Positive ΔG° → small Kₑq → reactants favored.

Actual ΔG depends on concentrations, not just ΔG°.

Thermodynamic relationships are exponential, so small energy changes matter a lot.

Know basic energy unit conversions (J, kJ, cal, kcal).

submissions.name: Lola Fuentes Brock
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation:
My revised slide improves both scientific accuracy and visual clarity. I corrected the chemical structures of proline and cysteine, which were incorrect in the original version, ensuring the modifications are chemically accurate. I also improved the visual appearance of the slide: the original repeated the “rule of 20” message at both the top and bottom, which was redundant, and the bottom box was not a clean rectangle, making the slide look unbalanced. I fixed these layout issues for a more professional and consistent design.

In addition, I added slightly more contextual explanation for each modification so students can better understand why these reactions matter, not just what changes structurally.

The original placement of this slide works well and should be retained. It fits naturally immediately after collagen is introduced, since collagen contains hydroxyproline and benefits from that connection. This slide could also be revisited later in the course during discussions of the proteome, where post-translational modifications help explain how protein diversity and function are expanded beyond what is encoded by the genome.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Note:
This slide shows that proteins are not limited to the standard 20 amino acids.

On the left is proline being hydroxylated after translation to form hydroxyproline. This reaction is catalyzed by prolyl hydroxylase and requires vitamin C, which is why vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy due to unstable collagen.

On the right is selenocysteine, which is formed by replacing sulfur with selenium. Unlike hydroxyproline, selenocysteine is incorporated during translation through UGA recoding and a specialized tRNA, and is often called the 21st amino acid.

The key idea is that these modifications expand protein function without altering DNA.

Student Takeaways:
Proteins are not limited to the 20 standard amino acids
Post-translational modifications alter amino acids after synthesis
These changes expand protein function without changing DNA

submissions.name: Allan Cheng
submissions.explanation: My slide presents a clinical connection of the Henderson-Hasselbach equation by using the example of aspirin permeability to membranes in the blood versus the stomach. My slide can be presented either after slide 40 or in lieu of slide 40. I think my slide encompasses both an explanation of how to interpret Henderson-Hasselbach and a clinical connection to make it more relevant to students.
submissions.notes:
Hook: Why does aspirin work when you take it orally, but other drugs have to be injected? It’s all about the proton "costume."

Talking Points:
Aspirin is a weak acid (pKa​≈3.5): This means it likes to give up a proton, but it will keep it if the environment is acidic enough.
The Stomach (pH 1.5): Since pH < pKa, the acid wins the tug-of-war. Aspirin keeps its proton (COOH). It is neutral and hydrophobic, so it slips right through the membrane.
The Blood (pH 7.4): Since pH > pKa, the base wins. The proton is stripped off (COO−). Aspirin becomes charged and hydrophilic.
The Trap: Charged molecules cannot cross the hydrophobic bilayer. Aspirin is now stuck in the blood, where it can travel to tissues and do its job.

STUDENT TAKEAWAYS

Write down: Ion Trapping: Neutral molecules cross membranes; charged molecules are trapped. Aspirin is neutral in the stomach (absorbed) but charged in the blood (trapped).
Memorize: pH < pKa → Protonated (Neutral for acids); pH > pKa → Deprotonated (Charged for acids).
Exam framing: Application: If a drug is a weak base with pKa 8, where would it be absorbed: the stomach (pH 1.5) or the small intestine (pH 8)?

submissions.name: AK (Annabelle) Gaskin
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
