Additionally none of the structures on the original slide appeared to be correct, so those have all been changed through the same process. I also had AI add a little pirate image on the side for modified after protein synthesis with the proline to hydroxyproline to add a quick way to memorize scurvy as the vitamin c deficiency. AI also helped me make mnemonics for both amino acid exceptions which are added under the structures. Further, at the bottom of the slide I told AI to include the  student takeaways from the original speaker notes. This slide could simply replace the incorrect slide.
submissions.notes:
quick aside—hydroxyproline requires vitamin C (scurvy connection, discuss what scurvy is and why this is important). Selenocysteine is the '21st amino acid.’”
Student takeaway: Some amino acids are modified post-translationally or rarely encoded as included at the bottom of the slide. .

submissions.name: Pravleen Saini
submissions.explanation: I think my new slide is better because it's visually more appealing. When I first saw the old slide I thought it looked really boring and cluttered. I feel like since we don't need to memorize the exact details for a reference guide I would want it to be more straight to the point.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes:
Take EC 2.7.1.1, for example. The 2 tells us it's a Transferase. The .7 narrows it down to transferring phosphorus. The .1 says the target is an OH group. And that final .1? That’s the specific serial number for Hexokinase.
Don’t lose sleep over memorizing these strings of numbers. In the real world, we use this system so a scientist in Tokyo and a scientist in London know they are talking about the exact same protein, even if they call it by different nicknames.


Student Takeaways:
Universal ID: EC numbers are the "Social Security Numbers" of enzymes—they provide a globally standardized way to identify a protein by its function.
Hierarchical Logic: The structure flows from General Class-->Subclass -->Specific Serial Number.
The "Big 6": Focus your energy on the first digit (the Class). That’s what tells you the fundamental chemistry happening.
Exam Framing: You aren’t expected to memorize these just use as a reference

submissions.name: Lilly Krikorian
submissions.explanation: This version is better because it is less redundant. Instead of using bullet points on the slide that present information already available in the graph, the bullet points have been eliminated and the graph has been enlarged. I also made the graph easier to read. This slide should replace slide 32 in the slide deck.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: 

As you can see, we can use two curves to represent myoglobin and hemoglobin binding. The myoglobin curve is hyperbolic (in blue) and the hemoglobin curve is sigmoidal (in red).

It is clear that myoglobin has a lower P50, whereas hemoglobin has a higher P50. But what does P50 mean? P50 is the pO2 when half of the fractional saturation (Y) is bound. Thus, a lower P50 means a higher affinity for O2 binding.

Hemoglobin binds O2 cooperatively (once the first O2 binds, subsequent O2 molecules will bind more easily), which is demonstrated by the sigmoidal curve and requires a higher pO2 to reach the same half-saturation point.

The "Catching Tennis Balls" Analogy

Imagine you are standing at the bottom of a ball pit, and I am throwing tennis balls (pO2) at you. You are trying to catch as many as you can.

Myoglobin (The Greedy Pro): Myoglobin is like a pro athlete with a massive, sticky glove. Even if I only throw a few balls (low pO2), they catch half of them almost instantly. They have a high affinity (stickiness), so their P50 (the number of balls I have to throw before they are half-full) is very low.
Hemoglobin (The Cooperative Team): Hemoglobin is like a team of four friends who have to work together. At first, they are a bit clumsy and drop the balls (low pO2). But once one person catches a ball, they all get in "the zone" and catch the next three easily (cooperativity). Because they start off slow, I have to throw many more balls (higher pO2) before they finally reach that half-full mark (P50).

So, the athlete (Myoglobin) is better at grabbing oxygen when there isn't much around, while the team (Hemoglobin) is better at loading up fast once the supply is high.

Student Takeaway: Lower P50 = Higher O2 affinity = myoglobin; Higher P50 = Lower O2 affinity = hemoglobin

submissions.name: Maria Gaytan
submissions.categoryRaw: New Clinical/Historical Connection, Missing something important that is in the publisher's slide deck
submissions.explanation: In the slide we touch on how BCAAs are essential for muscle growth especially for body builders bit we don't discuss the danger of excessive BCAA intake
submissions.notes: BCAAs are very important in growing strong and healthy muscles however, excessive intake of BCAAs can be very harmful. It can be linked to insulin resistance, obesity, heart problems, kidney strain, and neurodegenerative diseases.

submissions.name: Sophie Kaplan
submissions.explanation: I think my version better illustrates how misfolding can propagate/spread and the issues they can cause. I think the visual illustration would help students better understand the mechanism and help them fully grasp the concept of prions and their effects.
submissions.notes:
Prions are misfolded PrP that can cause normal PrP to adopt the misfolded conformation. This is important because it can lead to aggregation which causes diseases such as mad cow and scrapie. 

Student takeaways: prions can cause misfolding to spread, "bad fold recruits good fold"

submissions.name: Naja Pressey
submissions.explanation: This version is better because it is much less cluttered and easier for most to understand. We use navigation systems all the time to figure out where we are going, so why not have them explain enzymes? This new slide should be presented at the front, maybe after the fourth slide explaining that enzymes are powerful catalysts.
submissions.notes:
Think of a reaction like a GPS trip.
ΔG (thermodynamics) is the destination: Will the reaction happen?
ΔG‡ (kinetics) is the route: How fast will it get there?

Enzymes act like GPS rerouting:
They lower ΔG‡
They give a faster path,
The destination does not change—only the route does.

Student Takeaways (high-yield)
ΔG = “Will it happen?”
ΔG‡ = “How fast?”
Enzymes lower ΔG‡, not ΔG
Same reactants → same products, with or without enzyme
Faster ≠ more favorable

submissions.name: Nishita Koya
submissions.explanation: When determining how to fix a slide from the Chapter 5 notes, I decided to focus on the "Visual Overhaul" aspect. The slide that I chose to alter was unclear as it wasn't immediately obvious whether "deformation" had a positive or negative connotation. So, when creating my new slide, I decided to specify that by including in the title that "structure enables function." Visually, my version is also better than the original slide as it includes two different sections for general properties of red blood cells as well as important concepts to know for the exam. My version also puts all of the information in bullet points instead of just having the information in a random text box and crammed in one place. This helps to organize the information much better. This slide should be presented at around slide 14 of the slide deck.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: 
- Hook: "Your capillaries are narrower than your RBCs — every trip through is a squeeze. 7.5 μm cell through a 5 μm vessel."
- Point to diagram: "Compression and elongation. This isn't damage — it's design. The spectrin network provides resilient flexibility."
- Misconception alert: "Flexibility ≠ weakness. These cells last 120 days making this squeeze thousands of times daily."
- Do the math: "Exam question: 300 million Hb × 4 O₂ each = 1.2 billion O₂ per cell. Write it down."

Student Takeaways:
- Memorize: 7.5 μm RBC → 5 μm capillary. 300 million Hb/RBC. 1.2 billion O₂/RBC. 120-day lifespan.
- Exam calculation: If Hb binds 4 O₂, how many O₂ can one RBC carry?
- Key concept: RBC flexibility maximizes gas exchange surface area — structure enables function.

submissions.name: Julia Skinner
submissions.explanation: This version provides an analogy that students can relate to - highway driving and the EZPass. This version allows students to connect the abilities of enzymes to real life experiences, which further enforces the concept into their head. This slide could be for slide 47 because it explains the role of enzymes and what they cannot do, or it could be after 47 so that it can just provide an analogy to the overall concept.
submissions.notes:
Summary visual — refer back repeatedly:

Enzymes CAN:
✓ Lower activation energy (ΔG‡)
✓ Speed up reaction rate
✓ Help reactions reach equilibrium faster
✓ Provide an alternative reaction pathway

Enzymes CANNOT:
✗ Change overall energy difference (ΔG or ΔG°)
✗ Change equilibrium position (Keq)
✗ Change reactants or products
✗ Make unfavorable reactions favorable

Tagline:
“Same destination. Faster arrival.”

Student takeaways:
• Enzymes affect kinetics (speed), not thermodynamics (outcome)
• Enzymes provide an easier path, not a different final result
• Always separate activation energy vs overall free energy

Memorize:
What enzymes change = rate
What enzymes do NOT change = equilibrium or ΔG

Exam framing:
• Compare energy diagrams with vs without enzyme
• Identify what changes on graphs (peak height changes, start/end stay same)
• Common trick: enzyme lowers barrier, NOT final energy levels

submissions.name: Georgia Brown
submissions.explanation: This slide takes the abstract Henderson-Hasselbalch formula and turns it into a medical scenario, explaining how the body prevents acidosis during exercise. It makes a visual instead of just listing chemical equations. Also, this provides a solid example to the core theme of chapter 2. The slide should go between 50 and 51, as slide 50 states how the bicarbonate system is the foundation of acid-base physiology, which this slide further builds upon.
submissions.notes:
We've seen the Henderson-Hasselbauch equation as a mathematical tool, so now let's see it in clinical action. When exercising, your muscles produce carbon dioxide. Inside a red blood cell, carbonic anhydrase will convert this into protons and bicarbonate. In order to prevent the reaction from hitting equilibrium, which would stop the carbon dioxide transport, the Band 3 Transporter will export bicarbonate into the plasma. To maintain electrical neutrality, the cell will then pull in the chloride ion. This "chloride shift" allows you to sustain exercise without allowing your blood pH to crash.

Student takeaways :
- The reaction : CO2 + H20 --> H2CO3 --> H+ + HCO3- ; driven by carbonic anhydrase
- The shift : to maintain charge balance, Cl- enters the RBC as the HCO2- leaves via systemic tissues
- pH management : hemoglobin buffers the released H+ to prevent acidosis
- Clinical link : defects in band 3 or the carbonic anhydrase may lead to metabolic acidosis and exercise intolerance

submissions.name: Miguel Ballesteros
submissions.explanation: You currently cover Familial Hypercholesterolemia (FH) on Slide 69 to illustrate endocytosis defects. Although you have a slide on the Rough ER and Protein Trafficking, you are missing the most famous "traffic jam" disease: Cystic Fibrosis. This could go in after slide 69.
submissions.notes:
Cystic fibrosis shows that protein trafficking matters as much as protein synthesis.
The ΔF508 CFTR mutation causes slight misfolding; the protein would function, but ER quality-control chaperones destroy it before it reaches the plasma membrane. This is a disease of over-strict compartmental control, where location—not catalytic ability—is the problem.  

The Mechanism: The ER "Quality Control" (chaperones) detects the misfold and destroys the protein before it can reach the plasma membrane.

The Hook: The protein would work if it got to the surface, but the ER is too strict. This is a disease of over-zealous compartmental control.

Takeaway: Trafficking matters as much as synthesis.

submissions.name: Sophia Deng
submissions.explanation: The category that I chose was the Aha Analogy. This new slide would be presented in slide 16 of the Chapter 3 Slide Deck. I believe my version is better because its less wordy, clearer, and easier to read from a distance. The images are engaging and help to break down the confusing topic of how different amino R groups behave into something more memorable. Instead of reading the text on the slide, students can use this analogy to make connections that support deeper understanding and memory.
submissions.notes:
“Here’s a party dance floor where each guest represents an amino acid’s R group. The big water droplet DJ labeled H₂O stands for the watery environment around proteins. Guests who like water—our polar neutral side chains—hang out near the DJ because they can interact with water through hydrogen bonds, shown as the dotted lines to nearby water droplets.

Over on the left, the hydrophobic (nonpolar) guests wear raincoats and cluster together far from the water—this represents the hydrophobic effect, where nonpolar side chains group up to avoid water.

On the right, we have the charged groups. The guests holding + glow sticks are positively charged side chains, and the guests holding – glow sticks are negatively charged side chains. Notice how + and – gravitate toward each other and can form a strong attraction called a salt bridge, shown by the bold clasp/bridge icon.

So this whole diagram is a visual way to sort amino acids by what their R groups do: avoid water, bond with water, or attract opposite charges.”

Student Takeaways: 
- R groups sort by how they interact: hydrophobic (nonpolar) side chains cluster away from water, polar neutral side chains stay near water and form hydrogen bonds, and charged side chains carry + or –.
- Opposite charges “pair up”: positively and negatively charged R groups attract and can form a stabilizing salt bridge (ionic interaction).

submissions.name: McKenna Kundis
submissions.explanation:
The "Fix" Explanation

Problem: Slide 6 presents technical structures but lacks a "why" for student retention.


Solution: This analogy converts abstract ring structures into a "Dress Code" requirement .


Value: It highlights how receptors distinguish near-identical molecules (Estradiol vs. Testosterone) based on the C3 functional group .
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
"Think of the cell as a crowded party driven by random thermal motion . The Receptor is a Bouncer. Even though Estradiol and Testosterone look like twins, the bouncer only looks at their 'shoes'—the C3 functional group. Estradiol wears the 'right shoes' (Hydroxyl –OH) and gets in. Testosterone wears the 'wrong shoes' (Carbonyl =O) and is rejected. This chemical 'handshake' is the engine of cellular order."

STUDENT TAKEAWAYS:
- Molecular Recognition: Receptors discriminate between ligands based on shape and charge complementarity.
- Chemical Precision: Tiny differences (e.g., –OH vs. =O) determine whether a signal is accepted or rejected.
- Specificity: This "pickiness" allows organized pathways to exist within molecular chaos.

submissions.name: Mira Sakhia
submissions.slideRaw: 20; In place of the summary of the six enzyme classes
submissions.explanation: This new slide should be presented in place of the summary of the six enzyme classes. This slide is better as it creates a mnemonic that encompasses all seven enzymatic classes, not just the six and also provides a short definition and example for that new enzyme class. It also utilizes a funny mnemonic to help students remember with easy visuals to explain the concept in a few words.
submissions.notes:
Mnemonic: One Tiny Hamster Lifts Incredibly Large Trucks
Oxidoreductases (electron transfer), Transferases (group transfer), Hydrolases (H2O breaks bonds), Lyases (adds/removes from double bonds), Isomerases (Intramolecular Rearrangement), Ligases (ligation with ATP)
Addition of New Class: Translocases (movement of ions/molecules across membranes)
EC example walkthrough: Hexokinase = 2.7.1.1

Student Takeaways:
Memorize the mnemonic
Do not need to understand EC numbering basics

Exam framing: Match enzyme to class

submissions.name: Maura Saad
submissions.explanation: This slide can be placed instead of the old on. The reason this slide is better is because the chemical reactions make it easy to understand the function of the enzyme and the definition is placed with the sample reaction putting it all together in one image instead of two. The reactions, although simple, are correct and easier to understand than the original slides.
submissions.notes: 6 major classes translocase added recently as the 7th class. enzymes lower activation energy thereby speeding up reactions, enzymes do not change equilibrium constant and function to create both products and reactants based on their respective concentrations and Keq.

submissions.name: Diya Ghosh
submissions.explanation: My version is better because it is more visually appealing and more explicitly explains how the polar neural amino acids still are able to have a charge that allows it to bond to other molecules. Additionally, there is more information about glutamine and how it is a good example of how polar amino acids are biologically important.
submissions.notes:
Polar amino acids are like the diplomats of the protein world—they maintain a neutral overall charge while still having partial charges that are highly interactive with other polar molecules like water. While the molecule is neutral on a macroscopic level, it is "unbalanced" on a microscopic level. The R-groups contain electronegative atoms (Oxygen, Nitrogen, or Sulfur). These atoms act like "electron hoarders," pulling the negative electron cloud toward themselves. This hoarding creates partial negative and partial positive charges. These act like tiny magnets, allowing the side chains to form hydrogen bonds with water (hydrophilicity) and bind to specific enzymes. An example of this in action is Glutamine, unique for having two electronegative atoms in the side chain. It is the primary resource for rapidly dividing cells (like cancer cells) for three reasons: DNA Synthesis - It is a direct donor of nitrogen for RNA and DNA bases; Energy Production - It provides carbon atoms to the TCA cycle (anaplerosis) to generate energy; Stealth Transport - Its overall neutrality allows it to bypass electrical membrane barriers, while its partial charges allow it to bind tightly to transporters and enzymes.

Student Takeaway: Polar amino acids are neutral overall but possess "local" charges that make them essential for cellular life and rapid growth. By striking a delicate balance between neutrality and polarity, these amino acids—especially Glutamine—allow cells to maintain high metabolic rates and build the complex structures required for life.

submissions.name: natalia molina
submissions.explanation: I think the diagram is more simple/straightforward and the explanation is shorter and easier to understand as well. It should be presented in the same place as the old slide.
submissions.notes: SDS coats all proteins with a negative charge, denatures to the primary structure,

submissions.name: Kaya Kuhlmeier
submissions.explanation: I went a little more into affinity maturation and why vaccines can cause it, highlighting that the end product is BETTER antibodies, not just MORE antibodies and using Kd to help describe this.
submissions.notes:
1. Presenter Notes: The Molecular Hunger GamesScript this as your live explanation to the class:"To understand how vaccines actually work, we have to look at them through the lens of Survival of the Fittest. Inside your lymph nodes, there is a literal 'Hunger Games' happening.When the vaccine introduces a small amount of antigen, thousands of B-cells compete to grab it. This is where the math meets the biology. We measure their 'fitness' using the $K_d$ value, or the Dissociation Constant.Think of $K_d$ as a measure of 'slipperiness.' A High $K_d$ means the antibody is weak; it might bump into the virus, but it lets go almost immediately. In this competitive environment, those B-cells are 'unfit.' They can't hold onto the antigen long enough to get a survival signal, so they undergo apoptosis—they die off.However, during Somatic Hypermutation, some B-cells randomly mutate to have a Lower $K_d$. These cells are 'sticky.' They have a massive evolutionary advantage because they can grab the scarce antigen and hold on tight. Because they are the 'fittest,' the immune system selects them to clone themselves millions of times.By the time you get a booster, you’ve filtered out the high $K_d$ 'losers' and are left with an elite army of low $K_d$ 'winners'—antibodies that lock onto the virus and never let go."
2. Student TakeawaysThe "Bottom Line" for the lecture deck:Affinity Maturation = Micro-Evolution: The immune system uses Darwinian principles to "evolve" better antibodies in a matter of weeks.The Selection Pressure: The vaccine limits the amount of antigen available, forcing B-cells to compete.Fitness is Measured by $K_d$: In immunology, "fitness" is the inverse of $K_d$.$\uparrow$ $K_d$ = Weak binding (unfit, eliminated).$\downarrow$ $K_d$ = Strong binding (fit, selected for).The Result: Post-vaccination, your antibody population shifts from a high $K_d$ (micromolar) to a low $K_d$ (nanomolar or picomolar), creating a "high-affinity" defense.

submissions.name: Deeya Patel
submissions.explanation:
The original slide suffers from "cognitive overload." It attempts to teach three complex things simultaneously: the energy landscape (the curve), the mathematical derivation of Delta G, and the kinetic state. The "Crowded Party" graphic works because it isolates a single variable: Concentration. It removes the abstract physics (gravity/energy slopes) and replaces it with a visceral social experience everyone understands (crowding = stress). It makes the math variable Q tangible before they have to solve for it. 

Place this immediately before the current slide (42). You need to build the conceptual intuition first. If they understand why the reaction moves (to relieve crowding), the calculation on the next slide becomes a tool to quantify that movement, rather than just random algebra.
submissions.notes:
Key concept: Chemical Stress = Social Crowding
Where Q = [People in Product Room] / [People in Reactant Room] RIGHT NOW
Equilibrium (Keq) = The perfect party vibe (no one feels the need to leave)
Directionality depends on:
Crowding Stress (RT ln Q) → The "push" from overpopulation
Room Preference (ΔG°) → Which room is inherently nicer (better music/snacks)
High [Reactant] Crowding → Pushes people to Product room
High [Product] Crowding → Pushes people back to Reactant room

Student takeaways:
Molecules behave like people: they hate high-pressure environments.
ΔG is just a measure of how much they want to leave the room.
Memorize: Nature moves to relieve stress (lower Free Energy).
Hook: "Forget the molecules for a second. Imagine you are at a house party with two rooms."

Walk through step-by-step:
Scenario 1 (Forward): The Reactant room is packed. You are squished. You naturally move to the empty Product room. This is Q < K_eq. ΔG is negative (spontaneous move).
Scenario 2 (Reverse): Now the Product room is the crowded one. You get pushed back into the Reactant room. This is Q > K_eq.
Scenario 3 (Equilibrium): People are moving back and forth for snacks, but the crowd size in each room stays steady. No one feels "pushed." This is ΔG = 0

Common errors:
Thinking Equilibrium means "Equal" (50/50 split). Correction: Equilibrium is about comfort, not equality. A tiny room (unfavorable) holds fewer people than a mansion (favorable) at equilibrium.
Confusing Q (Right Now) with K_eq.
Interpretation:
"If ΔG is negative, the party is moving to the Product room. If positive, they are moving back to the Reactant room."

Student takeaways:
Calculations are just a way to measure "crowding."
If you know where the crowd is (Q) and where the comfort zone is K_eq, you know where the people will go.

submissions.name: Evelyn Pritchard
submissions.explanation: This new slide would be presented as the intro to section 7.2 because it gives an analogy that is easier for students to grasp the differences and relationships between apoenzymes, cofactors, and holoenzymes. My version is better because students can easily remember the picture of the car and battery to remember what each term does since it is a familiar object, rather than just looking at drawings of enzymes.
submissions.notes:
## Presenter Notes
The Hook: "Think of our bodies like a fleet of high-performance supercars. The proteins our DNA builds are the chassis and the engine—they look impressive, but without one specific part, they’re just expensive paperweights."

Defining the Apoenzyme: Point to the car with the empty engine bay. "This is the Apoenzyme. In Greek, apo means 'away.' It is away from its functional state. It has the structure, but it’s missing the spark."

The Battery (Cofactor): "The battery represents our Cofactors. These are the vitamins and minerals we eat. They aren't 'fuel' (like calories); they are the hardware required to make the machine run."

The Holoenzyme: Point to the glowing, active car. "Once the battery is installed, we have a Holoenzyme. Holo means 'whole.' It’s now a complete, functional unit ready to catalyze reactions."

The Clinical "So What?": "This is why vitamin deficiencies are so dangerous. If you don't have B12 or Zinc, you aren't just 'low on energy'—your molecular Ferraris are literally sitting in the garage unable to start."

### Student Takeaways
Apo- = "Away" (Inactive protein alone).

Holo- = "Whole" (Protein + Helper = Active).

Cofactors are the "Spark Plugs" or "Batteries" of life; without these inorganic (metals) or organic (vitamins) helpers, metabolism stops.

Clinical Link: Nutritional deficiencies cause disease because they create a backlog of "Apoenzymes" that can't do their jobs.

submissions.name: Julian Kim
submissions.slideRaw: Right after slide 33 about hemoglobin and CO
submissions.explanation: With the information from the prior slide about CO affinity, providing this analogy/meme would be able to keep the students engaged and allow for an easy way to remember the relationship.
submissions.notes:
The "250x" Fact: Emphasize that CO doesn't just compete; it dominates. Its binding affinity is roughly 200 to 250 times greater than oxygen's. Once CO moves in, it doesn't like to leave.

The Mechanism: Explain Competitive Binding. CO and O2 are fighting for the exact same spot: the iron (Fe 2+) center within the heme group.

Takeaway: Affinity is King: Carbon Monoxide has a significantly higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen does, allowing it to displace oxygen even at low concentrations.

submissions.name: Addysen Downey
submissions.explanation: Sickled was spelled as "sickd" on the original slide. Thus, I corrected that in my slide. I also demonstrated the color difference between sickled cells and normal red blood cells (sickled cells are darker). I also wrote out that the flow is clogged in sickle cell, but is smooth in red blood cells, to further emphasize this difference (beyond just the difference in shape of the red blood cells). This slide could replace the slide #4 that serves as the hook to the lecture. It serves the same purpose, but my version resolves the typo and has a slightly more clear diagram.
submissions.notes:
One single amino acid substitution can have profound downstream effects. By the end of this lecture, you all will know how different diseases, like Sickle Cell Anemia, arise from a single substitution. It starts with one substitution, but this results in a complete change in RBC structure, leading to vaso-occlusion and debilitating effects. As the lecture progresses, we will learn the exact mechanism.

Student takeaway: one amino acid substitution can have profound implications on cellular processes and disease.

submissions.name: Vani Gupta
submissions.explanation: This version is better because it explains the concept visually, which often is easier to understand. The slide should be presented after/instead of slide 11.
submissions.notes:
On the left, we see the Normal Sequence. Think of the amino acid sequence as the instruction manual and the bag of parts. If you follow the sequence exactly, you get a stable 3D Structure—the bookcase. Because the structure is correct, it can perform its Function: holding books."

"In biology, if a protein folds into the right shape, it can do its job, whether that’s carrying oxygen or breaking down sugar."

"Now, look at the right side. This is a Mutated Sequence. Imagine the manual had one typo, or we swapped a steel bolt for a weak wooden dowel.

"That tiny change in the 'parts list' (the amino acid sequence) causes the whole frame to tilt. This is exactly what happens in diseases like Sickle Cell Anemia or Cystic Fibrosis. In Sickle Cell, a single amino acid swap causes hemoglobin to clump, changing the shape of the entire red blood cell."

"The structure is now unstable, and as you can see, the books are falling off. The Function is lost. The protein is still there, but it's 'misfolded' and useless."

submissions.name: Reilly O'Brien
submissions.explanation: This slide gives an example of how Mass Spec can be used clinically and efficiently. Slide 54 currently talks about how MS is more accurate than Edman degradation, so this slide would show that accuracy in practice.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: Every baby born in this country receives a 'heel prick' test. We take that tiny drop of blood and run it through an MS/MS instrument to look for PKU. In PKU, the enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase is defective. Using Mass Spec, we aren't just looking for the protein; we are measuring the mass-to-charge ratio of its metabolites. If we see a massive spike in the peak corresponding to Phenylalanine and a drop in Tyrosine, we know within minutes that the child has a metabolic 'circuit break.' Because of this technology, we can start a restricted diet immediately, preventing permanent neurological damage before the first symptoms even appear.

Student Takeaways: Tandem Mass Spectrometry (MS/MS) allows for the rapid, simultaneous screening of multiple metabolic disorders from a single sample.

submissions.name: Lucy Friedman
submissions.slideRaw: Add after slide 27. Make my content slide 28.
submissions.explanation: This case highlights the relevance of nonpolar amino acid size and aromatic ring structure by demonstrating how phenylalanine’s large, hydrophobic aromatic side chain confers a competitive advantage at the LNAA transporter. By connecting side-chain size and ring chemistry to preferential transport across the blood–brain barrier, the case shows how molecular structure directly shapes physiological outcomes. It further situates this principle in a modern context, illustrating how technology-driven dietary exposure to artificial foods can produce real biochemical consequences. This should be included on slide 28 right after slide on nonpolar amino acids.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
This case emphasizes that some depressive or cognitive symptoms can have a dietary and biochemical origin, rather than being purely psychological.
Aspartame, a common sweetener in artificial diet beverages and sugar-free products, is metabolized into phenylalanine.
Increased consumption of these products can raise circulating phenylalanine, a large, nonpolar amino acid with an aromatic ring.
Phenylalanine, along with tyrosine and tryptophan, competes for entry into the brain via the Large Neutral Amino Acid (LNAA) transporter (LAT1) at the blood–brain barrier.
Because this transporter is capacity-limited, elevated phenylalanine from artificial diet beverages can outcompete tyrosine and tryptophan, reducing their brain availability.
Reduced availability of these amino acids can alter dopamine and serotonin synthesis, producing symptoms such as low mood, irritability, or brain fog.
What feels like a psychological change may reflect amino acid competition driven by dietary exposure, not toxicity or personal failure.
Modern artificial diet products can intersect with basic amino acid chemistry to produce real physiological effects.


Student Takeaways: 
Artificial diet sugar free products often contain aspartame, which is metabolized into phenylalanine.
Phenylalanine is large and nonpolar, with an aromatic ring that gives it a competitive advantage. 
Structure and abundance of amino acids directly impact function.
Phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan compete to enter the brain through the LNAA transporter (LAT1).
Increased phenylalanine from diet beverages can crowd out tyrosine and tryptophan.
This competition can affect dopamine and serotonin synthesis, influencing mood and cognition.
Some mood or focus changes can be diet-related and biochemically driven, not purely psychological.
This case shows how “zero-calorie” foods are not biochemically neutral.

submissions.name: Garvey Mckee
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation: The original image does not include how CO2 transports into RBCs as bicarbonate by omitting chloride shift. To maintain electric difference a Chloride ion must enter the cell for every bicarbonate ion that leaves. This version includes that and notes the Hamburger phenomenon that student's can read up on to understand more. This could replace the same slide 41.
submissions.notes: CO2 transport and the bicarbonate system is a way that the body regulates blood pH. Emphasize carbonic anhydrase role in RBC for CO2 conversion. Highlight chloride shift in RBC at tissues requiring Cl- to enter to maintain balance. Show that respiration bows off CO2 shifting equilibrium to the left and raising blood pH.

submissions.name: Faith Ryan
submissions.explanation: This slide should be presented in replacement of the previous slide. I felt like the previous slide had too much going on and the important information was getting lost. This new version has simpler text and visuals while still showcasing what the point of the slide is.
submissions.notes: This diagram shows how all four laws of thermodynamics come together in one equation: Gibbs free energy. The Zeroth Law defines temperature. If systems are in thermal equilibrium, they share the same temperature. The First Law tells us energy is conserved. Any change in internal energy is the balance between heat added and work done. The Second Law states that the entropy of the universe must increase for a process to be spontaneous. The Third Law defines a reference point for entropy: as temperature approaches absolute zero, entropy approaches a minimum.

submissions.name: Maha Mirbacha
submissions.explanation: I thought this slide was kind of boring. I felt that it could be more informative in a way that was more clear. I kind of struggled to understand what it meant. The original slide relies on text to explain "immunological techniques." The new slide provides a visual mental model of what that actually looks like (beads, columns, and specific binding). Students no longer have to imagine what "affinity" means, they can see the antibody grabbing the receptor.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes

Start by reminding the class that therapies like Tamoxifen work because they target the Estrogen Receptor (ER). But historically, we knew about the hormone (estradiol) long before we could isolate the receptor. Ask the class: "If a protein isn't an enzyme, how do you find it in a cell lysate?" Explain that unlike enzymes, ER has no catalytic activity to measure. We can't use a reaction rate to track it. We track it by what it binds to (its "specificity"). Technique 1: Immunoaffinity (Left Diagram): Walk them through the schematic.  Technique 2: Ligand Affinity (Right Diagram): Explain this is the alternative method. Remind students that ER is a nuclear receptor (intracellular), not a membrane receptor. You have to break the cell open completely to get it.

Student Takeaway

Core Concept: The Estrogen Receptor (ER) is a nuclear hormone receptor that lacks enzymatic activity. Because you cannot measure a chemical reaction to find it, you must purify it based on its specific binding properties rather than an activity assay.

submissions.name: Nathalie Bonilla
submissions.explanation: In place of slide 31 (originally titled "From Weak Bonds to pH"), I have attached a new slide to convey that pH is the "master dial" of biochemistry. In the original slide, there is a flow chart that shows pH at the bottom (below everything it affects), which may be confusing when trying to convey that pH is the "master dial" that controls lots of other things. In the new slide, pH is shown at the very top with a bigger "dial" visual, as it is the thing that controls everything after/below it (charge, protonation, weak interactions). There are also arrows to show this flow clearly.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
pH can be considered the master dial for biochemistry. It affects just about everything! This slide demonstrates how it can affect 3 things in particular: charge, protonation, and interactions. Everything here is actually interconnected if you look closely. For example, weak interactions are dependent on charge, and charge is dependent on protonation state, and protonation is dependent on…pH! Therefore, pH can be seen affecting just about everything that is important for biochemical functions. This is seen through this slide here again, with ideal pH levels showcasing optimal/efficient enzyme function and activity. 

Student Takeaways: 
pH is an extremely important determinant of biochemical function. pH affects protonation, which affects charge, which affects interactions, which affects enzyme activity.

I acknowledge that Gemini Pro Nano Banana was used in order to generate the visuals for this slide.

submissions.name: Arya Rajesh
submissions.explanation: This graphic is less cluttered and explains the difference between induced fit and lock-and-key with an analogy. It should replace slide 52.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
The Transition: Contrast the Lock & Key model (left) as outdated because it assumes enzymes are rigid. While it explains specificity, it fails to show how enzymes actually stabilize a reaction.

Induced Fit: Explain the current model (right) using the memory foam analogy. The enzyme is flexible, changing shape to "hug" the substrate.

Catalysis Power: This shape change stabilizes the transition state. The active site is evolved to fit this high-energy state—not the initial substrate—to lower the activation energy barrier.

Student Takeaways
Binding Energy: The energy released during the enzyme-substrate "hug" is the primary force that drives catalysis.

Flexibility = Function: The Induced Fit model is the standard because it accounts for enzyme adaptability.

Evolutionary Target: Active sites are evolved to be complementary to the transition state shape.

Exam Tip: Tighter binding to the transition state (TS) leads to a lower reaction barrier and faster catalysis.

submissions.name: Grace Tadros
submissions.explanation: This revised slide is better because it corrects the definition of catalytic efficiency (kcat/KM), clarifies its physiological meaning at low substrate concentrations, and improves conceptual flow after the introduction of kcat. It should be placed immediately after the turnover number (kcat) slide and before the diffusion-limit discussion in Chapter 8.
submissions.notes: Catalytic efficiency, defined as kcat over Km, tells us how well an enzyme functions when substrate concentration is low, which reflects physiological conditions. It combines catalytic speed and substrate binding into one metric. It measures enzyme performance at low substrate concentration. Values near 10^8 to 10^9 M^-1 s^-1 indicate highly efficient, diffusion-limited enzymes.

submissions.name: Sophia Qamari
submissions.explanation: I believe that my version is better because it captures the main idea of the slide before the presentation progresses into more detail. The previous slide is very busy and it is difficult to determine what the main point of the slide is from the back of the room. It is dark and has a bunch of arrows with two beakers. That is not enough for me to quickly understand the essence of the slide material as I am listening and taking notes. My new version of this slide is less crowded and gets straight to the beginning of the point that enzymes and powerful and specifuc catalysts. There are no small arrows or molecules that can't be determined from the back of the room. This new slide would be presented on slide 4 of the Lecture 7 dec.
submissions.notes:
This slide shows that enzymes don’t change the reaction itself — they change how fast it happens. Biology reuses the same chemistry for different physiological needs.

Without carbonic anhydrase, this reaction is extremely slow; with the enzyme, it happens in milliseconds.

Same enzyme, different tissues, different jobs.

In blood: carbonic anhydrase enables fast CO₂ transport and pH buffering.
Memory hook: Blood = Buffer + Breathe

In saliva: carbonic anhydrase helps generate protons quickly, contributing to taste perception.
Memory hook: Saliva = Sense

Key takeaway: Carbonic anhydrase dramatically speeds up a spontaneous reaction, enabling CO₂ transport and pH control in blood and sensory signaling in saliva.

submissions.name: Cayla Lee
submissions.explanation: The slide is informative; however, it is a little clustered with a lot of small information, making it hard to understand and follow along. I think the new version does a good job of creating a clear distinction between characteristics and the application of hydrogen bonds. It also explicitly states that C-H bonds are not H-bond donors. It is visually easier to follow with the right amount of diagrams / visual aspects. The new slide can remain where it is in the notes.
submissions.notes:
1. The Essentials
A Hydrogen bond is a weak attraction requiring two specific components:
The Donor: An H atom covalently bonded to O or N.
The Acceptor: A lone pair on an O or N atom.Note: S and P are too low in electronegativity to participate effectively.

2. Biological Impact: DNA 
H-bonds form between complementary bases (A-T, G-C). While weak individually, they provide massive stability in bulk across the double helix.

3. The "Invisible" Bond (Crucial Tip)
C-H cannot form H-bonds. Carbon doesn't pull electrons strongly enough; the bond isn't polarized.Result: Methyl groups are "invisible" to water, causing hydrophobicity.

Student Takeaways: Identify: O-H and N-H = Donors. O and N = Acceptors.
Avoid the Trap: Never pick C-H as an H-bond participant on an exam.
Real-world: Serine (-OH) loves water; Alanine (-CH3) hides from it.

submissions.name: Mariana Gonzalez Gomez
submissions.explanation: The island analogy works because it turns a not so interesting graph to look at into a physical survival story: the islands are safe zones where atoms fit, and the ocean is a "dead zone" where they crash. It transforms a boring graph into an intuitive visual where you instantly know that staying on solid ground means a stable protein.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: 

The blue 'Forbidden Ocean' represents the vast majority of possible shapes that a protein cannot take. If a protein tried to fold into these coordinates, its atoms would literally crash into each other, a phenomenon known as steric hindrance.

However, we have two safe havens:

1. The Beta Sheet Archipelago in the top-left, where the protein backbone is extended and flat.

2. The Alpha Helix Isle just below it, where the backbone twists into a tight, right-handed coil.

Student takeaways: 

Steric Clashes are the Enemy: Most (Φ phi, Ψ psi)angle combinations are physically impossible because atoms cannot occupy the same space (the "Forbidden Ocean").

Islands of Stability: Secondary structures like Alpha Helices and Beta Sheets exist because they are the few specific shapes where the protein backbone is stable and free of atomic overlaps.

submissions.name: sierra coppage
submissions.explanation: determining chirality was a concept that I found difficult for a while, and I find the way this new slide presents how to figure it out more understandable. This would go in after the slides talking about L and D isomers
submissions.notes:
I. Layout: COOH at the top, R-group at the bottom.
II. The Rule: If Amino (-NH2) is on the LEFT, it is L. If on the RIGHT, it is D.
III. Biological Fact: Ribosomes only use L-amino acids for protein synthesis.
IV. Exception: Glycine is achiral (it has two H atoms; no "left" or "right").
V. Warning: Never rotate the drawing 90°. It flips the 3D chemistry.

1. Mnemonic: "L = Left." (Amino group on the left side).
2. Orientation: Vertical line must have COOH (top) and R (bottom).
3. Nature's Choice: Life uses L-isomers.
4. Glycine: The only amino acid that isn't chiral.
5. Rule of Thumb: Do not rotate Fischer diagrams 90°; it changes the molecule.

submissions.name: Alex Xu
submissions.explanation: Currently, the slide clutters the screen with the substrates taking a backseat to the labels on the enzyme which appear redudant--the substrate enzyem complex is already made clear with the distinction in color and having the labels for EA and EAB appear to only clutter the screen. Furthermore, the comparison box also displays redundancy and explains the concept in simply a less clear manner than the diagram. Kinetic analysis is also not a core concept that should be on the slide. In this new slide, the central focuses hones completely in on substrate order as an analogy to entering doors either with the sequence mattering or not. Although there are no biological examples on this slide, there exists later slides where this concept is explained and I believe an introductory slide such as this one should explain the concept prior to giving examples that offer no help to a student that does not understand how the process functions initially. There's also a disparity between the connection of the traffic lights with the doors on the right, with the presence of both but not in both slides confusing students.
submissions.notes:
Key point: Ordered sequential reactions have fixed binding order whereas random sequential have flexible binding orders. 

Talking points: In ordered reactions, substrate A must bind prior to substrate B, as it creates a binding site in A's binding. In Random reactions, either substrate A or B can bind first, and both sites maintain their availability. 

Hook: Ordered reactions follow the path of a defined set of doors where you cannot get to where you want to be if you take the wrong sequence--random sequential lead you to the same destination no matter the order of doors taken. 

Student Takeaways:

Sequential bisubstrate reactions form either random or ordered reactions, where either a defined substrate must bind first or either one can. 
 
What to memorize: Ordered- fixed binding sequence, Random - flexible binding sequence

submissions.name: Lloyd Choi
submissions.explanation: I think that the current slide's explanation of using a scale really relies on the student solely memorizing. I don't think the idea of the proton "flying away" frames the situation for the student to easily memorize this pH/pKa rule. By defining the pKa as the molecule's grip and the pH as the environmental's pull, the student is able to memorize and also understand that the pKa is associated with the molecule itself while the pH comes from the environment. The slide would just replace the current one, so it would be at slide 26.
submissions.notes:
Think of pH and pKa as a tug-of-war over a proton.
pKa represents how tightly the molecule wants to hold onto H⁺, while pH represents how hard the environment is trying to pull it away.
If pH is lower than pKa, the molecule wins and the proton stays attached.
If pH is higher than pKa, the environment wins and the proton is pulled off.

Student takeaway: pH vs pKa determines protonation state

submissions.name: Jason Chen
submissions.explanation: This should be after slide 4. It explains Brownian motion better in a more approachable and easily understood manner.
submissions.notes:
Hook: proteins don't huddle together because they like each other, but because the surrounding water is essentially "forcing" them into a corner to regain its own entropic freedom.

Talking Points:
- The "Hydrophobic Attraction" Myth: Clarify that the term is a misnomer; nonpolar molecules do not "seek each other out" via strong attractive forces, but are pushed together by the solvent.
- The Entropy Penalty: Highlight that this localized ordering of water represents a significant decrease in the system's entropy, Delta S < 0, which is energetically unfavorable.
- Maximizing Solvent Freedom: Describe how the sequestration (aggregation) of nonpolar surfaces minimizes the total surface area in contact with water, thereby "liberating" the ordered water molecules back into the bulk phase.

Student Takeaways: 
Write down: Non-Energetic Basis: The hydrophobic effect is not driven by the enthalpy of attraction between nonpolar groups, but by the entropy of the solvent.

submissions.name: Madeline Strouse
submissions.explanation: My slide would replace slide 50 in the Chapter 7 slideshow, I believe this visual of a "shortcut" is more clear.
submissions.notes:
Imagine you’re racing. You have two choices: take the winding mountain road (the orange path) or use the specialized high-tech tunnel (the blue path). Both get you to the finish line, but one is significantly more efficient.
1. Enzymes are Biological Catalysts: They speed up chemical reactions without being consumed by the reaction itself. They don't change the starting materials or the final products; they only change the pathway taken to get there.
2. Lowering Activation Energy: The "Long Way" (Orange) represents the uncatalyzed reaction. It requires more energy and time. The "Shortcut" (Blue) represents the catalyzed reaction. The enzyme lowers the energy barrier, allowing the reaction to happen "sooner" and "faster."
3. The Active Site: The grey structure acts as the Active Site. It is the physical location where the "substrate" (the cars) enters to be processed into the product.
4. Efficiency of Life: Without these "shortcuts," most chemical reactions in the human body would happen too slowly to sustain life. Enzymes make the "impossible" (or the very slow) happen in milliseconds.

submissions.name: Sneha Lakamsani
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation: The old slide did not show the proper conjugated pi bond system that makes heme/porphyrin an aromatic molecule. The new slide version took out any misplaced bonds and ensured the correct number and positioning of bonds on the diagram. This slide can be placed in the same position that it was in the original slideshow.
submissions.notes:
🎤 Presenter Notes
The Problem: In a vacuum, heme prefers CO over O2 by a ratio of 20,000:1.
The Geometry: CO binds linearly (perpendicular to heme), while O2 binds at an angle.
The Mechanism: The Distal Histidine (His E7) sterically hinders the CO. Since CO wants to stand straight up, it "clashes" with the histidine residue.
The Result: This steric clash weakens CO’s affinity, dropping the ratio to ~200:1.
The Bonus: His E7 also forms a hydrogen bond with the angled O2, actively stabilizing it.
📝 Student Takeaways
His E7 Role: Acts as a "gatekeeper" that uses steric hindrance to discourage CO binding.
Binding Preference: 
CO: Forced into a strained, non-linear geometry (decreased affinity).
O2: Fits the pocket and is stabilized by H-bonding (increased affinity).
Biological Necessity: This reduction in affinity prevents poisoning from the CO naturally produced during heme catabolism.
Key Term: Proximal (His F8) is bonded to the Fe 2+; Distal (His E7) interacts with the gas molecule.

submissions.name: Jenna Wade
submissions.explanation: I personally found the difference between what Kcat and Km measure to be confusing, so I thought an analogy would be helpful to explain it. This slide should be presented after the kcat definition is given. The speed dating analogy works because it separates the "Search" Km from the "Action" kcat, helping students distinguish between how well an enzyme grabs a substrate versus how fast it processes it. By framing Km as "pickiness" (needing a crowd to find a match) and kcat as "conversation speed" (how fast you finish the date), it turns abstract kinetic variables into a memorable social narrative.
submissions.notes: Km represents the "pickiness" or Affinity of the enzyme. It is the substrate concentration required to reach half-maximal velocity. Low Km (High Affinity): The enzyme is "eager." It finds a match even when the room is nearly empty. High Km (Low Affinity): The enzyme is "picky." You need a huge crowd (high substrate concentration) before the enzyme finally sits down for a date. Once the date has started (the ES complex is formed), kcat measures the Speed of the interaction. Low kcat (Slow Talker): Even after finding a match, the enzyme takes a long time to finish the date and release the product. High Kcat (Speed Demon): The enzyme processes the substrate and resets for the next "date" almost instantly.

submissions.name: Emily Cobourn
submissions.explanation: The original slide had a typo-- it said "sickd" instead of "sickled," so I corrected the spelling. I also changed the narrowing of the arteries on the sickle cell side of the original slide because that is a longer-term consequence of the sickled red blood cells, and not an immediate consequence of the amino acid substitution. I also added a small image regarding the actual amino acid substitution to give students a more specific idea of what to think about when trying to determine how this substitution causes disease.
submissions.notes:
As we’ve previously discussed, amino acid structure and charge determine its behavior, so even if just one amino acid is changed, it can have a huge impact on the function of the protein. 

We will dive deeper into this disease soon, but for now, think about how this substitution at position 6 could cause normal red blood cells to take on this sickled shape. 

This single substitution leads to changes in the hemoglobin protein, causing the red blood cells to take on a sickle shape, and eventually leading to narrowing of the arteries and other issues after repetitive inflammation. 

Student Takeaways: One amino acid substitution can cause major problems in protein folding, causing serious disease.

submissions.name: Hayden Martin
submissions.explanation: I fixed the chemical structure of Slide 45 in Lecture 5. I wanted to fix the salt bridge formation for point 2 because I feel like the nuance is important here. I also fixed the carbamate formation in point 3. I wasn't able to upload the entire slide due to file size, but I uploaded a powerpoint with the new chemical structures.
submissions.notes: The presenter notes are the same. The main takeaway now is that the protonation of the histidine nitrogen can be seen which is the main driver behind the Bohr effect causing O2 release at low pH.

submissions.name: Sibley Hash
submissions.explanation: The original slide lists several very important concepts but presents them mostly as text. My revised slide shows these ideas visually by cearly connecting amino acid sequnece to protein structure and function, which makes the relatinships easier to understand when looking at the slide. I believe this slide should go in place of the original slide explaining why amino acid sequences matter, before going into more detail about amino acid sequences and binding.
submissions.notes: Amino acid sequence determines how a protein folds, and that folding determines its function. Small changes in sequence can disrupt structure and lead to disease (for example, in sickle cell a single substitution of glutamic acid to valine in hemoglobin changes how the protein behave and in cystic fibrosis a mutation in the CFTR protein/usually a deletion of phenylalanine disrupts protein folding and transport). Comparing sequences across species is also very useful for understanding evolutionary relationships, as conserved regions often reflect shared ancestry and preserved protein structure and function.

submissions.name: Mora Rojas-Hernandez
submissions.slideRaw: Place it right after Slide 19 (“The Brilliance of Km”) or immediately after the ALDH example (Slide 21).
submissions.explanation:
The current slides already include clinical examples for Km (ALDH/alcohol flush) and allostery (gout), but they focus mostly on genetic mutations or enzyme regulation failures. What’s missing is a clear example showing how normal kinetic properties like Km directly influence cell survival and competition in the body.
The hexokinase/cancer metabolism example is stronger because it:
Shows Km as a functional survival advantage, not just a definition.
Connects enzyme kinetics to a topic students already recognize (cancer, PET scans, glucose metabolism).
Reinforces the meaning of low Km = effective at low substrate concentration in a vivid, real-world context.
Links biochemistry to medicine, diagnostics, and metabolism all at once.
This makes the concept more memorable and answers the common student question:
“Why should I care about Km beyond exam problems?”
submissions.notes:
Brief Presenter Notes:
We just learned that a low Km means an enzyme works well even at low substrate levels.
Cancer cells exploit this. Many tumors overexpress hexokinase with very low Km for glucose.
This lets them grab glucose quickly, even when nutrients are limited.
That’s actually how PET scans detect tumors — they light up where glucose uptake is highest.
So Km isn’t just a number — it can determine which cells win in a competition for fuel. Student Takeaways (what to remember for exams):
Low Km = enzyme works efficiently at low substrate concentration.
Cells with low-Km enzymes can outcompete others when nutrients are scarce.
Cancer cells often rely on high glucose uptake (Warburg effect).
Enzyme kinetics concepts like Km can explain real medical tools (PET imaging).
Km differences matter physiologically, not just mathematically.

submissions.name: Khushi Rana
submissions.explanation: The original lecture separates thermodynamics (ΔG) and kinetics (ΔG‡) across multiple slides, which makes it difficult for students to connect why enzymes affect reaction rate but not equilibrium. This slide replaces abstract reaction-coordinate diagrams with a single physical analogy (mountain vs. tunnel) that simultaneously shows the energy barrier and the start/end free energy levels. By keeping the destination identical in both cases, the visual makes it immediately clear that enzymes change the path (kinetics) without changing favorability (thermodynamics). This slide should be presented immediately before the Gibbs Free Energy discussion to anchor the distinction early.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
I want to clear up the biggest conceptual trap students fall into in biochemistry. On exams, students are often asked whether an enzyme makes a reaction more favorable. The answer is no. Thermodynamics is the difference in altitude between where you start and where you finish—that’s ΔG. If you are at a higher elevation, going downhill is spontaneous. But if there is a massive mountain in the way, you still won’t get there quickly. That mountain represents the activation energy, ΔG‡, which determines kinetics. Enzymes do not flatten the mountain or move the valley. They act like a tunnel, providing an alternative pathway that lowers the barrier. Notice that the starting and ending elevations are identical whether you climb the peak or take the tunnel. That’s why enzymes affect rate, not equilibrium.

Student Takeaways:
• Thermodynamics (ΔG) determines whether a reaction can occur spontaneously and depends only on the start and end energy.
• Kinetics (ΔG‡) determines how fast a reaction occurs and depends on the height of the energy barrier.
• Enzymes lower the activation energy by providing an alternative pathway but do not change ΔG or Keq.
• Exam Tip: If a question asks whether an enzyme changes ΔG or Keq, the answer is No.

submissions.name: Reese Kennedy
submissions.explanation: The revised slide improves on the original by using a origami analogy to clearly represent protein folding and unfolding, which makes the core idea of Anfinsen’s experiment visually cohesive. Instead of relying on abstract enzyme shapes and chemical schematics, the origami imagery directly reinforces the concept that the protein can unfold and refold back into its correct structure without external instructions, just like a sheet of paper returning to the same origami form. This slide should be presented after the initial explanatory slide describing Anfinsen’s experimental setup and results, where it can serve as a conceptual reinforcement that helps students visualize the experiment’s main conclusion.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
- This slide uses origami as an analogy to help visualize Anfinsen’s experiment.
- Urea and β-mercaptoethanol unfold the protein by breaking noncovalent interactions and disulfide bonds, making the enzyme inactive—like crumpling an origami figure.
- When these chemicals are slowly removed, the protein refolds on its own and regains activity, just as origami returns to its original shape.
- The key point is that no external guide is needed for correct folding—the instructions are already built in.

Student Takeaways
- Proteins can renature and regain function after denaturation.
- The primary amino acid sequence contains all the information needed for proper folding.
- Disulfide bonds form correctly only after the protein begins folding.
- Anfinsen’s experiment shows that protein structure is sequence-dependent, not dictated by the environment.

submissions.name: Akshara Reddy
submissions.explanation: My version adds a visual analogy that helps to really distinguish enzyme types that could be easily confused such as lyase and ligase. This new slide should be presented in lieu of the current slide #11, which simply displays the definition of the enzyme is very unappealing to the eye.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: Think of your cell as a busy construction site. Enzymes are the specialized crew members that make all the work happen.
Look at the first two panels. These are your movers. Number 1, Oxidoreductase, is like the site Electrician. It manages power by moving electrons—represented by that battery—from one molecule to another to keep energy flowing. Number 2, Transferase, is your Crane Operator. Its whole job is to pick up a specific piece—like that 'P' brick—and move it from one truck to another. Next, we have the demolition team. The key difference here is how they break things. Number 3, Hydrolase, is the Water-Jet Cutter. It breaks chemical bonds, but it absolutely must use water—that high-pressure hose—to make the cut. Number 4, Lyase, is just 'The Breaker.' It snaps bonds with brute force, like a sledgehammer, without using any water. Finally, we have the builders and organizers. Number 5, Isomerase, is the Rearranger. It doesn't add or remove parts; it just moves the furniture around inside the same room to create a new layout. Number 6, Ligase, is the Welder. It joins two separate pieces together to build something bigger. Notice the fuel tank? That’s because building requires energy, usually ATP. And lastly, Number 7 is Translocase, the Gatekeeper. It doesn't build or break; it controls the flow of materials in and out through the security fences, or membranes, of the cell.

Student takeaways: 
The Bottom Line: Enzyme Classes

Oxidoreductase: The Electrician — They move electrons (Redox reactions).

Transferase: The Crane Operator — They move functional groups (like phosphates) from one molecule to another.

Hydrolase: The Water-Jet Cutter — They break chemical bonds by adding water.

Lyase: The Breaker — They break bonds without water, often leaving a double bond behind.

Isomerase: The Rearranger — They shuffle atoms around within the same molecule to change its shape.

Ligase: The Welder — They join two molecules together (this usually costs ATP energy).

Translocase: The Gatekeeper — They move molecules across a cell membrane.

submissions.name: Mackayla Raynor
submissions.explanation: The redesign replaces a cluttered, data-heavy table with intuitive icons and extreme time-scale comparisons to make the magnitude of enzymatic acceleration ($10^{17}$) immediately obvious from the back of the room. The new medical slide should be inserted after the discussion of transition states and binding energy (around Slide 40-45) to ground abstract theory in the real-world success of HIV protease inhibitors.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: Emphasize that OMP decarboxylase turns a 78-million-year "geologic" wait into a millisecond reaction, while HIV drugs prove that mimicking the high-energy transition state is the most effective way to "freeze" viral enzymes.

Student Takeaways: Enzymes provide a staggering speed boost necessary for life, and understanding their preference for the transition state allows scientists to design life-saving medications like protease inhibitors.

submissions.name: Lauren Kenah
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Explanation/Analogy, I am in pod 6 but before the extra credit was assigned I actually came up with a visual using Gemini Pro Nano Banana to help me understand Keq and concentration. I had AI come up with an analogy that helped it stick and then I asked to make a visual. It really helped me so I wanted to share it!!
submissions.explanation:
🧠 The "Aha!" Analogy: Is a concept explained in a confusing way? Create a visual analogy that makes it click immediately (e.g., explaining Competitive Inhibition using a parking lot analogy).

I was having a really hard time understanding Keq. I thought it was about total concentration on each side being equal. I wasn't understand it was about the ratio, that forward and reverse reaction rates were equal. Then when I learned enzymes didn't have an effect on Keq I was even more confused. Instead of making the enzyme climbing through the mountain a whole different slide, I was thinking you could relate the concept back to the idea that enzyme activity does not change Keq with the bridge analogy. I kept building the analogy and realized I could relate it to Q as well!
submissions.notes:
Imagine reactants and products as people on two islands connected by a bridge. The reaction is at equilibrium when people cross both ways at the same rate. Depending on the reaction, more people may naturally end up on one island than the other, reflecting whether the equilibrium favors reactants or products. An enzyme is like a moving walkway on the bridge: it lets people cross faster, so equilibrium is reached sooner, but the final ratio of people on each island (the equilibrium concentrations) doesn’t change.
Q is like taking a picture before people on bridge have reach equilibrium- how many on each island tells you where net movement will be to reach Eq.
*tells you which way traffic should flow to reach equilibrium

submissions.name: Kayla Wise
submissions.explanation:
FIX: MODY 2 is better for understanding biochemistry than Gout as it creates a direct, straight line from a math variable to a symptom. MODY2 focuses on understanding sensitivity and thresholds, which are deeper, more complex physiological concepts than simple inhibition.This version gives further insight is not just math but highlights sensitivity.
In MODY2, a mutation raises Glucokinase's Km​, making the pancreas 'blind' to normal sugar levels. It basically breaks the body's thermostat, showing how a single kinetic number controls your metabolic set-point. It should go after slide 46.
submissions.notes:
Key insight: MODY2 proves Km​ is a sensitivity setting: raising it makes the pancreas blind to glucose.

Hook: “A single shift in Km​ can make your pancreas blind to blood sugar.”

Clinical connection: High Km​ raises the glucose set-point, causing mild hyperglycemia.

Student study signals:
Core takeaway: Raising Glucokinase Km​ desensitizes the body's sensor, resetting the metabolic thermostat to maintain a permanently higher blood sugar baseline.
Exam framing: How does increased glucokinase Km lead to MODY2?

submissions.name: Isabelle Wu
submissions.explanation: The "Smart Sprinkler" analogy is superior to standard text-heavy slides because it solves the abstraction problem of feedback inhibition. While students often understand that a product inhibits an enzyme, they frequently struggle to visualize allosteric control. This new slide should be presented after slide 37.
submissions.notes:
Hook: Ask the class: "If the rose bush is soaked, why would you let water continue to fill the hose?" Emphasize that in biochemistry, "water" is ATP and carbon skeletons. 
Highlight the "Committed Step": Point out that e1 is the "Main Valve." Once you pass it, the cell is committed to that pathway. 
Differentiate Inhibition: Explicitly state that the wireless signal (F) is an allosteric inhibitor, not a competitive one. It binds to the "sensor" (regulatory site), not the "spout" (active site). The T vs. R Connection: Link this to the next section by explaining that the feedback signal "locks" the faucet handle in the T-state (Tense/Off). 📝 

Student Takeaways:
The Committed Step: Feedback inhibition almost always targets the first unique step of a pathway (e1) to prevent wasting energy and intermediates. 
Allosteric Site: The end-product binds to a regulatory site that is physically distinct from the active site. 
Homeostasis: This mechanism acts as a "molecular thermostat," ensuring the cell only produces what it currently needs. 
Quaternary Change: Binding of the inhibitor stabilizes the T-state, reducing the enzyme's affinity for its initial substrate. 
Exam Framing: How does the binding of an end-product to a regulatory site affect the enzyme's affinity for its substrate? Explain the 'molecular thermostat' logic of inhibiting e1 rather than the final enzyme in a sequence."

submissions.name: Parker Chapman
submissions.explanation:
Why it's better: This version replaces a static diagram with a dynamic visualization. The distorted, color-coded electron cloud makes the abstract concept of oxygen "pulling" electrons to create partial charges intuitively understood at a glance.

Where to place it: Replace the current Slide 5 entirely.
submissions.notes: Speaker Notes"Let's look at this new visualization of a water molecule. What you are seeing here is essentially an electromagnetic 'tug-of-war.'The Red Zone (Oxygen): The large red sphere represents the Oxygen atom. Oxygen is highly electronegative, which means it has a strong affinity for electrons. You can see the 'mist' of electron density being pulled tightly around it. This creates a region of partial negative charge, denoted by the delta-minus ($\delta-$).The Blue Zone (Hydrogen): Conversely, look at the Hydrogen atoms. Their shared electrons are being 'hogged' by the Oxygen. This leaves the Hydrogen nuclei exposed, creating a region of partial positive charge ($\delta+$).The Geometry Matters: Notice the specific 104.5° angle. If water were linear, these pulls might cancel each other out. But because it is bent, the molecule has a distinct negative pole and a distinct positive pole.The Big Picture: This separation of charge—this polarity—is the defining feature of water. It is the reason water is a liquid at room temperature, the reason it dissolves salt, and the reason life exists at all. It turns this molecule into a 'sticky' magnet that interacts with everything around it."Important Student TakeawaysElectronegativity Drives Polarity: Water is polar because Oxygen is more electronegative than Hydrogen, causing it to pull shared electrons closer to itself.Partial, Not Full Charges: Water does not have full ionic charges like table salt ($Na^+$ or $Cl^-$). It has partial charges ($\delta+$ on H, $\delta-$ on O), creating a permanent dipole.Structure Function Relationship: The bent shape (104.5°) is critical; without it, the dipole moments would not create a polar molecule.Foundation of Biochemistry: This simple polarity is the basis for Hydrogen Bonding, which we will discuss next as the force that holds DNA together and folds proteins.

submissions.name: Kimberly Hernandez
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Explanation/Analogy
submissions.explanation:
The revised wording is more accurate because it distinguishes where energy is invested from where the peptide bond is formed.
While peptide bond formation is energetically unfavorable, the ribosome does not directly supply energy or hydrolyze ATP to form the bond. Instead, ATP is consumed earlier during aminoacyl-tRNA charging, creating a high-energy ester bond that drives peptide bond formation during translation. The corrected version prevents the common misconception that the ribosome itself “pays” the energetic cost.
submissions.notes:
Our first constraint: the peptide bond.
Peptide bonds link amino acids. Three things to know:

First, they form by dehydration (condensation) synthesis—water is released as the bond forms.
Second, once incorporated into a polypeptide, each amino acid is called a residue.
Third, peptide bond formation is energetically unfavorable on its own, but the required energy is supplied indirectly by prior ATP hydrolysis during tRNA charging, not by the ribosome itself.

The ribosome catalyzes peptide bond formation by using the energy stored in the aminoacyl-tRNA ester bond—the cost was already paid before translation began.

submissions.name: Carol Melek
submissions.explanation: This slide states that proteins are “stained with a fluorescent antibody,” which is misleading. In Western blotting, antibodies do not stain proteins like Coomassie or silver stain. Instead, a primary antibody binds the target protein, and a labeled secondary antibody generates the detectable signal, which is often chemiluminescent, not fluorescent. This incorrect phrasing causes students to confuse gel staining with antibody-based detection, and to misunderstand the role of primary vs. secondary antibodies. Correcting this wording clarifies the mechanism and improves exam accuracy.
submissions.notes:
Western blotting is an antibody-based detection method, not a staining technique. After proteins are separated by SDS-PAGE, they are transferred to a membrane and blocked to prevent nonspecific binding. A primary antibody binds the specific protein of interest, and a labeled secondary antibody binds the primary antibody and generates the signal, often through chemiluminescence. This is different from Coomassie staining, which labels all proteins in a gel.

Student Takeaways:

SDS-PAGE separates proteins by size

Western blotting detects specific proteins using antibodies

Antibodies bind proteins; they do not stain them

Two antibodies are used: primary = specificity, secondary = signal

Detection is commonly chemiluminescent, not fluorescent

submissions.name: Mustafa Baryal
submissions.explanation:
The current slide text explicitly asks, "That pizza you had last night?", but the accompanying image shows a generic plate of chicken, rice, and broccoli. This creates some confusion but i still got the main point.

It can be fixed on the same slide by replacing the generic food plate with a diagram of a Deconstructed Spicy Pizza to directly match the professor's script and better illustrate the four biomolecules:

Carbohydrates: The Crust (Starch/Glucose).

Lipids: The Cheese & Oils (Saturated fats/Membranes).

submissions.notes: Everything on this slice is biochemistry. The crust is the fuel (carbs) your mitochondria will burn. The cheese is the lipids your cells use to build membranes. The meat provides the amino acids to rebuild your own muscle fibers.
