submissions.name: Camyla Gonzalez
submissions.explanation: The current Slide 17 explains "steric clashes" using abstract molecular geometry, which leads many students to simply memorize "green is good, white is bad" without understanding the why. This new slide uses a "theater seat" analogy to make the concept intuitive: just as you can't rotate your elbows 360 degrees in a crowded theater without hitting your neighbor, atoms in a peptide backbone cannot rotate freely without crashing into each other. This transforms the Ramachandran Plot from an abstract graph into a relatable physical constraint.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: Let's make the Ramachandran plot intuitive. Imagine the protein backbone is like a row of people in a crowded theater. You have two "joints" you can rotate—your phi (φ) and psi (ψ) angles. Theoretically, you could spin around 360 degrees. But practically, if you stick your elbows out at certain angles, you smack into your neighbor. This is exactly what happens in a protein: atoms clash if they try to occupy the same space. The "Green Zones" on the plot are simply the few comfortable positions where everyone fits without hitting each other.

Student Takeaways:
- Steric Exclusion: Most phi (φ) and psi (ψ) angle combinations are forbidden because atoms physically crash into each other (steric clashes).
- The 15% Rule: Only about 15% of all possible backbone conformations are energetically favorable.
- Green Zones: The "allowed" regions on the Ramachandran plot correspond to stable structures like α-helices and β-sheets where no clashes occur.

submissions.name: Elizabeth Drauszewski
submissions.explanation: While the current deck briefly mentions diabetes biomarkers, MSUD is the primary genetic disorder directly caused by BCAA metabolic failure. Including it fulfills the "Integration" target of connecting specific biochemical structures to real-world medical scenarios. While the current deck briefly mentions diabetes biomarkers, MSUD is the primary genetic disorder directly caused by BCAA metabolic failure. Including it fulfills the "Integration" target of connecting specific biochemical structures to real-world medical scenarios.
submissions.notes:
Brief Presenter NotesThe Disease: Introduce Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) as the critical clinical contrast to the bodybuilding "Power Trio" of BCAAs.
The Block: Explain that a missing enzyme (branched-chain-alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase) prevents the breakdown of Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine.
The Symptom: Mention that the signature "maple syrup" smell comes from a specific byproduct of Leucine that spills into the urine.
The Danger: Leucine buildup is neurotoxic, making this a medical emergency if not managed by a strict diet.
Student Takeaways
BCAA Disease: Associate the "branched" amino acids (Leu, Ile, Val) with Maple Syrup Urine Disease.
Mechanism: MSUD is a failure of catabolism (breakdown), not synthesis.
Clinical Marker: Sweet-smelling urine and neurological symptoms are the primary indicators of toxic BCAA levels.

submissions.name: Ariana Ipakchi
submissions.explanation: The new slide includes more bullet points that present the clear idea of what Anfinsen's experiment contained rather than simply describing who Anfinsen was. It gives an efficient description of what Anfinsen did and showed through his experiments. The slide, which is related to slide 53, also uses both words and a diagram to make the explanation easier for students.
submissions.notes:
Brief presenter notes: Christian Anfinsen was a biochemist who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his experiment involving protein folding. After using Urea and Beta-mercaptoethanol to denature the protein, Anfinsen showed that the protein would spontaneously return to its normal structure after the agents had been removed. Therefore, he proved that the information required for folding is contained in the amino acids of the protein.
Student takeaways: By showing that a denatured protein could return to its initial state spontaneously, Christian Anfinsen's experiment showed that the information required for protein folding is in the amino acids.

submissions.name: Hannah Rowlett
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Explanation/Analogy
submissions.explanation: I fixed a spelling error on the slide for credit and historical purposes, added short, one-line student takeaways that would be easier for studying, and I felt the need to include some exam traps so that way concepts are not mixed up, and it clears up any assumptions that could be made about the content of the slide
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: 
“This graph shows how reaction velocity changes as substrate concentration increases, with enzyme concentration held constant. At low substrate levels, shown at point A, velocity increases proportionally with substrate concentration.

As we move to point B, velocity continues to increase, but less dramatically because more enzyme active sites are occupied. By point C, the enzyme is nearing its maximum operating capacity.

At point D, the reaction reaches Vmax. The enzyme is saturated with substrate and working as fast as it can, so adding more substrate will not increase the reaction rate.”


Student Takeaways
Reaction velocity (V₀) increases as substrate concentration increases

At low [S], velocity is proportional to substrate concentration

At moderate [S], velocity still increases but not proportionally

At high [S], the enzyme becomes saturated

Vmax is reached when all enzyme active sites are occupied

Once at Vmax, adding more substrate does NOT increase velocity

This curve explains why enzymes have a maximum speed limit


Common Exam Traps (Short Version)
ΔG < 0 ≠ fast reaction
Thermodynamics tells if a reaction can happen, not how fast.

The enzyme does NOT slow down at high [S]
The plateau means enzyme saturation, not inhibition.

Vmax is not a visible peak
It’s an asymptote that is approached, not reached.

Doubling [S] does NOT always double velocity
Only true at low substrate concentrations.

Velocity ≠ amount of product
V₀ is a slope, not a single time point.

Vmax depends on enzyme concentration
More enzyme → higher Vmax.

submissions.name: Reese Burgener
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation:
My version is better because it correctly shows the positively-charged sodium being attracted to the negatively-charged chlorine in the top left (the original AI-generated graphic included a chlorine being attracted to a chlorine).
My version also (in the top right) correctly shows the partially-positively charged hydrogen atoms of water being attracted to the negatively-charged chlorine atom (the original AI-generated graphic showed the partially-negatively-charged oxygen of water attracted to chlorine).
I also made sure to include both hydrogens in all of the pictured water molecules (lest they be interpreted as hydroxyl groups).

I manually made these changes by coloring over the mistakes and then pasting images from elsewhere on the slide into the right molecular positions!

This slide should be presented in the same place it was before in the slide deck (11).
submissions.notes:
Hook:
The Gulliver Effect: Many weak water-ion interactions can overcome strong ionic lattices.

Talking Points:
- Dry NaCl: strong ionic bonds, melting point ~800 °C
- Add water: high dielectric constant (D ≈ 80) shields charges; hydration shells form → crystal dissolves
- Thermal motion: Brownian motion provides kinetic energy to ions
- Protein salt bridges: ~3–5 kcal/mol, dynamic, rearrange easily

Misconception to Preempt:
Dissolution ≠ breaking bonds. It’s mainly charge shielding and solvation energy.

Transition:
Next: How hydration shells stabilize ions in solution.

Student Takeaways:
- Write down:
Gulliver Effect: Many weak interactions can collectively overcome strong bonds.
Salt dissolves: Water shields charges + forms hydration shells, not by “breaking” bonds.
- Memorize:
Protein salt bridges: ~3–5 kcal/mol contribution to stability; dynamic and rearrange easily.
- Exam framing:
Predict consequences: Removing or mutating a salt bridge affects protein stability by altering weak ionic interactions.

submissions.name: Grace Purinton
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Explanation/Analogy
submissions.explanation:
1st: In this slide, I added the correct structure of CO2, it was pretty garbled and didn't have the right number of bonds. Now it has the actual molecular structure. I kept the structure of H2O the same because I was just depicting the heteroatoms and carbons in all of the structures. I could not figure out how to make the CO2 have the right format in PowerPoint or in the photo editing app I used. This would be a "factual fix". I have just copied and pasted your description as I didn't have to change much about the slide. ​

https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Carbon-Dioxide#section=Structures

2nd: I thought that a roller coaster analogy could help to explain the energy amount needed change and rate of reaction with an enzyme
submissions.notes:
1st: "We have many different kinds of enzymes that have very different functions in our bodies. They all enhance the rate at which a reaction takes place. Notice that I said 'rate'. This is a kinetic factor and the main thing that enzymes control. We have talked about thermodynamics in the previous chapter and now we are moving up to kinetics! Get ready for a roller coaster...though, because of the kinetics of an enzyme, the roller coaster will be less of a climb and drop." This is what I think you should say. ​

​

Chapter 7 answers: What makes enzymes so fast? What makes them so specific? How do they actually work?"​

Hook: "By the end of today, you'll understand why your patient's muscles are breaking down."​

Transition: "Let's start with a roadmap of where we're going."​

Student takeaways:​

Enzymes are protein catalysts that accelerate reactions without being consumed​

This chapter bridges thermodynamics (will it happen?) and kinetics (how fast?)​

Memorize: The distinction between thermodynamics and kinetics is fundamental​

Exam framing: Conceptual​

2nd: “Think about a roller coaster, it takes a while to get up the hump and a lot of energy if the hump is large. ​

Now imagine a mechanic comes along and lowers the hill. The start point and the end point are exactly the same, but suddenly the ride happens much faster and a lot more easily.​

That’s what an enzyme does.​

The reaction was already thermodynamically allowed. ΔG hasn’t changed, but the enzyme lowers the activation energy. It doesn’t push the reaction forward, and it doesn’t change where equilibrium is. It just makes it easier to get over the hump.​

So when you hear ‘enzymes speed up reactions,’ what that really means is: enzymes lower the energy barrier so molecules can get to the transition state more easily.​

Same destination. Faster ride.”​



Enzymes lower activation energy (ΔG‡), like lowering the height of a roller-coaster hill​

Enzymes do NOT change ΔG, equilibrium, or reaction favorability​

Thermodynamics = will it happen?​

Kinetics = how fast does it happen?​

Enzymes affect rate, not destination​

​

​

submissions.name: Reagan Stallings
submissions.explanation: This slide can stay at 38. I prefer my version because it feels more organized, there is no longer a logo over part of it, and there's more examples/visual aids.
submissions.notes:
Speaker Notes

Start with the beakers: on the left, Exothermic means heat exits the system, so the arrows point out and it would feel hot. On the right, Endothermic means heat enters or is absorbed, so arrows point in and it would feel cold. Below that, the graphs show Exothermic is a downhill release of energy (Delta H is negative), while Endothermic is an uphill climb (Delta H is positive). Finally, emphasize the bottom note: Thermic refers to heat flow (Enthalpy), whereas Gonic refers to free energy and spontaneity (Delta G). Do not mix these terms up.

Student Takeaways

Sign Convention: Remember that negative Delta H is Exothermic (releases heat), while positive Delta H is Endothermic (absorbs heat).

Touch Test: Exothermic reactions feel HOT because they release heat to you; Endothermic reactions feel COLD because they steal heat from you.

Vocabulary Trap: Enthalpy (Delta H) is about HEAT, while Free Energy (Delta G) is about SPONTANEITY. Use the mnemonic "Thermic equals Thermometer" to remember heat.

Key Examples: Combustion and respiration are Exothermic; melting ice and photosynthesis are Endothermic.

submissions.name: Nitya Manikonda
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation:
On slide 48, the diagram labeled "Carbamate" shows the reaction of carbon dioxide with a terminal amino group. While the text correctly states that CO2 reacts with terminal amino groups to form negatively charged carbamate groups, the chemical structure provided in the diagram is mislabeled or misleadingly drawn.

Chemical Structure Error: The product shown as "Carbamate" depicts the nitrogen atom directly bonded to a carbon that has a double bond to one oxygen and a single bond to another. However, the middle part of the reaction shows a red C=O molecule which would imply the formation of a carboxylic acid derivative.

Missing Negative Charge: The text explicitly mentions the formation of "negatively charged carbamate groups" , but the resulting structure in the diagram does not clearly display the negative charge resonance or the anionic nature required to form the salt bridges mentioned later.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: "Alright, let's look at the molecular interplay between CO2 and Hemoglobin. We already know that CO2 is a heterotropic effector, but how does it actually bind? Look at the chemical equation at the top left. The terminal amino groups—the N-termini—of the globin chains are unprotonated at physiological pH. This allows the nitrogen to act as a nucleophile, attacking the central carbon of a linear CO2 molecule. This reaction is reversible and results in a carbamate group.Notice two critical things about this product: First, the reaction releases a proton (H^+), which directly contributes to the Bohr Effect by lowering the local pH. Second, the carbamate group carries a negative charge.If you look at the structural model below the equation, this new negative charge on the N-terminus allows it to form a salt bridge with a nearby positively charged residue, like the Arg or His residues we discussed. These salt bridges are like 'molecular staples'—they specifically stabilize the T-state (the Tense state). By stabilizing the T-state, CO2 effectively lowers hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, which you can see in the rightward shift of the saturation curve on the graph. This ensures that in metabolically active tissues where CO2 is high, oxygen is released right where it’s needed most."  
Student Takeaways:The "Bottom Line" Chemical Mechanism: CO2 binds to the unprotonated N-terminus of globin chains to form carbamate.The Carbamate Reaction: R-NH2 + CO2 -> R-NH-COO^- + H^+.
Dual Impact on Oxygen Release:
1. Direct: The negatively charged carbamate forms salt bridges that stabilize the T state.
2. Indirect: The reaction releases protons (H^+), further promoting the Bohr effect. 
Curve Shift: Increased CO2 concentration results in a rightward shift of the oxygen-binding curve (decreased affinity, increased P50), facilitating O2 unloading in peripheral tissues.

submissions.name: Olivia Lasnicki
submissions.explanation: I was very confused by the concerted and sequential models of hemoglobin binding so I feel like adding an analogy here would be very helpful to students.
submissions.notes:
The concerted model: binding is like a binary on/off switch. All subunits change from T/R (or vice verse) together, like a single switch for the lights of a chandelier. 

The sequential model: binding is like a standing ovation. When the first person stands up to clap, it influences the next person to stand up and clap as well. Similarly, when the first subunit binds oxygen and undergoes a T/R change, it makes the next subunits more likely to bind oxygen and undergo a T/R change as well.

submissions.name: Aaron Silver
submissions.explanation: My new slide discusses a Clinical implication that we have not covered while also proving a big point about free energy and the capabilities of enzymes (what they can and cannot do). The left panel contrasts a healthy cell (where the enzyme acts as a "recycling worker" breaking down glycosaminoglycans) with a Hunter Syndrome cell. In the disease state, the enzyme is missing, causing the substrate (GAGs) to accumulate to toxic levels in the lysosome, even though the breakdown reaction is thermodynamically favorable. Slide 47 states that enzymes "accelerate reactions" but "cannot change ΔG". This clinical case proves that distinction. The breakdown of GAGs has a negative ΔG (it is exergonic) , meaning the "Traffic Light" is Green. However, without the enzyme to lower the activation energy , the reaction velocity is effectively zero. This is why this new slide should go after slide 47.
submissions.notes:
Hook: "We just established on the last slide that enzymes cannot change the 'Traffic Light' color—they can't change ΔG. Here is the ultimate proof of why that distinction matters. In Hunter Syndrome, the light is GREEN (ΔG<0), but the car has no engine."


Visual Walkthrough:

Left Panel (The Mechanism): Ideally, the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase breaks down sugar chains (GAGs). This reaction is Exergonic—it is thermodynamically favorable and releases energy.

The Trap: Even though the reaction wants to happen (Negative ΔG), the activation energy barrier (ΔG ‡) is too high without the enzyme. The cell fills with "trash" not because the reaction is impossible, but because it is too slow.

Right Panel (The Graph): The red line shows the accumulation (Kinetic Crisis). The blue line shows what happens when we inject Elaprase—we provide the "shortcut" through the energy barrier, and velocity instantly recovers.

Student Takeaways:

Hunter Syndrome (MPS II): Deficiency in iduronate-2-sulfatase.
Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics: The reaction remains exergonic (ΔG<0) but is kinetically trapped (rate ≈ 0).
Enzyme Replacement Therapy: Restores reaction velocity, not equilibrium.

Exam Framing:
Trap Question: "In a patient with Hunter Syndrome, has the ΔG of GAG breakdown changed?" Answer: NO. The ΔG is a property of the reactants/products. Only the rate has changed because the ΔG ‡ (activation energy) is no longer being lowered

submissions.name: Beall Roberts
submissions.explanation: The current Slide 11 lists "7 Major Classes," including a new category, but the mnemonic provided later on Slide 20 ("Old Tiresome Harold Loves Indoor Lamps") only covers the original six. This should replace Slide 20 - same location.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
You’ll notice the textbook was recently updated to include a 7th class: Translocases. While the old mnemonic 'Old Tiresome Harold Loves Indoor Lamps' helps with the first six, we’re adding 'Tonight' to make sure you don't forget the enzymes that move molecules across membranes. This is a prime example of how biochemistry is a living science: even the basic categories can expand.

Student Takeaways:
- The 7th Class: Translocases catalyze the movement of ions or molecules across or within membranes.
- Mnemonic Update: Use O.T.H.L.I.L.T. to remember all current classes.
- Exam Framing: Expect "Classification" questions to include Translocases as a correct option for membrane transport reactions.

submissions.name: Andrew Huang
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Explanation/Analogy, 	•	Too busy: big clip-art + long text block = hard to scan during lecture/exam review. 	•	One key idea is buried: why trace β-ME “rescues” activity (disulfide reshuffling → thermodynamic minimum). 	•	Risky detail: “wait >10 hours” is a memorization trap + could be off depending on conditions. Better: “over time (hours)”.
submissions.explanation:
•	Too busy: big clip-art + long text block = hard to scan during lecture/exam review.
	•	One key idea is buried: why trace β-ME “rescues” activity (disulfide reshuffling → thermodynamic minimum).
	•	Risky detail: “wait >10 hours” is a memorization trap + could be off depending on conditions. Better: “over time (hours)”.

Replace slide 55
submissions.notes:
“This is the classic Anfinsen RNase A experiment. First, you denature the protein and reduce disulfides—activity is gone because the protein is unfolded. When you remove denaturant and let it oxidize, disulfides re-form, but many are mismatched, so activity stays near zero. The key trick is adding trace β-mercaptoethanol: it allows disulfide bonds to break and re-form until the protein finds the most stable arrangement. Over time, the disulfides reshuffle into the native pattern and activity returns. The takeaway is Anfinsen’s hypothesis: the amino-acid sequence encodes the native fold, and the native fold corresponds to the thermodynamic minimum—given the chance to equilibrate, the protein finds it.”

Student Takeaways (“Bottom Line” bullets)
	•	Sequence → structure → function (primary sequence encodes the native fold).
	•	Native state is the thermodynamic minimum under the right conditions.
	•	Scrambled disulfides can trap proteins in local minima (low activity).
	•	Trace reducing agent enables disulfide reshuffling → native disulfides → activity returns.

Rescue = “unlocking” the wrong disulfides so the protein can try again until it clicks into the best fit.

submissions.name: Carolyn Tran
submissions.explanation: This image analogy provides a simple mental image analogy that makes the Vmax graphs and concept of low vs high Km easier to understand in its relation to "efficient substrate capture." It should be presented before the technical slide or next to the scenario pictures already on slide 15 so students can understand the "scientific" image fully.
submissions.notes:
The magnet represents the enzyme, while the metal balls represent substrate molecules.
With a low Km, the magnet grabs metal balls easily, even when only a few are nearby.
With a high Km, many metal balls are present, but few stick, showing weak binding. This illustrates how Km measures how easily an enzyme binds substrate. Low Km means the enzyme is efficient at low substrate levels, while high Km means it needs a lot of substrate to work effectively. With this, on a Vmax graph, low Km enzymes reach half-maximal velocity at a lower substrate concentration, while high Km enzymes need much more substrate to reach the same speed.

submissions.name: Kami Petrosillo
submissions.slideRaw: Original slide #46, this slide should be the new #47
submissions.categoryRaw: Added slide for a clinical hook and explanation that ties ELISA and Western Blotting together in medicine
submissions.explanation: This slide would be a beneficial addition to the deck right after slide #46 in Chapter 6. My slide gets a little more specific with the Western Blot explanation by placing it in the context of HIV testing and how it is used, creating an interesting clinical connection for the pre-med students with actual images of the blot. Slide #46 explains western blotting and gel electrophoresis and my slide uses that in the context of HIV testing. It also goes one step further to make a connection between ELISA and Western Blotting, rather than having them as separate pieces of information in our slides. This provides the perfect transition into the ELISA slides after my new, added slide.
submissions.notes:
Hook: "If ELISA is the 'smoke detector' that tells us there might be a fire, the Western blot is the 'thermal camera' that confirms exactly which viral proteins are burning."

Key Points:
Clinical Sequence: Western blotting is utilized as a confirmatory test for HIV only after a patient triggers a positive ELISA screen.

Detection Target: The process works by identifying specific antibodies the patient has developed against known HIV proteins.

Diagnostic Markers: A positive result is defined by the presence of clear bands at specific molecular weights, specifically gp160, gp120, gp41, and p24.

Negative Interpretation: In a negative blot, no specific HIV bands will appear, though non-specific background bands may occasionally be visible.

Student Takeaways:  Students often think the Western blot is used first because it's more specific; emphasize that because it is labor-intensive, it is strictly the second step to confirm the ELISA. The more specific the technique is, the more labor-intensive and time consuming.

submissions.name: Isabella Tribolati
submissions.explanation:
The current lecture slides introduce Km primarily as a mathematical value (Km = [S] at 1/2 Vmax). The "Vending Machine" analogy translates abstract concentration units into a familiar concept of "pickiness" or "hunger". It clearly illustrates that a "Low Km" enzyme is a "High Efficiency" scavenger that can work even when food (substrate) is scarce.

This new slide should be presented immediately after Slide 15 or Slide 17.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes:
"Think of Km as the enzyme’s 'hunger scale' or how picky it is about its food. If an enzyme has a Low Km, it has a massive appetite and high affinity; it’s like a vending machine that is so efficient it can even take a crumpled, dirty dollar bill and still give you a snack. It doesn't need much substrate to get to half-speed because it's so good at 'capturing' what is available.

On the flip side, a High Km enzyme is 'picky.' It's like a high-end vending machine that only accepts crisp, brand-new $100 bills. If the 'concentration' of $100 bills in your pocket is low, that machine just sits there. You need a ton of substrate to get this enzyme to move at a decent rate. "

Student takeaways:
Km = Substrate Sensitivity: It defines the "sweet spot" of substrate concentration required for an enzyme to be effective.
Inverse Relationship: A lower Km indicates higher affinity (more efficient at capturing rare substrate).
Physiological Match: In the body, Km values usually match the actual substrate concentrations found in the cell.

submissions.name: Kaylyn Luppino
submissions.explanation: This slide provides a visual representation for a fact that was previously only briefly mentioned in the speaker notes. Additionally, the slide brings in an interesting historical example to explain the clinical implications of a potential defect in hemoglobin binding. It could follow the slide that explain CO poisoning to offer an additional similar clinical application.
submissions.notes:
Hook: "We just learned that Carbon Monoxide turns you cherry red. Now let's meet the condition that turns you blue—and your blood chocolate brown."
The Explanation: It was mentioned earlier that iron must be in the Fe2+ (Ferrous) state to bind oxygen. If an oxidizing agent (like the drug Benzocaine) steals an electron, the iron turns into Fe3+ (Ferric). This is called Methemoglobin. This creates a double problem, just like Carbon Monoxide: 1. The oxidized sites are useless—they can't carry oxygen. 2. The remaining healthy sites hold onto oxygen too tightly because the tetramer is locked in the R-state.
The Twist: This creates a clinical nightmare: The patient looks blue (cyanotic) because their tissues are starving, but if you give them supplemental oxygen, it doesn't help because the iron literally cannot bind it. The antidote is ironic—we use a blue dye (Methylene Blue) to turn the patient pink again by chemically reducing the iron back to Fe2+.
Historical Fun Fact: This is the mechanism behind the famous 'Blue People of Kentucky'—a family with a genetic defect in the enzyme that normally repairs this oxidation.
Student study signals:
Core Concept: Oxidation of the heme iron from Ferrous (Fe2+) to Ferric (Fe3+) creates Methemoglobin. This form cannot bind oxygen at the oxidized site and locks the remaining healthy hemes in the R-state (high affinity), preventing oxygen release at tissues.
Memorize: Fe2+ (Ferrous) = Functional: Binds O2.
Fe3+ (Ferric) = Failed: Cannot bind O2.
Clinical Sign: "Chocolate Brown" blood; Cyanosis (blue skin).
Treatment: Methylene Blue (reduces iron back to Fe2+).
Exam Framing: "Compare the oxygen dissociation curve of a patient with CO poisoning vs. Methemoglobinemia." Answer: Both conditions cause a Left Shift (increased affinity in remaining sites) and a reduced carrying capacity (lower plateau). Both starve tissues despite "normal" pO2.

submissions.name: yesenia mosquera
submissions.explanation: The current Size Exclusion Chromatography slide is conceptually correct but dense, and students frequently misunderstand why large proteins elute first. This replacement slide uses a clear “highway vs scenic route” analogy to visually show that separation depends on how much time a protein spends inside the bead pores, not on speed.By simplifying the diagram and explicitly linking protein size to path length through the column, this slide directly addresses a common exam misconception and reinforces a high-yield concept. This slide should be presented immediately after the existing “Separation by Size” slide in Chapter 6 (first half) as a conceptual clarification.
submissions.notes:
Size exclusion chromatography is the most counterintuitive purification technique. Large proteins are too big to enter the pores in the beads, so they take a straight path through the column and elute first.Smaller proteins fit into the pores and repeatedly enter and exit the beads, which gives them a longer, more scenic path through the column and causes them to elute last. The key idea is that separation depends on how much time a protein spends trapped in the beads, not on molecular weight alone.
- Size exclusion chromatography separates proteins by size
- Large proteins elute first because they are excluded from bead pores
- Small proteins elute last because they enter pores and take a longer path
- “Excluded volume” refers to space inaccessible to smaller proteins

submissions.name: Mariam Mithqal
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Explanation/Analogy
submissions.explanation: The slide says: "LDH converts pyruvate -> lactate (produces NADH), and NADH at 340 nm is measured." This is stating that the LDH assay measures the CONSUMPTION of NADH and not the production. The reaction is actually pyruvate + NADH makes lactate + NAD+ and the NADH is the one that absorbs light, but because the NADH is oxidized to NAD+ (and this compound doesn't absorb at 340 nm), which means the signal will decrease over time and not increase (which is the assumption if NADH is produced and make the reaction reversed). This new slide should be presented in slide 7, as it is still referencing this LDH assay.
submissions.notes:
- LDH catalyzes pyruvate → lactate while oxidizing NADH to NAD⁺
- NADH absorbs at 340 nm and NAD+ does not (enzyme activity decreases over time)
- It shows an example of enzyme assay based on cofactor consumption

- LDH assays measure NADH consumption, not production
- A340 decreases as LDH activity increases (and NADH is the signal molecule since it's the one that absorbs UV light)
- The assay tracks substrate depletion/production formation

submissions.name: Shiv Mylavarapu
submissions.explanation: This Picture should be used with the Presenter Notes below to explain the purpose of High-Pressure Liquid Chromatography with a simple analogy. The picture should be placed right after Slide 22, which already explains HPLC, to bring the concept home. Slide 22, while scientifically okay, is heavy in words and quite small to see from the back of the room, so a quick analogy could help. This Image was created by Gemini.
submissions.notes:
The Hook: Alright, class, let’s talk about why we use the massive pumps of an HPLC system instead of just letting gravity do the work. To understand the 'High Pressure' part, you have to understand the 'F1' part.

The Comparison: Look at the left side of this diagram. Standard chromatography is like driving a minivan over a gravel road. The 'beads' in your column are like big rocks. Because there’s so much empty space between them, your proteins—Protein A and B—don’t interact with the surface very much. They just bounce through and cross the finish line in a messy, overlapping clump. That’s low resolution.

The HPLC Difference: Now, look at the HPLC side. We’ve swapped those rocks for microscopic beads—think of a high-tech F1 circuit. The surface area is suddenly massive, meaning every single protein molecule is forced into a 'high-grip' interaction with the stationary phase. 
But there’s a catch: that tiny bead size creates incredible resistance. You can’t just cruise; you need a 1,000-horsepower engine—or a 6,000 PSI pump in the case of HPLC—to blast the sample through that dense forest of beads.

The Finish Line: The result? Instead of a blurry pileup at the end, Protein A and B are separated into razor-sharp, distinct lanes. 
Remember: HPLC isn’t high pressure just for the sake of speed; it’s high pressure because it’s the only way to overcome the friction required for perfection.

submissions.name: Esther Yun
submissions.explanation: The “Hot Potato Ping-Pong” analogy is one of the best ways to understand double-replacement enzyme reactions because it captures every key feature in a single, memorable image. Substrate A binding is like the enzyme catching a hot potato, the reaction modifies the enzyme temporarily (the enzyme stays “hot”), and product P is released when the potato is tossed. Then substrate B binds (enzyme catches a second potato), reacts, and product Q is released, returning the enzyme to its original state. This analogy works because it clearly shows that substrates bind one at a time, the enzyme is temporarily modified between steps, and products are released sequentially—mirroring the actual ping-pong mechanism. On top of that, the humor and visual action make it easy to remember under exam pressure, much more so than abstract chemical equations. It should replace slide 30 on the chapter 8 lecture slides.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes

Introduce the analogy: Explain that the enzyme is like a cartoon character catching and tossing hot potatoes, representing substrates and products.

Step through the sequence:

Enzyme catches Substrate A → binds one at a time.

Enzyme is temporarily modified (hot) after interacting with Substrate A.

Product P is released (potato tossed).

Enzyme binds Substrate B → second potato is caught, still only one substrate at a time.

Product Q is released → enzyme returns to normal state.

Highlight key points:

Substrates bind sequentially, not simultaneously.

The enzyme changes state temporarily, then returns to normal.

“Ping-Pong” refers to the back-and-forth action of the enzyme being modified and reset.

Use the visual: Point to arrows, glowing potato, and labels to reinforce the sequence and temporary modification.

Student Takeaways

Substrates bind one at a time: Sequential binding is a hallmark of ping-pong (double-replacement) enzymes.

Temporary enzyme modification: The enzyme’s state changes between substrate reactions but resets after the second product is released.

Products are released sequentially: First product leaves before the second substrate binds.

Memorable analogy: Visualizing a “hot potato” bouncing makes the mechanism easy to recall during exams.

Terminology connection: The “ping-pong” name describes the enzyme bouncing between modified and normal states.

submissions.name: Emma Meehan
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation:
The “Fix” Explanation

Why this version is better

The original slide presents the Hill equation using Kd without clarifying that this constant is not the same physical dissociation constant defined earlier in the lecture. This can mislead students into thinking that cooperative binding simply “raises Kd to a power,” which is chemically incorrect.

The revised version:

Explicitly distinguishes Kd (single-site binding) from K₀.₅ / P₅₀ (cooperative systems)

Reinforces that the Hill equation is an empirical, curve-fitting model, not a mechanistic description

Prevents a common exam error: attempting to interpret hemoglobin’s affinity using Kd instead of P₅₀

Preserves the instructor’s intent to treat the Hill equation as a black-box interpretation tool while ensuring conceptual accuracy

Overall, the fix improves conceptual precision without increasing mathematical complexity, aligning better with exam expectations.

Where the New Slide Should Go

Placement:
Immediately after the first Hill coefficient slide and before students are asked to interpret binding curves quantitatively.

Exact location in deck:
After the slide introducing:

“The Hill coefficient gives us a number for how cooperative a protein is”

and before:

“Cooperativity Enhances Oxygen Delivery”

This timing ensures students:

Learn what the Hill coefficient measures

Understand what the parameters do and do not mean

Apply the concept correctly when interpreting physiological binding curves

Placing the clarification slide here prevents downstream confusion during curve-shift, P₅₀, and clinical interpretation questions later in the lecture.
submissions.notes:
Brief Presenter Notes

“Up to now, Kd has meant a true dissociation constant for a single binding site.
For cooperative proteins like hemoglobin, that physical meaning breaks down.
The Hill equation is an empirical model — it tells us how steep the curve is, not the exact binding mechanism.
That’s why we use K₀.₅ or P₅₀, not Kd, when interpreting hemoglobin’s oxygen affinity.”

Student Takeaways

The Hill equation is empirical, not mechanistic

nH measures cooperativity (steepness of the curve)

Kd applies only to single-site binding

For cooperative proteins, use K₀.₅ / P₅₀, not Kd

Hemoglobin: nH ≈ 2.8 → strong but imperfect cooperativity

submissions.name: Yoko Chan
submissions.explanation: In the original slide, the protein had different colors. However, it would be difficult for a student to tell what the color means. In the updated slide, I added a color bar at the bottom to indicate that the color correlates with hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity so that anyone can tell the core of the protein has the hydrophobic amino acids and the surface has the hydrophilic amino acids.
submissions.notes:
Same as before. (Hook: Point to the protein cross-section: where are hydrophobes? Where are charged residues? 
Talking Points: 
• Activity: 30 seconds individual, then compare with neighbor 
• Hydrophobic residues: buried in compact core 
• Charged/polar residues: on surface, interacting with water 
• Thermodynamic outcome of hydrophobic effect Misconception to Preempt: Some students think charged residues are buried for stability. Opposite: burying charge is costly. 
Transition: Bottom line summary of the hydrophobic effect. 
STUDENT TAKEAWAYS Write down: Protein structure: hydrophobic core, polar/charged surface. This is thermodynamically driven. 
Memorize: Inside = hydrophobic, Outside = hydrophilic Exam framing: Application: Predict effect of mutating a core leucine to glutamate.)

submissions.name: Charlie Haffer
submissions.explanation: This version is better because it separates appearance from behavior, which is exactly where students get tripped up. The closed door labeled “Looks like a single bond” captures the visual intuition students bring with them. The bolt labeled “Behaves like a double bond (resonance)” explicitly introduces the hidden constraint that contradicts that intuition. By putting the restriction on the bolt, not the door itself, the slide makes resonance feel like an added physical rule rather than a mysterious chemistry fact. Avoiding real chemical structures eliminates the risk of incorrect bonding, stereochemistry errors, or students over-fixating on atom-level detail. This new slide should be resented with slide 13.
submissions.notes:
“Okay, so this is one of those things that feels wrong at first. We tell you bonds rotate. Then suddenly—surprise—this one doesn’t. Think of the peptide bond like a door. It looks like a normal door. You’d expect it to swing freely. But someone bolted it shut. That bolt is resonance. It gives the bond partial double-bond character, which means rotation is basically off the table. So the whole thing is forced to stay flat. And that flatness? That’s not trivia. That’s a constraint—and constraints are what make protein folding even possible.”

Peptide bond is flat and rigid. No free rotation allowed. Locked into a planar structure.

submissions.name: Haley Oh
submissions.explanation:
"Fix" Explanation: The original Slide 31 presents a dense table where critical success metrics—Specific Activity and Fold Purification—are visually buried. My overhaul transforms this into a 'Purification Scorecard.' It uses a Yellow Highlight on the Specific Activity column because it is the metric that 'matters most'. I also added a clear Math Box to demonstrate the Fold Purification formula, which was previously only mentioned in the notes. Finally, I integrated the SDS-PAGE visual next to the data to reinforce the connection between quantitative success and visual purity
Placement: This should replace Slide 31/32. Alternatively, it can be placed immediately after Slide 31 as a "Summary/Calculation Guide" before moving into the Estrogen Receptor example.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: This table is your protein’s 'Report Card.' Don't be distracted by the Total Protein or Yield dropping; that's actually a normal sign that we are throwing away 'junk' proteins to find our target. The column that matters most is Specific Activity. Notice how it increases at every step? That is the hallmark of success. To calculate your 'Fold Purification,' just divide your final Specific Activity by your starting value ($30,000 / 10 = 3,000$). Visually, this is what a 3,000-fold purification looks like: moving from a 'smear' in Lane 1 to a single, pure band in Lane 5.
Student Takeaways: 
• Specific Activity = Units of activity per mg of total protein; the primary measure of purity.
• Fold Purification = Final Specific Activity / Initial Specific Activity.
• Yield Loss is expected as you remove contaminating proteins.
• Success = A single band on an SDS-PAGE gel and an increase in Specific Activity at every step.

submissions.name: Benjamin Wu
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation: The diagram showed Km as substrate concentration AND Michaelis constant, which was wrong, and is now shown to be [S]
submissions.notes:
Key point: "This equation describes the curve you just saw. Everything we discuss maps onto V, Vmax, [S], or Kₘ."
Hook: "Maud Menten was a Canadian physician in 1913—one of the few women doing quantitative biochemistry at the time. Her work is still taught to every biochemistry student."
Misconception: Students try to memorize without understanding—emphasize that this IS the saturation curve in equation form
Transition: "Why do we measure 'initial' velocity specifically?"
Student study signals:
Core takeaway: The Michaelis-Menten equation mathematically describes the hyperbolic relationship between substrate concentration and reaction velocity
Terms to memorize: V = Vmax[S]/(Kₘ + [S]), what each variable represents
Exam framing: "Given Vmax = 100 μmol/min and Kₘ = 5 mM, calculate V when [S] = 5 mM"

submissions.name: David Minoza
submissions.explanation: I would include this slide to help students visualize how different the % gel used affects Coomassie Staining. This slide should be presented/added after slide 31
submissions.notes:
Hook: “Gel percentage isn’t a memorization rule — it’s a pore size control dial.”

Key Points:
Gel % controls pore size • High % = smaller pores • Low % = larger pores • Gel acts as a molecular sieve • Small proteins resolve better in tight gels • Large proteins require looser gels

Preempt misconception:
Students memorize “high % = small proteins” without understanding why. The mechanism is physical restriction by pore size, not chemical recognition.

Transition:
If gel % determines separation resolution, how would you choose a gel to resolve two proteins far apart in size?

Student Study Signals

Core takeaway:
Gel percentage determines pore size. Higher % gels have smaller pores (better for small proteins). Lower % gels have larger pores (better for large proteins). The gel separates proteins by physically restricting movement based on size.

Terms to memorize:
Gel percentage, pore size, molecular sieve, resolution, acrylamide concentration

Exam framing (Application):
HIGH-YIELD: If you are separating a 25 kDa protein from a 150 kDa protein, which gel % would maximize resolution and why?

submissions.name: Lea Patel
submissions.explanation: The original slide 53 relies on a complex chemical structure diagram that can be overwhelming for a student first learning the concept. My version is better because it can serve as a supplement to slide 53 by reducing cognitive load and clarifying MS1 vs. MS2. It reduces cognitive load by using the "Train Car" analogy to transform abstract chemical fragmentation into a logical, mechanical process that is easier to visualize. It clarifies MS1 vs. MS2 by visually separating the isolation of the intact peptide (MS1) from the measurement of fragments (MS2), making the "tandem" nature of the technique explicit.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: 
We’ve discussed weighing whole proteins, but how do we actually read the sequence? Think of the peptide as a train where every car is a different amino acid. In the first stage (MS1), we park the entire train in a terminal to isolate our specific "train" of interest from the rest of the traffic. That train then enters the Collision Cell, which acts like a rough stretch of track where high-energy gas collisions snap the couplings between cars at random spots, a process known as Collision-Induced Dissociation. In the second stage (MS2), we weigh every possible fragment that comes out of that crash. By looking at the mass difference between peaks on our spectrum, we can identify exactly which "car" was lost. For example, if one partial train weighs 500 units and the next weighs 571, the 71-unit difference tells us that specific car was Alanine. By measuring these "train pieces," we aren't just seeing the protein; we are essentially spelling out its primary structure one letter at a time.

Student Takeaways:
MS/MS is "Molecular Spelling": While traditional MS only gives you the total weight, Tandem MS breaks the peptide into a "sequence ladder" where the mass difference between consecutive peaks identifies the specific amino acid.

Collision-Induced Dissociation (CID): This is the process where high-speed collisions with gas molecules cause the peptide backbone to fragment, typically into N-terminal (b-ions) and C-terminal (y-ions).

"New School" Efficiency: Unlike older methods that took years to sequence a single protein, MS/MS can sequence hundreds of peptides in minutes with femtomole-level sensitivity.

submissions.name: Angelina Nguyen
submissions.explanation: This visual is cleaner, and the mnemonic device may be easier for students to understand. The context and words on the slide are minimized, therefore, bringing more organized thoughts.
submissions.notes: Oxidoreductases is for redox and energy, which focus on H or e- transfer. Transferases is for shipping and kinases, which move a group from A to B. Hydrolases uses digestion and water, which use H2O as chemical scissors. Lyase is for cleaving, and double bonds, which break bonds without water. Isomerases are for geometry and rearrange, which means same atoms, new shape. Ligases are for stitching and ATP, which use energy to glue two things together.

submissions.name: Eyram Golo
submissions.slideRaw: between page 43 and 44(The sequence following the structural discussion of collagen)
submissions.explanation: The current lecture material introduces Collagen as a structural protein that is NOT an $\alpha$-helix, highlighting its requirement for hydroxyproline and Vitamin C.
submissions.notes: Presenter Notes & Student Takeaways: While the lecture introduces collagen defects, this visual bridges the gap by showing that collagen is a triple-helical cable requiring a repeating Gly-Pro-Hyp sequence. The 4-hydroxyproline (Hyp) acts as a molecular "staple," providing the interchain hydrogen bonds that brace the strands together. Because the modifying enzyme, prolyl hydroxylase, is strictly Vitamin C-dependent, a deficiency means these staples are not produced. Consequently, the Bottom Line for students is that without Vitamin C (Ascorbate), the collagen triple helix becomes thermally unstable and unravels at body temperature 37, leading to the connective tissue failure known as Scurvy.

submissions.name: Dhruv Admala
submissions.categoryRaw: Missing something important that is in the publisher's slide deck
submissions.explanation: Since the information regarding the distinction between mRNA and functional RNA is missing, it is important to include it in the slide deck. Therefore, the slide includes a brief description of these differences and how it applies to transcription/translation.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
Hook: "If DNA is the master blueprint of the cell, Transcription is the process of copying a specific page of that blueprint to take it to the construction site."
Context: Clarify that this takes place in the nucleus (in eukaryotes).

Left Column: The Outputs (The "What")
Messenger RNA (mRNA): Explain that this is the "middleman." It carries the genetic code from the DNA to the ribosome. It is the coding RNA.
Functional RNA: Crucial distinction: Emphasize that not all RNA codes for protein. Examples: Mention Transfer RNA (tRNA) and Ribosomal RNA (rRNA). These are the "workers" that help build the protein, not the blueprint itself.

Right Column: Gene Expression (The "Why")
Accessibility: DNA is tightly packed. Transcription "opens" the gene so the cell can use it.
Phenotype Connection: Explain that "Physical nature" refers to the phenotype. The proteins (or RNAs) produced here result in eye color, enzyme function, etc.
The "Always vs. Sometimes" Rule:
Key Point: Transcription always results in RNA.
Nuance: Translation (making protein) only happens if that RNA is an mRNA. If it's a functional RNA, the process stops there because the RNA is the final product.

Student Takeaways:
Key Definitions:
Transcription: The process of copying a segment of DNA into RNA.
mRNA (Messenger RNA): Types of RNA that act as a template for making proteins.
Functional RNA: RNA that performs a function itself (like tRNA or rRNA) and is not translated into a protein.

Gene Expression: This is how the information in your DNA becomes a physical trait.

Study Tip: Remember that all gene expression produces RNA, but not all gene expression produces protein.

submissions.name: Drishti Daga
submissions.explanation: The old slide has an error  where one of the labels on the diagram for sickled red blood cells reads "SICKD RED BLOOD CELLS". I corrected that to "SICKLED RED BLOOD CELLS"
submissions.notes:
"Class, take a look at this. We often talk about biochemistry as a series of abstract equations, but here is the physical reality. On the left, you see the smooth, biconcave shape of normal red blood cells. On the right, look at how they’ve collapsed into rigid, crescent shapes.

Don't worry about the 'why' just yet—we’re going to solve this mystery by the end of the hour. For now, I just want to plant a seed: every single structural change you see here—the sickling, the blood vessel blockages, the resulting pain and anemia—is caused by the swap of just one amino acid out of the hundreds in the hemoglobin chain. Structure determines everything."

Student Takeaways

The Bottom Line: Genetic disorders like Sickle Cell Anemia are often rooted in a single amino acid substitution.


The Chain of Logic: A change in the primary sequence (structure) leads to a change in chemical properties, which ultimately dictates biological behavior.


Medical Impact: In hemoglobin, the E6V mutation replaces a charged/hydrophilic residue (Glutamate) with a hydrophobic one (Valine), creating a "sticky patch" that causes proteins to aggregate.

submissions.name: Elizabeth Chuang
submissions.explanation: same as where it currently is
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: Brief scripted explanation of the slide, exactly as I would say it in class.
- Histidine has an ionizable R group (side chain). Amino acids with ionizable R-groups have additional transitions, which is why there are 3 pKa values on this graph instead of just 2 (for amino group and carboxyl group)
- pI = when the amino acid is neutral, or has a net charge of 0
- Calculating pI: Label the net charge of each amino acid, pick the two pKa values on either side of the net-zero form to find average of. 

Student Takeaways: The "Bottom Line" bullet points (just like in our lecture decks).
- Amino acids with ionizable R-groups have additional transitions.
- pI = when the amino acid is neutral, or has a net charge of 0
- Calculating pI: Pick the two pKa values on either side of the net-zero form

submissions.name: Maggie Shifflett
submissions.explanation: The original slide 37 contains dense bullet points that make the slide crowded and difficult to read. The new slide doesn't contain the entire information from the bullet points, but presents the most important information in a less crowded, easy to read table with some analogies to get the point across.
submissions.notes:
The most critical takeaway here is that Thermodynamics and Kinetics are independent variables.

Look at the Exergonic column on the left. Even if a reaction is spontaneous ($\Delta G < 0$), it might be stuck in the 'High Barrier' row. A diamond turning into graphite is thermodynamically favored, but it’s a 'Turtle' reaction—it takes billions of years because the activation energy is too high.

Enzymes don't change the column; they only change the row. They take a 'Turtle' reaction and turn it into a 'Rabbit' reaction by lowering the activation barrier ($\Delta G^{\ddagger}$). Finally, note the bottom-right: if a reaction is Endergonic ($\Delta G > 0$), even a low barrier won't make it go alone—it requires coupling to ATP to move forward."

Student Takeaways
$\Delta G$ is the "Destination": It only determines if a reaction is spontaneous (Exergonic, $< 0$), non-spontaneous (Endergonic, $> 0$), or at equilibrium ($= 0$).
$\Delta G^{\ddagger}$ is the "Roadblock": This value (Kinetics) determines the velocity; enzymes only lower this barrier and provide no information about the final equilibrium state.
Independence Rule: The thermodynamic favorability ($\Delta G$) of a reaction provides no information about its rate or velocity.
Path-Independence: $\Delta G$ depends only on the free energy difference between reactants and products; it is independent of the pathway or the enzyme.
Enzyme Limitation: Enzymes accelerate the rate at which equilibrium is reached, but they cannot change the equilibrium position ($K_{eq}$) or force an unfavorable reaction to happen.

submissions.name: Raj Bhowmic
submissions.explanation: I feel this new slide would show what would happen if water molecules stick to each other too much, after the discussion on how water surrounds ions and leading into what would happen if the solvation energy failed. It would be between slides 12 and 13.
submissions.notes:
The Hook: "We just spent time discussing how water dissolves polar molecules by surrounding them. Now, let’s look at what happens when that 'hydration shell' is missing in a human lung. This is the biochemistry of Cystic Fibrosis."

Compare and contrast: 

- "In a healthy lung, you have a thin layer of water."
- "Because there is plenty of water, the long mucus proteins (mucins) form hydrogen bonds with the water molecules."
- "This keeps the mucus slippery and thin so your cilia can sweep away bacteria."
-  "In CF, a salt-channel defect means water doesn't move into the airway."
-  "The mucus becomes dehydrated."
- "Without water molecules to 'distract' them, those mucins stop H-bonding to water and start H-bonding to each other."

The Result: "This massive cross-linking of 'weak' hydrogen bonds turns a liquid into a thick, 'sticky' polymer that acts like glue. It traps the cilia, prevents them from beating, and creates a 'hotel' for bacteria. It’s a life-threatening failure of solvation."

Transition: "If the dehydration in Cystic Fibrosis shows us what happens when water isn't there to interfere with hydrogen bonds, it raises a broader question about the physics of all weak bonds: in what specific environment do ionic interactions reach their maximum strength?"

Student takeaways:
- "This is the Gulliver Effect in action"
- "Individual H-bonds are weak, but when you remove the solvent and let thousands of them link up, they become strong enough to shut down a lung."

submissions.name: Dongze Li
submissions.categoryRaw: missing the explanation of the heterozygote advantage in the slide
submissions.explanation:
The original slide presents epidemiological data on sickle cell disease but does not explain why the disease shows this geographic and population-level distribution.

This revised version improves the slide by explicitly connecting the epidemiology to its evolutionary mechanism: heterozygote advantage under malaria selection pressure. By briefly explaining how HbA/HbS heterozygotes have increased survival in malaria-endemic regions, the slide helps students understand that disease prevalence can reflect adaptive evolutionary processes rather than random genetic distribution.

This addition reinforces key course concepts such as natural selection and balanced polymorphism while keeping the slide concise and exam-relevant.

This slide should be presented immediately after the existing epidemiology slide on sickle cell disease, as a mechanistic follow-up that explains the observed patterns in disease distribution.
submissions.notes:
This is a classic example of heterozygote advantage.In malaria-endemic regions like West Africa, individuals heterozygous for the sickle-cell allele have increased resistance to malaria.Although homozygous HbS causes severe disease, the survival advantage of heterozygotes maintains the allele in the population.

Student Takeaways
Disease prevalence can reflect evolutionary pressures
Heterozygote advantage can maintain harmful alleles
Sickle cell anemia is a classic example of balanced selection

submissions.name: Rylee Perkins
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Visual/Diagram, Better Explanation/Analogy, Missing something important that is in the publisher's slide deck
submissions.explanation: This is a better version because this slide actually describes what is going on in the slides and how the 2D gels are able to identify proteins with altered expression in disease states. Right now, there is no text with the slides so there is no quick reminder of the differences. Additionally, I fixed the "Proteins Levels" grammatical error which was incorrect on the slide and make sure to site the original photos.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
Hook: "This image is a snapshot of how cancer rewires cellular machinery at the protein level."
Comparison: Compare Normal (A) to Tumor (B). Note that the arrow points to GAPDH, which is upregulated (darker/larger) to fuel cancer's high energy needs.
The Point: This is how we discover biomarkers. We find a "changed spot," cut it out, and identify it using Mass Spectrometry.
Transition: "Now that we’ve spotted a difference, let's look at how we quantify purification success."

Student Take Aways
Core Takeaway: 2D gels identify differential expression. Changed spots are candidates for biomarkers.
Terms: Biomarker: A molecular "red flag" for disease.
Differential Expression: Changes in protein abundance between samples.
Exam Prep: H
Q: How do you identify a specific protein spot? 
A: Cut the spot from the gel and use Mass Spectrometry.

submissions.name: Elaine Christian
submissions.explanation: This new slide gives a better understanding of how the Zwitterion functions. With both positive and negative ends there are specific functions that it serves just like a battery's different ends.
submissions.notes:
At physiological pH, amino acids have both negatively and positive ends
Importance: hydrophillic tendencies and folding of proteins, can act as buffers and keep body stable
Clinical takeaway: drugs are sometimes coated in this so th ebody doesn't automatically fight/reject it, but keeps it in the body due to neutral charge

submissions.name: Angelina Navarro
submissions.explanation: Much more clear and in one photo slide 13
submissions.notes:
The Core Concept: Affinity Chromatography is a method for separating a specific protein from a messy mixture based on a unique biological attraction like Velcro sticking to fuzz.

The Three Stages:

The Catch (Loading): You pour your mixture over the slide. The "Velcro" (the Ligand) grabs only the specific "fuzzy tennis balls" (Target Protein). Everything else, like the smooth marbles (impurities), just slides right off.

The Clean (Washing): You rinse the slide. Since the target is stuck tight to the Velcro, it stays put while any leftover dirt or marbles are washed away.

The Release (Elution): You change the conditions (using a special "oil" or buffer) to make the Velcro let go. The purified target falls off into a clean container, separating it completely from the waste. 

Takeaway: Unlike other types of chromatography that separate by size or charge, Affinity Chromatography separates based on biological function/structure.

submissions.name: Naomi Debebe
submissions.explanation: mine is better because it uses a fun way to explain how the R-groups that are polar vs. nonpolar interact with water in colloquial terms by comparing them to "introverts" & "extroverts". The social dynamic example makes it easier to understand
submissions.notes: Essentially, protein folding is a "social dynamic" driven by how amino acids interact with water. The "introverted" hydrophobic groups huddle in the center to escape the aqueous environment, while the "extroverted" polar groups stay on the surface, forcing the linear chain into its functional 3D shape.

submissions.name: Michelle Wang
submissions.categoryRaw: Explaining Additional information stated in the "Exam Framing" section
submissions.explanation: I decided to add an addtional slide afer slide #22 since, "How does competitive inhibition alter the Lineweaver-Burk plot?" was a question stated in the "exam framing" section of the presenter notes and I wanted to compile an answer for current/future students. I chose to find a diagram that showed how the line would change due to different inhibitors and explained how Km and Vmax would change for each type of inhibition.
submissions.notes:
"Different inhibitors can change how the line is plotted on the Lineweaver–Burk Plot. In competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds at the active site, Km increases, since you need a higher concentration of substrates in order to complete with the inhibitor, and Vmax stays the same since it can still function at max capacity, as long as theres a high enough concentration of substrates. In uncompetitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds at an allosteric site, Km is decreased proportionally to how much Vmax is decreased. Vmax is decreased since the inhibitor binds to enzyme-substrate complexes, preventing future substrates from binding. In noncompetitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds to the enzyme anytime, Km stays the same since substrates are able to bind and dissociate as normal. Vmax decreases since less enzymes are functioning at max velocity."

Student Takeaway: Based on how the inhibtor interacts with the enzyme, Km and Vmax are changed.

submissions.name: Menna Helal
submissions.explanation: I aimed to find a better and more visually satisfying way to show how disulfide bonding can impact protein folding inside vs outside the cell. How different cellular conditions have different reducing and oxidizing environments, emphasizing the importance of the formation of disulfide bonds, allowing for a more compact and stable 3d protein structure.
submissions.notes: This slide illustrates how cellular location dictates protein structure through distinct redox environments. Inside the cell, the cytosol is reducing, which prevents disulfide bond formation and keeps proteins flexible. In contrast, the extracellular environment is oxidizing, driving the oxidation of cysteines to form cross-links. These covalent bonds act as 'molecular staples,' locking the protein into a compact, stable 3D structure necessary to withstand the harsher conditions outside the cell

submissions.name: Assiatu Sesay
submissions.slideRaw: Section 7.3: Gibbs Free Energy. This should follow Slide 37, which states that ΔG provides no information about the rate of a reaction.
submissions.explanation: On Slide 37, the text says ΔG provides no info on rate, but it doesn't show why. This Match Analogy is better because students already know that a match doesn't burst into flames while sitting in a box, even though the combustion reaction is highly exergonic (ΔG<0). This provides a concrete "Aha!" moment: the reaction is "favorable" (thermodynamics), but it is stuck until you provide the friction (activation energy/kinetics)
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: "Class, Slide 37 says ΔG doesn't tell us about speed. Think of a match. Burning wood is highly exergonic—it has a very negative ΔG. But a match doesn't ignite just because it's 'spontaneous.' It stays in the box safely because the Activation Energy (ΔG ‡) is too high. You have to strike it to provide that initial energy. An enzyme's job is like making the match-head more sensitive so that even a tiny 'nudge' can start the fire without changing how much heat the fire eventually releases." 

Student Takeaways:
Thermodynamics (ΔG): Tells you the match can burn (it is exergonic/favorable).
Kinetics (ΔG ‡): Tells you the match won't burn until you overcome the barrier (the friction).
The Enzyme Rule: Enzymes lower the friction required (ΔG ‡) but don't change how much energy the "fire" produces (ΔG).

submissions.name: Sadaf Ghani
submissions.explanation: New slide 54. This version is better because it relates to another medical scenario we haven't discussed but relates to BCAAs.
submissions.notes:
- Maple Syrup Urine Disease -> deficiency in BCKAD -> body unable to break down BCAAs -> BCAAs and toxic acid byproducts build up in in the blood and spill into urine
- Maple syrup odor caused by leucine buildup; high levels of leucine are neurotoxic
Student takeaways: Just as Sickle Cell is a structural failure of one amino acid (Glu -> Val), MSUD is a metabolic failure to process a specific class of amino acids
