submissions.name: Marie Yoon
submissions.slideRaw: 42 (Allosteric Enzymes Depend on Alterations in Quaternary Structure)
submissions.explanation: There are too many words on the slide which are hard to read. The image of the orchestra is also unnecessary as it doesn't match the "marching band" example given and it just takes up space. The diagram is also hard to understand without any context given. The new slide should be added in the slide deck as a replacement because it gives a simpler and easy to understand diagram and only highlights the main points.
submissions.notes:
The Concerted (MWC) Model: 
Key Mechanics: The Concerted Model explains how binding at one active site can instantly influence distant sites on different subunits.
Symmetry Rule: All subunits in an enzyme must exist in the same state; you will never see a mixture of T and R within a single molecule.

The Mechanism: Why the Curve is Sigmoidal
Trapping the R-state: Substrate binds preferentially to the rare R-state molecules, "trapping" them in that high-affinity form.
The Equilibrium Shift: To restore the natural T <-> R balance, more T-state molecules are forced to convert into the R-state.
Cooperativity: Because a single binding event flips all subunits in that molecule to the high-affinity R-state, more active sites become available instantly.
Kinetics: This rapid acceleration of binding leads to sigmoidal (S-shaped) kinetics rather than a standard hyperbolic curve.

submissions.name: Karan Malik
submissions.explanation:
This version is superior because it replaces a text-heavy definition slide with a Visual-First Molecular Model.

Scientific Accuracy: The original "bell curve" was a hallucination of generic data. This updated version correctly illustrates the plateau-style solubility curve, showing how solubility rises sharply (Salting In), remains stable across a range of ionic strengths, and then drops precipitously (Salting Out).

Mechanistic "Why": Instead of just stating that salt causes precipitation, this slide visualizes the "Solvation War." It clearly depicts salt ions "stealing" water molecules, which exposes the hydrophobic ("oily") patches of the protein, triggering aggregation.

Elimination of Cognitive Load: By using a 3-panel infographic, the student can see the transition from charge-shielding to dehydration in one glance, making the concept of fractionation intuitive rather than a list of facts to memorize.

Slide Placement

Location: Chapter 5, immediately after Cell Lysis/Homogenization and before Column Chromatography.

Reasoning: Salting out (Ammonium Sulfate Fractionation) is almost always the first crude purification step performed on a raw lysate. It bridges the gap between having a "messy cell soup" and the more refined, high-resolution separation techniques like Ion Exchange or Size Exclusion chromatography.
submissions.notes:
2. Presenter Notes

"Class, this slide summarizes the entire physical relationship between proteins and salt.

On the left (Salting In), we start with low salt. Proteins often clump here because their surface charges attract each other. Adding a little salt provides 'shields' that neutralize those charges, allowing the proteins to dissolve. This is why some proteins won't even dissolve in pure distilled water!

As we move to the right (Salting Out), we reach a breaking point. Salt ions are much better at attracting water than proteins are. In this 'Solvation War,' the salt ions steal the water away to form their own hydration shells.

Look at the third panel: the protein is now 'naked.' Its hydrophobic, or 'oily,' patches are exposed. To hide from the water, these oily patches on different proteins find each other and aggregate. This is the 'crash' or precipitation we use to purify different fractions in the lab. The oiliest proteins crash first!"

3. Student Takeaways (The "Bottom Line")

Salting In: Low salt concentrations increase solubility by shielding the ionic charges on the protein surface, preventing aggregation.

Salting Out: High salt concentrations decrease solubility by competing for water molecules (solvent), forcing hydrophobic patches to aggregate.

The "Oily" Factor: Proteins with more surface-exposed hydrophobic residues precipitate at lower salt percentages.

The pI Connection: Solubility is always lowest at a protein's Isoelectric Point (pI) because the net charge is zero, reducing repulsion between molecules.

submissions.name: Syed Sarim
submissions.explanation:
Slide 50 uses a "Tunnel through a Mountain" analogy. While helpful for visualizing a shortcut, it fails to explain the physical mechanism: why does the enzyme binding lower the energy? It makes the enzyme look like a passive observer rather than a dynamic participant that physically pulls the substrate into a new shape.

Instead of a tunnel, we use the analogy of Magnetic Attraction. The Substrate is a metal ball. The Transition State is the peak of the mountain. The Enzyme is a powerful magnet positioned only at the very top. This explains why the enzyme binds the Transition State tightest. The magnet doesn't pull the ball at the bottom (Substrate), but as the ball begins to move up, the magnet's pull (Binding Energy) makes the climb significantly easier.
submissions.notes:
"We often say enzymes are like 'tunnels' through a mountain, but that's a bit too passive. A better way to think about it is 'The Magnetic Mountain.'

Imagine the transition state is the peak of a mountain you have to climb. The enzyme isn't just standing there; it's a giant magnet positioned at the very top. But here’s the trick: the magnet only 'recognizes' the substrate once it starts changing into the transition state geometry.

As the substrate distorts, the magnet's pull—what we call Binding Energy—kicks in. This invisible pull 'pays' for the cost of the climb, effectively lowering the height of the peak. This is why transition-state analogs, like the Statins we discussed, make such potent drugs: they look like that 'halfway' shape, so the enzyme magnet grabs them and never lets go."

Student Takeaways:
The Best Fit: Enzymes do not fit the substrate perfectly (Lock-and-Key); they are complementary to the Transition State (Induced Fit).
Paying the Toll: The free energy released upon the interaction of the enzyme and the transition state is called Binding Energy.
The Mechanism: Binding energy is the specific source of catalytic power; it physically lowers the Activation Energy.
Clinical Goal: Effective drugs are often Transition-State Analogs because they exploit the enzyme's evolved preference for the transition state's geometry.

submissions.name: Millie Degefa
submissions.explanation: The "two pockets" explanation is a better analogy for zwitterions because it helps conceptualize how a single molecule can have both positive and negative charges at the same time while staying neutral overall. The pockets of the hoodie are in different regions and hold opposite charges, but they are a part of the same hoodie. This new slide should be presented on slide 10 of the slide deck.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: Think of a zwitterion like a person wearing a hoodie. It’s one hoodie, but inside the hoodie, there are two pockets that are separated. Like a zwitterion, one pocket holds positive charge, and the other pocket holds negative charge. Even though the charges in the pockets exist in different places, they balance out since they are a part of the same hoodie, so the net charge is zero. That’s what a zwitterion is: a single molecule with both a positive and a negative charge at the same time.

Student takeaway: A zwitterion is a molecule with both positive and negative charges in different regions, making it overall electrically neutral.

submissions.name: Simran Kulkarni
submissions.explanation: This version is better because it connects how hemoglobin binds oxygen cooperatively using a car door analogy, which helps students connect a biochemical concept to an everyday action. This should be presented after slide 26.
submissions.notes:
Hemoglobin starts in a "locked" T-state where it is hard for the first oxygen to bind, but that first successful binding acts like a central unlock button. This triggers a shift to the R-state, instantly swinging the remaining doors open so the rest of the oxygen can rush in effortlessly.

Student Takeaways: 
- Cooperativity = Teamwork: Hemoglobin transitions from a "locked" T-state (low affinity) to an "unlocked" R-state (high affinity) once the first oxygen binds.
- Efficiency through Allostery: Binding at one site causes a structural "shift" that is felt across the entire protein, ensuring all four seats fill up quickly once the first one is taken.
- Smart Delivery: This "all-or-nothing" behavior allows hemoglobin to be a greedy sponge for oxygen in the lungs while becoming a generous donor in the tissues where oxygen levels are low.

submissions.name: Mylie McDonough
submissions.explanation: This version includes a clinical application emphasizing the importance of fetal hemoglobin, in maternal/fetal blood transfer. Including more clinical applications, makes the concepts more engaging especially for a lecture full of students interested in pursuing medicine. This slide shows the drastic ways things can go wrong when fetal hemoglobin is dysfunctional, so it should directly follow the slide about it (around slide 44).
submissions.notes:
🎣 The Hook: The "Greedy" Protein Paradox
"Imagine you’re starving, and a delivery truck full of food pulls up to your house—but the driver has welded the back doors shut. The food is right there, but you can’t have it.
That is exactly what happens in Hydrops Fetalis. The problem isn't that the fetus lacks hemoglobin; the problem is that the hemoglobin it does have (Hb Bart's) is so 'greedy' for oxygen that it refuses to release it to the tissues. It's a protein that is perfectly saturated and completely useless."

1. The Genetic Failure  Most humans have four alpha globin genes. In Hydrops Fetalis (Alpha-Thalassemia Major), all four are deleted. Without alpha chains, you can’t make fetal hemoglobin or adult hemoglobin The excess gamma chains have no partners, so they huddle together to form gamma tetramers, known as Hb Bart’s.
2. The Sigmoidal vs. Hyperbolic Curve 
The Shift: Look at the graph on the slide. Normal Hb is sigmoidal (S-shaped) because of cooperativity. Hb Bart’s loses that S-shape. It becomes hyperbolic, similar to myoglobin.The curve shifts violently to the left. In biochem terms: a left shift = lower P50 = higher affinity. While normal Hb has a P50 of 26 mmHg, Hb Bart’s is so low it’s barely off the Y-axis. It holds onto O2 even at the extremely low partial pressures found in fetal tissues.
3. The Clinical "Domino Effect"
Hypoxia: Tissues starve for oxygen despite high saturation.
Cardiac Failure: The fetal heart tries to compensate for the "suffocation" by pumping faster and harder (High-output heart failure).
Hydrops: Eventually, the heart fails, and fluid leaks into the body cavities (edema), leading to the classic "swollen" appearance of Hydrops Fetalis.

💡 Student Takeaways
The Cause: Deletion of all 4 alpha-globin genes.
The Protein: Hb Bart’s (gamma 4 tetramer).
The Problem: Extremely high O2 affinity; no O2 delivery to tissues.
The Graph: A massive left shift and loss of the sigmoidal curve.
The Outcome: Severe intrauterine hypoxia and fatal edema.

submissions.name: Ivan Vorobyev
submissions.explanation: There was an error that was made on the slide 26, which was the wrong formula for catalytic efficiency where it said catalytic efficiency=Km/Kcat below the image. as such my slide would replace slides 26 or go below it.
submissions.notes: Catalytic efficiency tells us how well an enzyme works when substrate is low, which is often the physiological case. It combines two ideas: kcat (the enzyme’s top speed when saturated) and Km (how much substrate you need to reach half of Vmax). The correct relationship is kcat/Km, not Km/kcat. A higher kcat/Km means the enzyme both turns over quickly and reaches high rates at lower substrate concentrations—so it’s more effective under limiting [S].

submissions.name: Michelle Chuang
submissions.explanation: I included a easier to read visual and an explanation of the visual.
submissions.notes:
Student Takeaways: 
1. amino acids change pH
2. Zwitterion is neutral form 
3. at pH 7, amino acids are zwitterions, where they have both positive and negative charges 

Presenter Notes: 
1. Explain pKa values
2. Discuss physiological pH 
3. Relate to protein structure

submissions.name: Zahra Amin
submissions.explanation: The original slide relies on numerical abundance data and text to explain why carbon is central to life, which encourages memorization without revealing the underlying chemical logic. This revised slide replaces the table-driven explanation with a causal visual comparison that explicitly shows why carbon is biologically favored over silicon like stronger bonds, higher energy yield, and recyclable oxidation products. By reducing text and emphasizing cause-and-effect relationships, the slide lowers cognitive load while improving conceptual understanding.
submissions.notes: Although silicon can form four covalent bonds like carbon, biochemistry depends on what happens after oxidation. Carbon–carbon bonds are stronger and release more energy, and oxidation produces carbon dioxide, which is soluble and recyclable. Silicon oxidation produces silicon dioxide, an insoluble solid that is removed from biochemical circulation. Life requires both stability and recyclability, which carbon uniquely provides.

submissions.name: Brad Rotondi
submissions.explanation: Either in place of the hydrolase slide or after 7.2 HAROLD as a clinical example.  My slide is better because it still includes the relevant identifier of a water molecule, and it also highlights a clinically irreversible example with nerve agents.
submissions.notes: Presenter Notes: "Acetylcholinesterase functions as a hydrolase by using a water molecule to break down acetylcholine and reset the enzyme’s active site for the next reaction. However, nerve agents like Sarin mimic the substrate and form an extremely stable, covalent phosphonyl bond with the active site serine, excluding water and preventing hydrolysis." Student takeaway: "Hydrolases rely on water to function and recycle themselves."

submissions.name: Allegra Williams
submissions.explanation:
The current slides (Slides 30–32) rely heavily on Cleland line diagrams to distinguish between Sequential and Ping-Pong mechanisms. While chemically accurate, these abstract diagrams make it difficult to quickly intuit the physical difference in substrate timing.

This new slide visualizes the specific analogy mentioned in the speaker notes—'The Tango' vs. 'Tag-Team Wrestling'. By converting the text-based hook into a visual schematic, the slide reduces cognitive load and creates an immediate 'Aha!' moment. It moves the concept from abstract memorization of line diagrams to a concrete, memorable schema, fulfilling the 'Aha! Analogy' bounty category.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes (Script)

"We often get bogged down in the Cleland line diagrams, so I want to give you a mental image to distinguish these two mechanisms. Think of Sequential reactions (like Lactate Dehydrogenase) as a Tango. You need the lead and the partner—the Enzyme and both substrates—on the floor, locked together in a 'Ternary Complex', before the dance can move forward.

In contrast, Ping-Pong reactions (Double Displacement) are like Tag-Team Wrestling. The Enzyme wrestles with the first substrate, modifies it, and sends it out of the ring before the second substrate can even tag in. This creates that temporary 'Substituted Enzyme Intermediate' we saw in the diagrams. If you remember Tango vs. Tag-Team, you'll remember the difference in binding order."


Student Takeaways (Bottom Line)

Sequential Mechanism (The Tango): Requires a Ternary Complex. Both substrates (A and B) must bind to the enzyme simultaneously before any catalysis occurs.

Ping-Pong Mechanism (Tag-Team): Involves a Substituted Enzyme Intermediate. The first product (P) is released before the second substrate (B) binds. The enzyme is temporarily modified during the process.

Key Difference: Sequential = "All together at once." Ping-Pong = "First one in, first one out."

submissions.name: Turner Russell
submissions.explanation: It is somewhat confusing to know what the nature of the cofactor-enzyme interaction is like and how the improve its function. This version is better because it gives a visually memorable way to understand cofactors and coenzymes. This new slide should go after slide 23 in the chapter 7 slide deck.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: A good example of a cofactor function is that of a carpenter. A carpenter with no tools is like an apoenzyme, a carpenter with a simple tool like a hammer is a cofactor that is a small inorganic ion that stabalizes the molecule. A cofactor with a complex coenzyme is like a carpenter using a complex drill tool. Lastly, a cofactor that is tightly bound, a prosthetic group, is a like a carpenter with a bionic arm.

Student take away: 
- there are various types of cofactors: it is an umbrella term
- apoenzymes have no cofactor and are inactive, haloenzymes have a cofactor and are active
- coenzymes are more complex than simple inorganic ions
- vitamins are like the materials that combine to make a drill, think blade, handle, fuel tank
- some simple tools and complex tools can be bound tightly (prosthetic groups)
- Bottom line: there are various types of cofactors and when you get them all sorted in your head, it isn't too complicated.

submissions.name: Caoilainn Bischoff
submissions.explanation: The molecular drawings on the original slide were not accurate, and my new version is better because it correctly depicts: (1) the H2O molecules involved in cohesion (# of atoms in each water molecule and dashed lines), (2), correct hydration shells with H2O dipole facing the right way around chlorine, and (3) correct drawings of water molecules that were previously missing H atoms. It should be presented in its original sequence but with the revised images on slide 7.
submissions.notes:
PRESENTER NOTES
Hook: Water is the solvent of life

"First, let’s look at cohesion: thanks to hydrogen bonding, water molecules essentially 'hold hands,' creating the surface tension and capillary action that allow trees to pull water hundreds of feet into the sky. 
But water isn't just sticky; it's the ultimate solvent. Through solvation, water’s partial charges surround ions in 'hydration shells,' effectively dissolving salts and minerals.
Finally, we see the hydrophobic effect. Water is so attracted to itself that it rejects nonpolar molecules, pushing them together to maximize its own entropy—a process that is actually the driving force behind how our cell membranes and proteins fold into shape."

STUDENT TAKEAWAYS
Write down: 
Water: (1) cohesion via H-bonds, (2) dissolves ions/polar molecules, (3)
drives hydrophobic clustering - The hydrophobic effect is arguably THE most important organizing force
Memorize: Three functions of water in biochemistry and how they work together 
Exam framing: Application: How does water dissolve NaCl but not oil?

submissions.name: Daniel Goldberg
submissions.explanation: My version adds an actionable takeaway from the content on peptides. The slides discuss the historical connection well, but don't emphasize the clinical value of peptide therapy for targeted treatments. This slide should be inserted between slides 14 and 15.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes:

Open with the metaphor: the body is like a huge city, and most drugs are like letters tossed into the streets — they don’t know where to go.

Introduce the key idea: targeted delivery. The peptide acts as a molecular “address label” that recognizes a specific receptor on cancer cells.

Emphasize the separation of roles: the peptide is the navigator, not the treatment itself — its job is targeting. The payload is what actually does the therapeutic or imaging work.

Walk through the visual: bloodstream = roads, cells = houses, receptor = ZIP code. Only the matching address allows docking.

Highlight why this matters: better targeting can reduce off-target effects and improve efficiency.

Connect to the real science: this is the principle behind peptide-drug conjugates — engineered specificity at the molecular level.

Close by reinforcing the big idea: precision delivery is just as important as the drug itself.

Student takeaways: 
Drugs don’t automatically know where to act — targeting is engineered.

A peptide can function as a biological navigation system.

The payload and the targeting component have distinct roles.

Specific receptor matching enables selective delivery to cancer cells.

Targeted systems aim to increase effectiveness and reduce collateral damage.

Peptide-drug conjugates are a real-world application of molecular precision medicine.

submissions.name: Keane Tao
submissions.explanation: Original slide had an arrow that suggested Km was both the substrate concentration and the Michaelis constant. I felt the graph was also a bit small to read the labels on the y axis, so I enlarged it while reducing the size of the equation a bit.
submissions.notes:
"The Michaelis-Menten curve is shown on the left, with substrate concentration on the x axis and reaction velocity on the y axis. At a substrate concentration of Km, the reaction reaches half of its maximum velocity, vmax. On the right, the equation that governs the behavior shown in the graph is shown. v is initial reaction velocity, [S] is substrate concentration, Km is the Michaelis constant, and vmax is the maximum reaction rate." 
Student takeaways:
- Michaelis-Menten curve is hyperbolic
- Km is dependent upon 1/2 vmax, and is a concentration of substrate
- The reaction velocity represents the rate at the beginning of the reaction with known substrate concentration [S]

submissions.name: Schubin Chon
submissions.explanation: The current slide (Slide 14) is slightly convoluted in terms of its explanation of the CORN rule, with your viewing orientation being in-line with the Hydrogen atom of the model, but as the reference point is the palm, it is not intuitive and may lead to students being confused when attempting it in class. The "steering wheel" rule may be slightly better, with the idea of looking at the hydrogen atom as the "steering wheel" and using CORN as a method to see in which direction the steering wheel is supposed to turn. This is pretty intuitive as most have used a steering wheel before, and the direction the steering wheel turns is also in line with the R and L designations.
submissions.notes:
Speaker Notes: "Let's simplify Amino Acid Configurations with the 'Steering Wheel' method. This will save you from doing mental gymnastics during the exam.

Imagine the amino acid is a car and you are driving in reverse. The Hydrogen is the steering column pointing right at your chest.

Now look at the steering wheel. You have three groups on the rim: CO (Carboxyl), R (Side Chain), and N (Amino).

Read them in order. If they spell C O R N in a Clockwise direction, you have the L-isomer, because if you turn the steering wheel clockwise while reversing, you will point the front of your car LEFT.

submissions.name: Josephine Kicklighter
submissions.slideRaw: Maybe after slide 26. Somewhere in section 5.3 where hemoglobin cooperativity is explained
submissions.explanation:
My version gives a concrete example of hemoglobin cooperativity and makes it easier for students to visualize. It highlights the energy barrier. By framing the T-state as "shyness," students can immediately grasp that binding isn't just about a physical fit; it's about overcoming a thermodynamic/structural resistance. It explains the Sigmoidal Curve shape. Students often struggle to remember why the curve starts slowly and then gets steep. The "icebreaker" concept gives them a logical reason for that initial "lag" phase on the graph. It’s much easier for a student to recall a "dance floor" during an exam than a "quaternary salt bridge shift." Once they remember the dance floor, they can back-map that to the biochemistry.

This slide should be presented after slides 26 or 27, right after the idea of hemoglobin cooperativity is brought up.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
"Now, let’s look at Hemoglobin’s positive cooperativity through the lens of social peer pressure.

Think of the Hemoglobin molecule as this dance floor, and Oxygen molecules as the dancers. In the T-State, or Tense state, the protein is 'shy.' The subunits are locked by salt bridges, making that first Oxygen molecule work really hard to bind. You can see the dancer on the left—he’s hesitant, and it takes a lot of 'partial pressure' to get him out there.

But notice what happens next: Once that first dancer breaks the ice, he physically changes the shape of the floor. This is the conformational change to the R-State, or Relaxed state. The 'shyness' or resistance of the remaining subunits vanishes. Suddenly, the affinity spikes, and the next three Oxygen molecules rush onto the floor almost effortlessly.

This is why our binding curve isn't a straight line; it’s an S-shaped sigmoidal curve. Hemoglobin stays 'off' when oxygen is low, but flips 'on' rapidly once the first guest arrives at the party."

Student Takeaways: The "Bottom Line"
Cooperativity Defined: The binding of one O2molecule increases the affinity of the remaining subunits for O2
​
T-State (Tense): Low affinity, stabilized by salt bridges; represents the "shy" start of the curve.

R-State (Relaxed): High affinity, salt bridges broken; represents the steep upward climb of the curve.

Sigmoidal Kinetics: The "S-curve" is the mathematical hallmark of cooperativity (unlike the hyperbolic curve of Myoglobin).

Biological Advantage: This allows Hemoglobin to be a "smart" transporter—saturated in the lungs (high pO2) but quick to unload in the tissues (low pO2).

submissions.name: Maria Koutsourais
submissions.explanation: I fixed this slide so that it is more visually appealing, less cluttered, and emphasizes the most important and key takeaways. The text is larger so that it can be seen from the back of the class, and important information is highlighted. It also shows the necessary formulas. This slide should be presented on slide 8 of presentation 5.
submissions.notes: Kd is the dissociation constant and the affinity number, where under certain assumptions it will equal 50% occupancy. A smaller Kd means that there is a higher binding affinity, so less ligand concentration is necessary tight binding. To find Kd you calculate the concentration of the receptor times the concentration of the ligand and divide that by the concentration of the receptor bound to the ligand. Thus, at 50% saturation (Y=0.5), this means that 50% of the receptor is unbound, and 50% is bound, so [R] = [RL]. When we plug this into the Kd equation, it gives us Kd = L1/2. This will only hold true when the ligand is not depleted and there is a single binding site with no cooperativity. The assumptions where Kd does not equal L1/2 is when the high receptor concentration depletes the ligand, and/or if there are multiple binding sites that allows for cooperativity. The usual hyperbolic curve relationship will be shifted.

submissions.name: Skye Everett
submissions.explanation: In the powerpoint I downloaded, the original slide incorrectly labels a guanidinium group on both lysine and arginine when it is actually just arginine that has the guanidinium group in its side chain. Guanidinium is also spelled wrong in the powerpoint. I also think I would be better to separate the positive and negatively charged amino acids into two slides to emphasize their properties.
submissions.notes:
Lysine (Lys, K): Lysine is positively charged due to a terminal amino group. It's flexible side chain allows interactions with negatively charged residues and nucleic acids.
Arginine (Arg, R): Only Arginine contains a guanidinium group that gives it its positive charge over a wide pH range. The guanidinium group creates strong hydrogen bond interaction and a high basicity making it even more positively charged than lysine's amino group. 
Histidine (His, H): Histidine is unique because its imidazole side chain can be either positively charged or neutral near physiological pH, allowing it to play key roles in pH-dependent processes and enzyme active sites.
Student takeaway: Arginine has a guanidinium group, lysine has an amino group, and histidine's imidazole ring can gain or lose a proton near physiological pH giving these amino acids a positive charge that are effective at binding negatively charged molecules.

submissions.name: Emma Leishear
submissions.explanation:
This slide improves the presentation by linking iron chemistry to a clinical condition, making an abstract concept more meaningful and giving a real life example. Instead of just stating that Fe²⁺ is required for oxygen binding, the slide shows what happens when certain things go wrong. The visuals reduce cognitive load by clearly illustrating normal vs. impaired oxygen binding, and the clinical clues and treatment demonstrate how biochemical principles guide diagnosis and therapy. 
The slide fits best between Slides 38 and 40, during the transition from oxygen-binding curves to pathological regulation of hemoglobin as placing the slide here creates a natural bridge from normal binding behavior to clinical disorders.
submissions.notes:
Hemoglobin must have Fe²⁺ to bind oxygen

In methemoglobinemia, iron is oxidized to Fe³⁺ → cannot bind O₂

Hemoglobin structure is intact, but function is lost

Double problem:

Fe³⁺ hemoglobin cannot load oxygen

Remaining normal hemoglobin holds O₂ too tightly (left-shifted curve)

Results in tissue hypoxia despite normal lungs

Pulse oximetry may appear normal or misleading

Classic clues: cyanosis unresponsive to O₂ and chocolate-brown blood

Treatment follows biochemistry:

Methylene blue reduces Fe³⁺ → Fe²⁺

Oxygen alone is not sufficient

Key takeaway:

A single electron change at iron completely disrupts oxygen delivery

submissions.name: Eric Wei
submissions.explanation: “Allostatic” is a physiology term related to stress responses, not enzyme kinetics. Allosteric enzymes depend on alterations in quaternary structure. So, T/R ratio= allosteric constant not allostatic constant.
submissions.notes: Think of the concerted model like a marching band: the whole band is either standing still or marching together. In allosteric enzymes, all subunits flip together between the T state (low-affinity) and the R state (high-affinity). Even without substrate, the enzyme is constantly shifting between these two states. When substrate binds, it stabilizes the R state, tipping the balance and making it easier for more substrate to bind. That’s how binding at one site affects distant sites and why allosteric enzymes show a sigmoidal response instead of a smooth hyperbola. The T state isn’t inactive—it just binds substrate less well. Keep in mind that real enzymes can blend this behavior with the sequential model, but the concerted model gives us the big picture.

submissions.name: Clarissa Tso
submissions.explanation:
The slide is now less wordy and easier to read from the back of the room.

This slide can replace the same 13th slide.
submissions.notes:
Kinetic parameters are determined by measuring initial velocities at
multiple substrate concentrations, then fitting the data to the Michaelis-Menten
equation. Modern analysis uses non-linear regression, though Lineweaver-Burk plots
provide visual intuition.

submissions.name: Sophia Xie
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram, Better Explanation/Analogy
submissions.explanation: Bullet point 5 on Slide 42 defines L0 as the "allostatic constant." This is a typo. It should be the Allosteric constant. "Allostatic" refers to allostasis (the physiological process of maintaining homeostasis through change/stress), which is a completely different biological concept. The current slide lists the features of the Concerted (MWC) Model as dry facts. I corrected the terminology and introduced the "Synchronized Swimmer" Analogy to visualize the "All-or-None" concerted transition. This slide can be presented in the same location, slide 42 of the slide deck.
submissions.notes:
Let’s look at the Concerted Model, also known as the MWC model. First, a quick correction on the slide text: L0 is the Allosteric constant, not 'allostatic.' 'Allostatic' refers to physiological stress—we don't want that! Now, the hardest part of this model is understanding the 'Concerted' transition. I want you to think of this enzyme like a Synchronized Swim Team.

The team has two rules: 
Uniformity: They must all be doing the exact same thing. Either everyone is underwater (the T-state), or everyone is above water (the R-state). You can never have half the team up and half down.
Stability: Naturally, they prefer to be underwater (the T-state). It takes energy to stay up. This is our Allosteric Constant (L0)—it's simply the ratio of how much they prefer being 'underwater' (T) versus 'above water' (R).

So, how does the substrate turn the enzyme on? Imagine the substrate is a beach ball that can only be caught by a swimmer who is above water (R-state). Even though the team prefers to be underwater, they occasionally pop up. If a substrate comes along and grabs a swimmer while they are up, it locks them in that position.

Because of Rule #1 (Uniformity), if one swimmer is locked above water, the whole team must stay above water. The substrate has effectively shifted the entire equilibrium from T to R, making the other active sites available for business. That is the essence of cooperativity."

Student Takeaways: 
Correction: L0 is the Allosteric Constant (Ratio of T/R), not the allostatic constant. A high L0 means the enzyme is very stable in the inactive T-state.
Mechanism: Substrate binding pulls the equilibrium by "trapping" the unstable R-form.
Rule: Subunits change shape simultaneously (Concerted).

submissions.name: Sahaana Mohan
submissions.explanation: My version explains the four ways of protein separation through a concrete example (an airport). The protein is represented by travelers and the rules of the airport describe the different ways of protein separation (charge, size, solubility, and affinity). Instead of the red marble example described in the slide deck, this analogy might resonate with students better.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: “First, SOLUBILITY.
Different proteins drop out of solution at different salt concentrations. When we add salt, some proteins ‘sit down’ and stop moving while others stay dissolved. That’s salting out—it’s not very precise, but it’s fast and effective as a first step.”
“Second, SIZE.
With gel filtration, proteins are separated by how big they are. This is where things feel backwards—larger proteins come out first because they don’t enter the pores of the beads.”
“Third, CHARGE.
If we know a protein’s pI, we can control its charge and use ion exchange chromatography to separate it from proteins with different charges.”
• SOLUBILITY → Salting out
• SIZE → Gel filtration
• CHARGE → Ion exchange
• BINDING → Affinity chromatography
“Fourth, BINDING AFFINITY.
If we know something specific our protein binds to, we can use affinity chromatography. This is the most selective approach—only the protein we care about is retained.”

Student Takeaways: Proteins can be separated using four properties: solubility (salting out), size (gel filtration), charge (ion exchange), and specific binding (affinity chromatography). Each purification method exploits a different property, and the choice of method depends on the question being asked.

submissions.name: Rachel Woods
submissions.explanation: The Light Switch vs. a Dimmer Knob analogy is really helpful for distinguishing between the 'all-or-nothing' nature of the MWC/concerted model and the 'step-by-step' transition of the KNF/sequential model. In the current slide deck for chapter 8, there is no visual analogy for the concerted vs sequential models. This slide would best be placed after discussing the basics of allosteric concerted and sequential models (after slide #45).
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes:
Let’s look at the two competing models for how an enzyme 'flips' from its inactive T-state to its active R-state using a visual analogy. Think of the enzyme like this chandelier. On the left, we have the Concerted Model (MWC) model. In this scenario, the enzyme is governed by a Master Switch. Because the subunits are physically 'locked' together to maintain symmetry, they must all change state at the exact same time. There is no middle ground. Even if only one substrate molecule binds, it 'traps' the entire enzyme in the R-state. You’ll notice the equilibrium constant heavily favors the 'Off' or T-state until that switch is flipped. The bottom line here? Symmetry is everything. Now, look at the right side: the Sequential Model (KNF). Here, we don't have a master switch; we have Individual Dimmer Knobs for each subunit. When a substrate binds to one subunit, it induces a conformational change only in that specific subunit. However, that change 'nudges' the neighbors, making it slightly easier for them to turn their own knobs. This allows for hybrid states—where the chandelier is half-dim and half-bright. This model is more flexible and explains how binding at one site can ripple through the protein step-by-step.
Student takeaways:
-The "All-or-Nothing" Rule: In the Concerted Model, the enzyme exists in only two states (T and R). Hybrid states (like a T2R2 mix) are physically impossible/forbidden.
-Symmetry Preservation: The Concerted Model requires all subunits to be identical in shape at all times. The Sequential Model allows subunits to have different shapes simultaneously.
-The Trigger: Concerted -- Substrate binding shifts a global equilibrium that already exists between T and R. Sequential -- Substrate binding induces a change in one subunit, which then influences its neighbors (the "ripple effect").
-Cooperativity: While both models explain Positive Cooperativity (binding makes the next one easier), only the Sequential Model can account for Negative Cooperativity (where binding of one substrate makes it harder for the next to bind).

submissions.name: Lena Zaher
submissions.explanation: My slide is an addition for students to visualize the effects of myoglobin when it is in the blood. It can go after slide 19, where it first introduces the clinical connection.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
The Concept: Myoglobin is an intracellular protein. Its presence in the blood is a "cellular leak" indicator.

The Cause: Physical trauma (Rhabdo) or ischemic death (Heart Attack) ruptures the muscle cell membrane.

Clinical Utility: It is an early marker (rising in 1–3 hours), but non-specific (can’t distinguish between heart or bicep).

The Danger: Filtered by the kidneys; high concentrations are nephrotoxic.

Student Takeaways
Normal State: Myoglobin stays inside muscle cells.

Abnormal State: High blood myoglobin = Muscle Damage.

Key Diagnoses: MI (Heart Attack) or Rhabdomyolysis.

Pros/Cons: Faster than Troponin (Pro), but less specific (Con).

submissions.name: Olorundamilola (Dami) Ayandipo
submissions.explanation: My new slide provides a visual differentiation between the smooth and rough ER. I think the text on the original is helpful, but the images (besides the one of the literal cell, do not provide additional clarifiation on what the ER does). It would fit in after slide 66.
submissions.notes:
The ER: Manufacturing & Logistics
Rough ER (The Assembly Line): Covered in ribosomes (the "polka dots"). This is where proteins are built, folded into their 3D shapes, and "packaged" for transport.

Smooth ER (The Refinery): No ribosomes. It focuses on producing lipids (fats) and detoxifying chemicals. Its sleek surface allows for chemical processing rather than construction.

Student Takeaways
Key points for students to write in their notebooks.

Direct Connection: The ER is physically attached to the Nucleus, allowing it to receive "orders" (mRNA) quickly.

Structural Difference:

Rough ER: Has Ribosomes (dots); looks bumpy; makes and folds Proteins.

Smooth ER: No Ribosomes; looks sleek; makes Lipids and cleans up Toxins.

The "Lumen": The inside of these "pipes" is called the lumen. It provides a protected environment for chemical reactions to happen away from the rest of the cell.

Transport Hub: The ER doesn't just make things; it moves them. It acts as a highway system to get products to their next stop (the Golgi Apparatus).

submissions.name: Susanna Stair
submissions.explanation: Overall, I feel that this version of this slide is better because in the initial image although it has a graph and explains the concept vaguely to the left of the graph, I feel that the initial graph is a bit ambigious. On the initial graph, the equilibrium is not labeled and the difference between the pink and grey line is not clear. I feel like this slide needs a slight analogy/better explanation to show how enzymes do not alter equilibrium, as the visual is a bit dull and does not get the point across super well. This new slide makes these slight corrections and therefore I feel it is more suitable for the slide deck. This new slide should be presented as slide 49 instead of the current slide 49.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: 
-The enzyme allows for the reaction to reach equilibrium more quickly but does not change where the equilibrium lies
-Enzyme is like taking a shortcut to get to the same destination (key word, same destination)
-Equilibrium always remains the same
Student Takeaways: 
-Enzymes change the route, but not the destination
-The rate changes for the forward and reverse reactions (shortcut for both)
-The final destination does NOT change

submissions.name: Maria Dolan
submissions.explanation: This slide is better because all of the diagrams have accurate structures of histidine and other compounds. It also more accuratley and clearly shows when and how histidine changes protonation forms.
submissions.notes:
Histidine is often called the pKa shape-shifter because its side chain has a pKa of about 6, which is very close to physiological pH. That means small environmental changes can shift it between protonated and neutral forms.

Because of this, histidine is extremely useful in enzyme active sites. It can both donate and accept protons, which makes it ideal for acid–base catalysis. It also plays roles in pH sensing, metal coordination, and biological signaling pathways such as histamine production.

The key idea to remember is that histidine’s chemical behavior is driven by where the pH sits relative to its pKa, allowing it to toggle charge states in conditions where most amino acids do not

- Imidazole side chain pKa ≈ 6
- Physiological pH ≈ 7.4 → histidine can be protonated or neutral
 - Protonation rule:
       - pH < pKa → protonated
        - pH > pKa → deprotonated
- Functional roles:
       - Acid–base catalysis
       - Proton transfer and buffering
        - Metal ion binding

Student Takeaways:  
- Histidine’s side chain is an imidazole ring with a pKa ≈ 6.
- Because its pKa is near physiological pH, histidine can easily switch between protonated (positive) and neutral forms.
- Histidine commonly functions in:
     - Acid–base catalysis in enzyme active sites
      - Proton transfer and buffering 
       - pH sensing in proteins
      -Metal ion coordination
Protonation rule to remember:
     -pH < pKa → protonated (positively charged)
     -pH > pKa → deprotonated (neutral for histidine side chain)
- Histidine is a precursor to histamine in biochemical pathways.

**Why professors emphasize histidine: it is one of the few amino acids whose charge state changes around physiological pH, making it critical for enzyme mechanisms.

submissions.name: Linda Tol
submissions.explanation:
The new slide should replace the original slide 3 with the Barista Analogy. This new Pizza Delivery analogy may be better suited because it accounts for other scenarios that the barista analogy didn't consider, such as:
1. what happens when barista is slammed? (saturation)
2. why not just hire more baristas? (Vmax vs enzyme concentration)
3. why not pre-make coffee? (substrate availability)
This new analogy considers these questions using a different food-related concept.
submissions.notes:
"Quick question: If I double pizza orders, does delivery rate double? Let's find out using a pizza fleet."
SCENARIO 1: Light Orders (30 seconds)
Show graph panel 1 (green line)
"Few orders arrive. Drivers finish deliveries, come back, take next order immediately.
1 order → 1 delivery/min
2 orders → 2 deliveries/min
Rate ∝ [Orders]
This is LINEAR. First-order kinetics. Low [S] region of Michaelis-Menten."
SCENARIO 2: Medium Orders (30 seconds)
Show graph panel 2 (orange curve)
"More orders. At first proportional, then... not quite.
6 orders → 5.5 deliveries (not 6!)
7 orders → 5.7 deliveries
Why? Drivers getting queued. Rate of increase SLOWS DOWN. Curve bends."
SCENARIO 3: Peak Orders - SATURATION (40 seconds)
Show graph panel 3 (red plateau)
"Saturday night. ALL drivers fully loaded with max pizzas.
Here's the KEY: Even if orders TRIPLE, delivery stays 4.5 pizzas/min.
Why? All drivers are BUSY. Enzyme is SATURATED. V ≈ Vmax. Constant. Zero-order kinetics.
This is the most important insight: Adding substrate when saturated does NOTHING."
SCENARIO 4: Double Drivers (30 seconds)
Show graph panel 4 (purple curve)
"Hire 8 drivers instead of 4 → Vmax DOUBLES.
But notice: Km stays same. Why? Km depends on pizza-driver FIT (chemistry).
More drivers doesn't change that. Only VMAX changes."
STUDENT TAKEAWAYS
🟢 TAKEAWAY #1: Linear at Low [S]
When substrate is scarce, velocity increases proportionally with [S].
You should remember: V ∝ [S] = first-order kinetics
This means: Most metabolic enzymes in your cells operate HERE
🟡 TAKEAWAY #2: Saturation at High [S]
When substrate is abundant, velocity plateaus at Vmax.
You should remember: Adding more substrate = ZERO benefit
This means: The enzyme, not substrate, is the bottleneck
🟣 TAKEAWAY #3: [E] Changes Vmax, NOT Km
You should remember: Doubling enzyme → Vmax doubles; Km unchanged
This means: Cells need BOTH more enzyme (capacity) AND allosteric control (on/off)

submissions.name: Vinitha Vennapusa
submissions.explanation: The original slide shows Dr. Deppmann's handwritten work for solving a Michaelis Menten Equation. This new AI-generated image clearly shows the step by step process to solving the example Dr. Deppmann worked through, except the work is more clear and also explain what was done to get to the next step.
submissions.notes:
Key point: "This is a classic exam problem—manipulate the M-M equation
algebraically" Walk through: Set V = 0.8Vmax, substitute, solve for [S]/Kₘ

Bottom Line: Practice manipulating this equation with different given variables.

submissions.name: Jalen Li
submissions.explanation: The original slides state that 2,3-BPG lowers hemoglobin’s oxygen affinity but do not explain the physical mechanism behind this effect. This slide introduces a clear structural “doorstop” analogy that shows how 2,3-BPG binds only the T state, stabilizes the low-affinity conformation, and must be expelled before hemoglobin can shift to the R state and bind oxygen tightly. This makes the causal relationship between structure and function intuitive rather than memorized.
submissions.notes:
Brief Presenter Notes: 2,3-BPG binds only to deoxyhemoglobin in the T state, where a central cavity is open. By occupying this cavity, 2,3-BPG stabilizes the low-affinity conformation and physically prevents the T-to-R transition. For hemoglobin to bind oxygen tightly, 2,3-BPG must be released, which lowers overall oxygen affinity and promotes oxygen delivery to tissues.
Student Takeaways
2,3-BPG binds only the T (deoxy) state of hemoglobin
It stabilizes the low–oxygen-affinity conformation
Oxygen binding requires 2,3-BPG release
This mechanism ensures efficient oxygen delivery to tissues

submissions.name: Sarina Parikh
submissions.explanation: This slide should be placed right before the original slide on Edman degradation. My version is not necessarily better, but provides a simpler introduction and added context into what Edman degradation is before moving onto Professor Deppman's slide with information from the textbook.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:

Hook: Imagine a Pez dispenser where, instead of pushing a candy out, a mechanical claw reaches in and grabs only the very top brick.

Key Points: Edman degradation is a method of sequencing amino acids in a peptide by systematically snipping off one residue at a time from the N-terminus. To make this stick, you want to emphasize the sequential, repetitive, and non-destructive (to the rest of the chain) nature of the process. If the protein chain is the "candy stack" from our analogy, PITC is the chemical hook that selectively grabs the very first candy.

Core Takeaway: Here is how it works in three simple steps:
The "Tagging" (Coupling): PITC is added to the protein chain. It only reacts with the N-terminus (the "front door" of the protein). It ignores all other amino acids in the middle of the chain.
The "Snip" (Cleavage): Under acidic conditions, the PITC-tagged amino acid becomes unstable and breaks away from the rest of the chain.
The "Reveal": The removed amino acid (now called a PTH-amino acid) is stable enough to be identified by a machine, while the rest of the protein chain remains completely intact, just one unit shorter.
Terms to Memorize: PITC reagent (phenyl isothiocyanate), peptide to PTH amino acid
Exam Framing: each cycle must be near 100% efficient, and the N-terminus must be free

submissions.name: Nick Larson
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Visual/Diagram, Made the slide more readable from far away and less clustered. More clean and effective.
submissions.explanation: This slide should take place of number 20. My version is better because it will be easier to read from far away and is less clustered. The long paragraph is split up and easier to read as well. I also did an uplift on the diagram to make it more visually appealing.
submissions.notes:
Hook: “Think of Ion Exchange Chromatography as molecular velcro. Opposite charges stick. Same charges keep flowing.”
Key points: Beads are charged (+ or -) … Proteins with Opposite charge BIND - Same charge FLOW THROUGH
Elute with salt gradient (disrupts ionic interactions) • Cation exchanger (negative beads) binds cations (+); Anion exchanger (positive beads) binds anions (-)
Preempt misconception: Students confuse cation and anion exchangers. Remember: the exchanger is named for protein charge, not the bead charge
Transition: What if we want maximum specificity? Target exactly one protein?
📚Student Study Signals
Core takeaway: Ion exchange separates by charge. Cation exchangers (negative beads) bind positive proteins. Anion exchangers (positive beads) bind negative proteins. Elution uses salt gradient or pH change.
Terms to memorize: ion exchange chromatography, cation exchanger, anion exchanger, salt gradient
Exam framing: Application: Your protein has pI 4.0. At pH 7.0, is it + or -? Which column would bind it? (Answer: negative charge, use anion exchanger)

submissions.name: bailey allen
submissions.explanation: This version is more effective for a lecture setting because it transforms a list of definitions into a functional narrative. Instead of just memorizing what a lysosome is, students can now see why it must be a separate room: to prevent its "acidic incinerator" from destroying the rest of the factory.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes

The Hook: Start by asking the class if they could cook a five-course meal, do laundry, and run a chemistry experiment all in a single-room studio apartment.

The Concept: Explain that Prokaryotes operate like that studio—everything happens in one open space, which limits how big or complex they can get.

The "Aha!" Moment: Eukaryotes are the "Industrial Complex". By building walls (membranes), the cell can have a "Furnace Room" (Mitochondria) that is hot and energetic right next to a "Blueprint Vault" (Nucleus) that needs to stay cool and protected.

The Clinical Connection: Remind them that when these "rooms" fail—like a leaky incinerator—you get diseases like Tay-Sachs, where toxic waste piles up and destroys the whole factory.

Student Takeaways

Compartmentalization = Control: Membranes aren't just bags; they are physical barriers that allow the cell to run incompatible chemical reactions at the same time.


The Eukaryotic Advantage: Internal membranes allow eukaryotic cells to be thousands of times larger and more specialized than prokaryotes.


Specific Roles: * Nucleus: Protection and isolation of the genetic master files.


Mitochondria: Sequestration of high-energy ATP production


Lysosomes/ER/Golgi: A dedicated assembly line for shipping, receiving, and waste management.

submissions.name: Rebecca Qiu
submissions.explanation:
The original slide was: vocabulary-heavy and abstract, so students memorize names but fail to map reactions to classes. Additionally, the “7th class” (translocases) feels tacked on.

The new slide was improved by: replace with a reaction-first layout: Show a generic reaction (e.g., “bond + water → broken bond”) → then label Hydrolase. Visually isolate Translocases as membrane-specific, not reaction-chemistry-based
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes (What you would say in class)

“Instead of memorizing enzyme names first, I want you to start by looking at what the reaction actually does. Ask yourself: What changed? Did electrons move? Did a group move? Did water break a bond? That reaction logic tells you the enzyme class. For example, if water is used to break a bond, that reaction must be a hydrolase — no memorization required. Lyases are often confused with hydrolases, but notice: lyases make or break double bonds without using water or ATP. Isomerases are the easiest conceptually — nothing leaves the molecule; atoms are just rearranged. Ligases are the opposite extreme: they force two molecules together and always require ATP. Now look at translocases. These don’t change chemistry at all. They move molecules across membranes. That’s why they’re separated visually — they don’t belong in the same reaction-chemistry framework. If you can describe the reaction in words, you can identify the enzyme class on an exam — even if you’ve never seen the enzyme before.”


Student Takeaways (Bottom Line for Slides / Exam Review)

Enzyme classes are defined by the type of reaction, not by the enzyme name
You should identify the reaction first, then assign the class
Reaction → Class Mapping
Electron transfer → Oxidoreductases
Group transfer (e.g., phosphate, methyl) → Transferases
Bond broken using water → Hydrolases
Double bonds formed or broken without water or ATP → Lyases
Rearrangement within one molecule → Isomerases
Two molecules joined using ATP → Ligases
Molecule moved across a membrane → Translocases (not reaction chemistry)

High-Yield Exam Insight

If water is involved, think hydrolase
If ATP is required to join molecules, think ligase
If nothing enters or leaves, think isomerase
Translocases transport — they do not chemically transform

submissions.name: Sarah Carroll
submissions.explanation: On the Henderson-Hasselbach slide, the seesaws that were showing the relationship between [HA] and [A-] were incorrect. The one on the left had [HA] on both sides of the seesaw and the one on the right had [A-] on both sides of the seesaw. I fixed this, so that the image now reflects the same information as the typed information.
submissions.notes: There is no change to the presenter information, only an image.

submissions.name: Maddie Tran
submissions.explanation: This slide should replace the current slide 19.  My version is better because it is more concise with bigger text, so it's easier to read and comprehend during the lecture.  The slide still contains the important information and graph to emphasize the main points.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
Defining Km Operationally: Focus on Km as the specific substrate concentration [S] where the enzyme reaches exactly half of its maximum capacity, or 1/2 Vmax.

Efficiency versus Affinity: Explain that a low Km suggests high efficiency or a "tight grip" on substrate, meaning the enzyme reaches half-maximal speed even at low concentrations.

Comparative Kinetics: Use the graph to demonstrate that one enzyme can have different Km values for different substrates; the substrate with the lowest Km (S1) is the most effectively captured.

In Vivo Relevance: Mention that Km is generally a good proxy for the actual substrate concentrations the enzyme encounters within a living cell.

Student takeaways:
Km is the substrate concentration [S] required to achieve exactly half-maximal velocity (1/2 Vmax).

A low Km indicates high efficiency, as the enzyme can "find" and convert substrate even when it is scarce.

submissions.name: Catherine Zhou
submissions.explanation: Integrating this specific case study is a pedagogical "win" because it transforms abstract mathematical concepts into a high-stakes clinical reality. Most students find pure kinetics dry; this gives them a reason to care.
submissions.notes:
🎙️ Presenter Notes
The Hook: Start by telling the students that enzyme kinetics isn't just math—it's the difference between a headache cure and a liver transplant.
The Transition: Use the $V_{max}$ diagram to explain the shift in kinetics. Point out that at therapeutic doses, the drug concentration is far below $K_m$, meaning the rate of metabolism is proportional to the dose (First-Order).
The "Traffic Jam" Analogy: Explain that Glucuronidation and Sulfation are like a 10-lane highway. Usually, traffic flows fine. But in an overdose, the "cars" (acetaminophen) exceed the highway's capacity ($V_{max}$). The overflow has no choice but to take the "dangerous side road" (CYP450).
The Antidote: Emphasize that NAC timing is critical. It acts by replenishing the "sponge" (Glutathione) that soaks up the toxic NAPQI spill.
📝 Student Takeaways
Enzyme Saturation: Toxicity occurs because the high-capacity safe pathways (Phase II) reach $V_{max}$ and become saturated.
Shift in Kinetics: Metabolism shifts from First-Order (predictable/safe) to Zero-Order (constant rate, leading to accumulation) during an overdose.
The Toxic Culprit: NAPQI is the reactive intermediate produced by the CYP450 (Phase I) pathway when the safe pathways are overwhelmed.Glutathione (GSH): This is the body’s primary defense against NAPQI. Once GSH is depleted ($<30\%$ of normal), liver damage begins.NAC Mechanism: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) provides the cysteine necessary to regenerate Glutathione, effectively "neutralizing" the kinetic trap.

submissions.name: Kelechi Ezenwa
submissions.explanation: The original slide states the pH vs pKa rule correctly, but many students struggle to apply it when predicting protonation states on exams. My revised slide introduces a simple visual “tug-of-war” analogy that frames pKa as a balance point between protonated and deprotonated forms. This helps students immediately understand why pH = pKa corresponds to a 50/50 mixture and allows them to predict charge states without memorization. This slide should be presented immediately after the pH vs pKa rule is introduced, before students are asked to apply the rule to amino acids and titration curves.
submissions.notes: Think of pKa as a balance point in a tug-of-war between protonated and deprotonated forms. When pH equals pKa, neither side wins — the molecule exists 50% protonated and 50% deprotonated, think: lack of protons. If the pH rises above the pKa, the deprotonated form wins, think: excess protons. If the pH drops below the pKa, the protonated form wins. You don’t need to memorize structures to answer exam questions — just compare pH to pKa and ask which side of the balance you’re on.

submissions.name: Jasmine Lobana
submissions.explanation: The updated slide places those equations into their anatomical context (Brain, Lungs, Kidneys, Tissues), providing a better understanding for how pH regulation occurs in our bodies. It should be placed instead/alongside slide 39
submissions.notes:
Slide 14 introduced the buffer equation, but this slide shows it in action. We have a 'Thermostat' in the brainstem that tastes the blood for pH.
Normal State: The brain adjusts breathing depth to keep the equation balanced.
The Clinical Extremes: If you Hyperventilate (Panic Attack), you blow off CO2 too fast. The equation shifts Left, consuming protons, causing Alkalosis and dizziness. Conversely, in Respiratory Depression (like an Opioid overdose), breathing slows, CO2 builds up, shifting the equation Right and causing Acidosis.

The Backup: While the lungs handle the fast CO2 changes, the Kidneys handle the long-term work, physically excreting the protons from fixed acids like Lactic Acid

The Hemoglobin Connection: Finally, at the bottom, we see the link: The protons generated at the tissues are the exact signal that forces Hemoglobin to release oxygen (The Bohr Effect), while the high pH in the lungs resets it to pick oxygen up."

Student Takeaway: the buffer equation lies at the center of pH regulation in our body

submissions.name: Pratha Ravani
submissions.explanation:
My new slide would go after slide 21 in the lecture 7 slideshow. Slide 21 talks about proteases, a specific type of hydrolase, that works by breaking peptide bonds using water. My slide after this goes more in depth about how proteases are used by both our bodies, and viruses. Half of my slide talks about how protease supplements are used to help with digestion for people who don't have enough naturally in their body, and the other half talks about how viruses use proteases to replicate, and how protease inhibitors can be used in antiviral drugs to stop replication.

I believe that my slide is a good addition to give more context on how proteases are used in our body. Slide 21 highlights proteases as a type of hydrolase, without going much in depth to why they can be useful. My slide goes into the clinical aspect, and is relevant to us today. Especially the second half on viruses, I focus on COVID as an example, since some COVID drugs use protease inhibitors to prevent spread. It gives more information of potential supplements or drugs we may have to take.
submissions.notes:
First part (as supplements): 
• Proteases have a big role with protein digestion. Proteases are naturally found in our pancreas as trypsin and chymotrypsin and help with digestion. People who have issues with their pancreas, or any other gastrointestinal disorders, can take protease supplements as a way to help with digestion.
• These supplements are made up of two types of proteases, trypsins and chymotrypsins, which are extracted from animal pancreas. Vegetarian versions of the supplements use different types of proteases, usually bromelain or papain, which are extracted from fruits like pineapples and papayas.
• Proteases are also being explored as a therapeutic supplement for things like pain relief for chronic musculoskeletal pain or osteoarthritis pain. 

Second part (virus replication and protease inhibitors):  
• Viruses use proteases to help them spread by encoding proteases to help them replicate. This is seen with viruses like HIV, Hepatitis C, and even recently, with COVID-19. Protease inhibitors are used to treat virus infections, by preventing the virus from making more copies of itself. Protease inhibitors are usually used in combination with other antiviral medications, as boosters. 
• Proteases help viruses spread by breaking protein chains into smaller ones through hydrolysis. These smaller proteins chains will then replicate the virus. Protease inhibitors work by blocking proteases, preventing viruses from replicating. 
• If we look specifically at COVID-19, the protease inhibitor, Nirmatrelvir, inhibits the protease 3CL, preventing COVID from replicating. Pfizer developed and antiviral prescription drug called Paxlovid, which is a combination of Nirmatrelvir and another protease inhibitor, called ritonavir. 

Student takeaways: proteases can be taken as supplements to help digestion, but viruses, such as COVID, can also use proteases as a way to replicate. Protease inhibitors are used in antiviral drugs to stop the spread of viruses. 


Sources for use as supplement: 
https://www.ebsco.com/research-starters/biology/proteolytic-enzymes-therapeutic-supplement
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4030975/

Sources for the virus inhibitor: 
https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/treatments/24937-protease-inhibitors
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8595904/

Supplement bottle image from amazon, Paxlovid box image from the Paxlovid website

submissions.name: Sophia Go
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram
submissions.explanation: I redrew the diagram for "Structure & Terminology" because it originally had some factual errors and it is now a better representation and visual of what happens in real life. A later slide in the Ch. 4 presentation explains that almost all peptide bonds in proteins are trans, whereas all 5 bonds in the image were originally depicted as cis with the R groups not alternating sides. I redrew the R groups to alternate sides to represent what generally happens in nature. Additionally, the word residue is listed on the original slide but it is not clearly shown what the specific amino acid residue would be, so I clearly outlined a single residue. Finally the side chains were highlighted in green in the original image, which I kept, but the double-bonded oxygen was also highlighted in green, which is misleading since it is a part of the main chain backbone and is not a variable side chain. This slide should replace the original slide 7 in the deck, and it is the same except for the one diagram I changed.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: A polypeptide chain consists of a main chain backbone with side chain variable "R" groups that are attached on either side, and tend to appear on alternating sides of the chain in nature. A single amino acid is called a residue, while a small number of amino acids strung together is called an oligopeptide or peptide, and proteins or polypeptide chains are typically to 50 to 2000 residues in length, with the longest known protein titin being 27,000 amino acids long. In terms of molecular weight, a single amino acid is approximately 110 g/mol, which means that the molecular weight of most proteins is between 5500 to 220,000 g/mol, or Daltons. Daltons or Da is equivalent to 1 g/mol and is the mass of one Hydrogen atom, and is a common unit for molecular weight of proteins along with kiloDaltons or kDa.

The way to answer this question would be to be to divide the total molecular weight, which is 55 kDa or 55,000 daltons by 110 Da per average residue, which yields a result of 500 residues. On exams, this math appears constantly.

Student takeaways:
- Polypeptide chain: main chain backbone with peptide bonds joining amino acids and variable R group side chains that tend to alternate which side they are on in the peptide chain.
- A single amino acid in a polypeptide chain is a residue -> peptides slightly larger -> proteins are typically 50-2000 residues long.
- A single amino acid is an average of 110 g/mol or 110 Da (1 Da = 1 g/mol); use this to determine the number of residues in a protein given it's molecular weight (often given in kDa)

submissions.name: Anna Saline
submissions.explanation: While the deck briefly acknowledges the addition of Translocases as the 7th major class of enzymes on Page 11, the rest of the material (and the official mnemonic) still defaults to the traditional six. I’ve updated the mnemonic and the visual layout to ensure students aren't "trapped" by outdated classification during the exam.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: If you look at older textbooks, you'll see enzymes grouped into six categories. We’ve used the mnemonic 'Old Tiresome Harold Loves Indoor Lamps' for years. However, biology is a living science! As of 2018, the IUBMB officially added Class 7: Translocases. These enzymes are unique because they don't just transform a molecule into something else; they move it across a membrane. Think of the ATP/ADP translocase in your mitochondria. Our new mnemonic is: 'Old Tiresome Harold Loves Indoor Lamps Tonight!' Don't forget that last 'T'—it’s the difference between an 'A' and a 'B' on the classification section." 

Takeaways: 
-There are now 7 major enzyme classes, not 6.
-Translocases (EC 7) catalyze the movement of ions or molecules across membranes.
- Update to O.T.H.L.I.L.T. (the extra T is for Translocases).
- Unlike the other classes that focus on chemical bonds, Translocases focus on spatial location within the cell.

submissions.name: Leila Carey
submissions.explanation: This analogy helps explain both the process and purpose of the bicarbonate buffer system in the blood by connecting it to a more digestible story, which hits all of the major points. This slide should likely be placed in the deck as slide 47, as a way to reinforce/better explain the process introduced on slide 46. (of chapter 2's slide deck)
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
1. The "Heist" Analogy (The Mechanism)Set the Scene: Metabolism acts as the factory producing "smoke" (CO2).The Transformation: In the blood, smoke becomes a "Robber" (H+/Acid). We need to contain him.The Getaway: The Robber jumps into the "Getaway Car" (HCO3-/Bicarbonate).The Neutral Unit: Together, they form Carbonic Acid (H2CO3)—this is the safe vehicle speeding through the bloodstream.The Escape: At the lungs (the cliff), the car crashes and reverts to smoke. We exhale the smoke, effectively dumping the acid.
2. The "Traffic Managers" (Regulation)
Manager 1: The Lungs (Respiratory Control)Role: Controls the speed of the "cars" driving off the cliff. Speed: Reacts in seconds. Hyperventilation: Driving too fast off the cliff -> Losing too much smoke/acid -> Respiratory Alkalosis.
Hypoventilation: Blocking the exit -> Smoke backs up, Robbers multiply -> Respiratory Acidosis.
3. The "Fleet Managers" (Metabolic Control)
Manager 2: The Kidneys (Renal Control)Role: Controls the supply of "Getaway Cars" (HCO3-). Speed: Reacts in days (slow but powerful). Action: If acidity is high (too many robbers), the kidneys manufacture more cars to pick them up.
Student Takeaways: 
CO2 is Potential Acid: When you breathe out CO2, you are physically removing acid (H+) from your body.
The Equation: Remember the reversible relationship:
CO2 + H2O <-> H2CO3 <-> H+ + HCO3-
Breathing Rules:Panic breathing (Hyperventilation) = Low CO2 = Basic blood (Alkalosis).
Holding breath (Hypoventilation) = High CO2 = Acidic blood (Acidosis).

submissions.name: Katharine Lavayen
submissions.categoryRaw: Missing something important that is in the publisher's slide deck
submissions.explanation: I included the paragraph "The CO-Hb binding curve does not reach the same max capacity as normal Hb. CO reduces the amount of O2 binding sites available, which leads to starved tissue cells due to the inadequate delivery and release of O2" This is because I felt like I was confused on why exactly there were starved tissues and having a little blurp explaining directly this difference in how the CO binding curve is exhibiting a locked R state is important.
submissions.notes:
To make this slide stick emphasize that CO poisoning isn't just about "blocking" oxygen but it’s a locking of the R state.
Start at the top: CO isn't just a competitor; it’s a dominant one. With an affinity 250x stronger than O2, it essentially takes the seat at the heme table before oxygen can even get close.

"The R-State Trap: "Look at the bottom left. When CO binds to even one subunit, it triggers a conformational change that locks the entire hemoglobin tetramer into the R-state. This is the 'Relaxed' state usually reserved for when we are rich in oxygen. By forcing this state, the remaining subunits have a pathologically high affinity for oxygen."The Graph’s 'Double Whammy': "On the right, notice two things about the red curve. First, it peaks much lower than the black line. This is the reduced capacity—the physical blocking of sites. Second, notice it’s shifted left and lost its 'S' shape. It becomes more hyperbolic. This means at tissue pressures (around 20-40 torr), the hemoglobin is holding onto O2 with a 'death grip' instead of releasing it.

"The Result: "So, the tissue isn't just starved because there's less oxygen in the blood; it’s starved because the oxygen that is there is legally 'locked' in the R-state and can't jump off into the cells."Student TakeawaysDual Mechanism of Action: CO causes harm via two distinct methods:Occupancy: It physically blocks O2 from binding (lowers the curve).

Allostery: It locks Hb in the R-state, preventing the release of O2 already bound (shifts curve left).

Affinity vs. Delivery: High affinity is usually good for loading oxygen in the lungs, but in CO poisoning, the affinity is so high that delivery to tissues becomes impossible.The "Hyperbolic" 

Shift: CO poisoning turns the sigmoidal (cooperative) curve into a more hyperbolic one, meaning the protective "unloading" phase of hemoglobin is destroyed.
Clinical Reality: This is why victims of CO poisoning can have "cherry-red" skin; their hemoglobin is saturated with O2 but their cells are still suffocating because that O2 won't release.

submissions.name: Ahana Garimella
submissions.explanation: There are three columns: Essential, Semi-Essential, and Nonessential so that students will not be confused. This new slide should just replace the previous one, so 43.
submissions.notes:
If you look at the previous list of amino acids, you might see Arginine listed as nonessential. But here is the clinical reality: Arginine is the 'teenager' of amino acids. While adults can generally make enough of it, children and infants cannot. During periods of rapid growth, pregnancy, or recovery from a major burn or surgery, our internal production can't keep up with the demand. This makes Arginine 'conditionally essential.' When you see a patient in a hypermetabolic state or a growing child with protein deficiency, Arginine must come from the diet, just like the other nine essential amino acids.

Student Takeaway: Semi-Essential Status: Arginine is conditionally essential; the body makes it, but not always in sufficient quantities

submissions.name: Gabrielle Wibisono
submissions.explanation:
Students frequently struggle to distinguish between kcat and kcat/KM. This analogy provides a concrete mental model for why a "fast" enzyme (kcat) is ineffective without high efficiency (kcat/KM) under physiological conditions where substrate is limiting. It moves the concept from abstract math to a recognizable scenario. 
Placement: This should be presented immediately after the formal definition of Catalytic Efficiency on Slide 27 to solidify the concept before moving into complex bisubstrate mechanisms.
submissions.notes:
Chapter 8 often focuses on Vmax and kcat as the 'gold standards' of speed. But think about kcat like the top speed of a Ferrari. It’s impressive on a clear, empty track—which, in biochemistry, means a test tube where we've saturated the enzyme with substrate. However, your cells are messy and substrate is often rare (low [S]). In these 'foggy' conditions, top speed doesn't matter if the enzyme can't find the substrate. This is why we look at kcat/Km. It combines the engine power (kcat) with the navigation system (Km). An enzyme with high kcat/Km is 'kinetically perfect' because it captures and processes substrate as fast as physically possible—reaching the diffusion limit.

Student Takeaways (The Bottom Line)
kcat (Turnover Number): Measures maximum catalytic activity per active site when the enzyme is fully saturated with substrate.
kcat/Km (Efficiency): The 'specificity constant' used to compare an enzyme's preference for different substrates under physiological conditions.
The Diffusion Limit: The physical ceiling for kcat}/Km (10^8 to 10^9 M^-1s^-1), where the reaction is limited only by how fast molecules collide.
Physiological Reality: Most enzymes operate at [S] levels near their Km, making kcat/Km the more relevant metric for in vivo performance

submissions.name: Bella Nolla
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Visual/Diagram, some words were cut off on the original slide
submissions.explanation: The original slide was very bland and some of the words were slightly cut off
submissions.notes: The estrogen receptor (ER) is a nuclear hormone receptor that binds estradiol and is essential for therapies like tamoxifen. Its dysregulation plays a major role in breast cancer and osteoporosis. Unlike enzymes, ER has no catalytic activity, so it cannot be tracked using standard enzyme assays during purification. Instead, researchers must identify it by its ability to bind estrogen. A common misconception is that all receptors are on cell membranes, but ER is intracellular. The key idea is that ER is purified based on binding affinity, not enzyme activity.

submissions.name: Ava Franklin
submissions.explanation: Replace slide 42 - I corrected the chemical structures of the 4 amino acids presented on the slide
submissions.notes:
Slide: Additional / Modified Amino Acids
Presenter Notes: Up to now, we’ve talked about the standard 20 amino acids—but biology is a little messier than that. Some amino acids are modified after translation, and a few are rarely encoded in special cases. These aren’t new building blocks—think of them as chemical upgrades. Hydroxyproline, for example, is made from proline and is essential for collagen stability. Selenocysteine is sometimes called the ‘21st amino acid’ and shows up in redox enzymes. The key idea is that proteins don’t stop evolving once they’re made—cells fine-tune them chemically.

Student Takeaways: Some amino acids are modified after translation, modifications expand protein function and stability, and selenocysteine is rare but biologically important

submissions.name: Sude Mohac
submissions.explanation:
Why this version is better: It answers "So What?": Students often zone out during theory. By connecting the chemistry (charge) to a disease they know and one that we already talked about in class  (Sickle Cell), you instantly grab their attention.

It connects the dots: The original slide just says "charges separate." This slide shows how: Mutation → Charge Change → Graph Shift. It makes the abstract concept concrete.

I would put this  slide right after slide 20 which introduces ion exchange chromatography.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: 
We've talked about how ion exchange separates proteins by charge. 'So what?' you might ask. Well, this simple principle is exactly how we diagnose Sickle Cell Anemia in the clinic.

Look at the left panel. Sickle cell is caused by a single point mutation in the beta-globin chain. We swap a Glutamate—which is negatively charged—for a Valine—which is neutral. Think about the physics: If you remove a negative charge, the resulting protein (HbS) becomes less negative (or relatively more positive) than the normal protein (HbA).
