Silicon is a lot more common on Earth's Crust, and also makes four covalent bonds just like carbon, so why don't we use the more abundant element? Well, there are three key reasons. First, carbon--carbon bonds are much stronger than silicon bonds due to carbon's smaller size, allowing atoms to get closer together. Second, these stronger bonds release more energy when broken during combustion, providing important fuel for organisms. Third, after carbon has undergone combustion, it produces carbon dioxide which is soluble in water and can exist as a gas, helping it remain in biochemical circulation.

submissions.name: Asfar Chaudhry
submissions.explanation: This slide uses the hydrophobic effect as the primary causal mechanism of disease rather than a side detail. Instead of simply linking a mutation to symptoms, it shows how disrupted hydrophobic interactions alter protein folding energetics, triggering ER quality control and protein degradation before function is even tested. This reinforces the hydrophobic effect as a thermodynamic principle with direct clinical consequences, not just a structural rule. I think the new slide should be presented after slide 27 in the slide deck as a clinical connection.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes

1. The Hook: Flat-Pack Frustration "Raise your hand if you’ve ever built flat-pack furniture. You know the feeling—you're almost done, but one crucial screw or locking cam goes missing. What happens to the cabinet? It’s wobbly. It doesn't square up. You wouldn't trust it to hold anything heavy.

Today we're using that frustration to understand Cystic Fibrosis at a molecular level."

2. Left Panel: Normal Folding & The "Anchor" "Look at the left panel. This represents a normal CFTR protein being built by the cell.

The Cabinet Panels: These represent the long chain of amino acids that make up the protein. To work, they have to fold into a very specific 3D shape.

The Golden Cam-Lock (Phe508): This is the most important part of this image. This lock represents a specific amino acid called Phenylalanine at position 508.

The Connection to Hydrophobic Effect: Phenylalanine is large and very hydrophobic (oily). The inside of the cell is mostly water. Just like oil droplets clump together in water to escape, hydrophobic amino acids are constantly pushed together into the center of the protein by the surrounding water.

The 'Click': When you twist that cam-lock in real life, it pulls the wood tight. In the protein, the hydrophobic effect drives Phe508 to bury itself deep in the protein's core. This action 'locks' the protein into its stable, functional shape.

The Result: The cell's quality control system sees a perfectly folded protein and ships it to the cell surface to do its job."

3. Right Panel: The ΔF508 Mutation "Now look at the right panel. This is the most common cause of Cystic Fibrosis, the Delta-F508 mutation.

The Missing Piece: 'Delta' means deletion. That one crucial hydrophobic Phenylalanine is missing from the instructions.

The Failed Assembly: Without that hydrophobic anchor, the protein core cannot snap tightly together. The surrounding water isn't forcing that section closed because the 'oily' piece isn't there.

The 'Wobbly' Protein: The resulting protein is unstable. It vibrates; it doesn't hold its shape. It’s like the cabinet with the missing lock."

4. The Biological Consequence "The cell has very strict quality control. It recognizes this wobbly, improperly folded protein as 'junk.'

Instead of being shipped to the cell surface, the defective protein is sent to the proteasome—the cell's woodchipper—and destroyed.

The takeaway: The disease isn't caused because the protein doesn't work; it's caused because the protein never even makes it to the cell surface because a single missing hydrophobic interaction made it too unstable to pass inspection."

Student Takeaways 

1. The Hydrophobic Effect is the Driving Force of Folding
Water molecules prefer to interact with each other. They squeeze non-polar (hydrophobic/oily) molecules together to maximize their own interactions.

2. Hydrophobic Amino Acids act as Structural "Anchors"
Proteins fold in a way that buries hydrophobic amino acids in their core, away from water. These buried hydrophobic interactions are the primary stabilizing force of a protein's 3D structure.

3. Missing Anchors Lead to Instability and Degradation (The CF Mechanism)
The ΔF508 mutation deletes just one hydrophobic amino acid. Without this crucial interaction in the core, the protein cannot fold into its stable state. The cell’s quality control machinery detects exposed hydrophobic regions on the unstable protein and destroys it.

submissions.name: Saketh Alluri
submissions.explanation: I personally do not think the AI did a good job at the surrealistic/hyperrealistic rendition of the factory analogy. So, I wanted to overhaul and make the slide look a bit neater. It should be presented in the same spot.
submissions.notes:
Speaker Notes:
Introduction

Explain the ER as an extension of the nuclear envelope (the "brain's" porch).

It is one continuous membrane, despite looking like two different structures.

The Rough ER (The Blue Section)

Texture: Looks "rough" under a microscope because of ribosomes.

Job: Primary site for protein synthesis.

Process: Ribosomes build protein chains → they drop into the ER "lumen" → the ER folds them into 3D shapes.

The Smooth ER (The Green Section)

Texture: "Smooth" because it lacks ribosomes.

Shape: Changes from flat sacs to a tubular network.

Job 1: Synthesis of lipids (fats, oils, and hormones like steroids).

Job 2: Detoxification (converts toxins into water-soluble substances to be flushed out).

Job 3: Storage (specifically stores calcium ions for muscle contraction).

The Big Picture

Structure follows function: Liver cells (detox) have more Smooth ER; Pancreas cells (insulin/protein) have more Rough ER.

Student Takeaways:
Rough = Ribosomes = Proteins: If you see dots, it’s making proteins.

Smooth = Lipids + Detox: No dots means it’s making fats or cleaning the cell.

Physical Link: The ER is the "highway" that connects the nucleus to the rest of the cell's transport system.

submissions.name: Sanjana Rao
submissions.explanation: My revised roller-coaster slide works better because it shows the difference between thermodynamics and kinetics in a simple, visual way. The start and end heights are the same in both pictures, which makes it clear that ΔG and equilibrium don’t change, while the hill in the middle changes height, showing that enzymes lower activation energy (ΔG‡) and speed up the reaction. This helps fix a common confusion students have about what enzymes actually change. It’s also less cluttered than a full reaction-coordinate graph, so students can understand the idea quickly and then apply it to exam diagrams. This slide should go right before the Section 7.4 transition-state slide so students already know to look for changes in ΔG‡ but not ΔG or Keq or in place of slide 51.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: Look at these two roller coaster tracks. The start platform is the reactants and the end platform is the products.
The important point is that in both pictures, the start and end platforms are at the same heights—so the overall free-energy change, ΔG, is the same. That’s thermodynamics: it tells us the difference between reactants and products—basically, whether the reaction is “downhill” or “uphill” and where equilibrium lies.

Now, kinetics is about how fast we get from reactants to products, and that depends on the height of the hill in the middle—that’s the activation energy, ΔG‡.
Without an enzyme, the hill is huge, so the reaction is slow. With an enzyme, the hill is smaller—meaning the enzyme lowers ΔG‡, so the reaction happens faster.

So the big takeaway: enzymes don’t change ΔG or equilibrium—they just lower ΔG‡, making it faster to reach the same destination.

Student takeaways: Thermodynamics (ΔG): compares reactants vs products → tells favorability/equilibrium, not speed. 
Kinetics (ΔG‡): the activation barrier → determines reaction rate. 
Enzymes lower ΔG‡ (smaller hill) → faster rate. 
Enzymes do NOT change ΔG, ΔG°′, or Keq → same start/end heights, same equilibrium. 
Enzymes speed up both forward and reverse reactions; they just help you reach equilibrium faster.

submissions.name: Abigail Jimenez
submissions.categoryRaw: Mnemonic so its easier to remember
submissions.explanation: Since this slide is putting everything together, my slide is a better reference slide to what was covered in prior slides. I also included mnemonics since a lot of students use mnemonics to recall.
submissions.notes:
This slide puts the entire protein folding story into one 'cheat code' for your memory. 

Remember the top line." The Framework: "Walk through Sequence → Shape → Fold → Friends. 

Sequence (1°): It's just the spelling. The order of amino acids. 

Shape (2°): These are local patterns like helixes and sheets, held together by backbone interactions.

 Fold (3°): This is the big 3D crunch. The hydrophobic effect pushes water-hating parts inside. 

Friends (4°): When multiple folded chains stick together." 

The Misfolding Trap: At the bottom, we answer the 'So what?' question. If proteins misfold, they expose sticky parts, clump together, lose function, and cause disease (like Alzheimer's)


Student takeaway: Proteins are built from a Sequence (1°) stabilized by peptide bonds, into Shapes (2°) held by backbone H-bonds, then Folded (3°) via side-chain interactions, and sometimes joined by Friends (4°) as multiple subunits, where any misfolding causes them to "Clump → Loss → Disease.".

submissions.name: Annabelle Huang
submissions.explanation: The fix: this version is better because the slide looks less crowded with too much information. This slide should either replace #65 or go before #65. My slide has emphasis on the cross beta-sheets, but I left the percentages out because they are already written on slide #68 (Note: I would have made my slide incorporate more of the Zombie theme, but I ran out of Nano Banana pro free daily prompts).
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: Prions can be viewed as zombies of the molecular world. Misfolded Prp^sc proteins can perform templated conversions, in other words “infect”, a normal PrP^c protein. The Prp^Sc protein forms because it is a kinetically favored state over the Prp^c protein.

Student Takeaways: 
Proteins can have the same sequence with two very different forms. 
ex) Prions have the same sequence that gives rise to the green form (rich in alpha helices) or the red form (rich in abnormal cross-beta amyloid aggregate)
Prions violate Anfinsen's dogma that 1 sequence = 1 protein structure.

submissions.name: Lauren Hamilton
submissions.explanation: Slides 12 and 13 detail the several reasons why amino acid sequences are important. However, the slides are dense with words. As a visual learner, improved version is most optimal for this slide deck because it has images to better explain these fundamental concepts.
submissions.notes:
When we talk about protein sequences, we aren’t just looking at a string of letters; we are looking at biological destiny. Think of the sequence as a 3D printer’s code: if the code is perfect, the protein folds into a functional machine. If there is a single ‘typo’—what we call a mutation—the key no longer fits the lock, leading to disease. Finally, because these sequences are inherited, they act as a molecular paper trail. By comparing the 'spelling' of proteins across different species, we can map out the history of life on Earth without ever digging up a single fossil.

Order = Shape: The specific linear arrangement of L-amino acids is the sole factor that determines how a protein folds into its final 3D form.
Precision is Vital: Because function follows form, a change in even one amino acid can render a protein useless, often resulting in genetic diseases.
The Genetic Link: Amino acid sequences are the direct translation of our DNA; they are the bridge between our genes and our physical traits.
Molecular Clock: The more similar the protein sequences are between two species, the more recently they shared a common ancestor.

submissions.name: Nancy Zhang
submissions.explanation: The new slide can replace the old 41st slide. In the new slide it is clearly illustrated that in heterotropic effect, inhibitors and activators shift the activity curve in different directions, and in homotropic, the substrate affects the activity curve by affecting sensitivity. Moreover, emphasizing neither effector changes Vmax.
submissions.notes:
ATCase exists in two conformations: a low-activity T state and a high-activity R state. Regulation works by shifting the balance between these two states.

Homotropic effectors: substrates, eg aspartate. When substrate binds, enzyme’s apparent affinity ↑. This shifts the activity curve left
Heterotropic effectors: different molecules, eg ATP and CTP. They stabilize different conformations of the enzyme: ATP stabilizes the R state and activates the enzyme, while CTP stabilizes the T state and inhibits it.
“Same Vmax, different sensitivity—affinity for homotropic, conformation for heterotropic.”

Study Takeaway 
Homotropic vs Heterotropic Regulation — ATCase
Homotropic effectors (substrate):
	•	Change enzyme affinity
	•	Shift apparent K_{0.5}
	•	Mechanism: cooperative substrate binding
Heterotropic effectors (ATP, CTP):
	•	Shift T ⇌ R equilibrium
	•	ATP → stabilizes R (activator)
	•	CTP → stabilizes T (inhibitor)

submissions.name: Madeline Livingston
submissions.explanation: It was difficult to visualize where in the body these modes of CO2 transport were happening, and how they functioned. The new image provides a bit more insight into the transportation process, while still maintaining the integrity of the equations and mechanisms.
submissions.notes:
Dissolved in Plasma (~5%) is the simplest form of transport. CO2 is highly soluble in water and diffuses from tissues directly into the plasma. This dissolved portion is what creates the partial pressure, pO2, that drives diffusion in the lungs. 

Bicarbonate Ions (~70%) is a vital part of the body's pH buffering system. CO2 enters the RBC, where Carbonic Anhydrase converts it to H2CO3, and then HCO3- and a proton. To maintain electrical balance, the negative Bicarbonate leaves the cell, and a negative Chloride  ion enters. This is known as the Chloride Shift.

Carbamate (~25%) Instead of changing into an ion, CO2 binds directly to the proteins in the blood. CO2 binds to the amino groups -NH2 of the globin chains in hemoglobin. It does not bind to the iron sites where oxygen sits. 

Student Takeaways: 

Carbon dioxide is a "molecular chameleon" that changes its form to avoid making the blood toxic

One quick note for the student: In the first section, the partial pressure created by CO2 is actually PCO2. PO2 refers specifically to Oxygen.

submissions.name: Jai Sethi
submissions.slideRaw: The new slide will go after 50 and become 51.
submissions.explanation: This slide is very beneficial because it explains the concept of the transition state using an analogy that is easy for anyone to understand. By connecting the chemistry concept to a real-life example, it makes the idea of the transition state more accessible and easier to grasp. I would place this slide after the original slide so the scientific explanation is introduced first, and this slide can then reinforce it by serving as a visual analogy.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: This slide uses a mountain hiker analogy to explain the transition state. Just like a hiker must climb to the top of a mountain, reactants must gain activation energy to reach the transition state. The peak represents the transition state, which is the highest-energy and most unstable point. Once the peak is reached, the reaction can proceed downhill to form products.
Student Takeaways: The transition state is the highest-energy point in a reaction. Activation energy is the energy needed to reach the transition state. Analogies can help make complex chemistry concepts easier to understand. Once activation energy is overcome, products form more easily.

submissions.name: Kiley McGee
submissions.explanation: This slide is a better visual representation, and shows the connection between the pH buffer and the physiology. The images on the original slide were not very visible and it was not as obvious that the reactions were the opposite directions of each other
submissions.notes:
Speaker Notes (Script)The Hook: "Hemoglobin isn't just an oxygen truck; it’s a sponge for acid. It keeps our blood pH stable."In Tissues (Left): "Cells produce $CO_2$. Inside red blood cells, this converts to acid ($H^+$). Hemoglobin immediately binds this acid so it doesn't hurt the cell."In Lungs (Right): "When oxygen hits hemoglobin, it kicks the acid off. The acid turns back into $CO_2$, and we exhale it."Bottom Line: "Essentially, we transport acid from our muscles to our lungs safely hidden inside hemoglobin."

Student Takeaways (Cheat Sheet)
The Equation is Reversible
Hemoglobin's Job: It buffers pH by binding hydrogen ions ($H^+$) in the tissues.pH Rule of Thumb:High $CO_2$ (holding breath) = Acidic (Low pH)Low $CO_2$ (hyperventilating) = Alkaline (High pH)Key Enzyme: Carbonic Anhydrase drives this reaction.

submissions.name: Gabriela Kobak
submissions.explanation: This version is better or adds to the original slide because an analogy makes the concept easier to understand and relate to real-world scenarios. I felt like the original slide was confusing, and I could not relate the information to immunizations.
submissions.notes:
The Concept: B-Cells are rock climbers, and the Antigen is the "handhold" on the wall. To survive (not fall), the climber must maintain a grip on the hold. The Key Variable: Grip Strength = Binding Affinity ($1/K_d$).
- There are many climbers (B-cells) on the wall. Some have weak grips, some have strong grips. Because the holds are so big and abundant, everyone stays on the wall.
- Boosters Create a "Hard Wall" for B-Cells: Think of the booster shot as making the climbing wall much harder by drastically reducing the number and size of available handholds (antigens).
- Survival of the "Stickiest": When the antigen supply is abundant (primary response), even B-cells with moderate "grip" (higher $K_d$) can survive. But with limited antigen (booster), only the B-cells with the strongest "grip" (lowest $K_d$) can hold on and continue to proliferate. 
- Affinity Maturation is Like "Evolution in Action": Just like only the fittest climbers survive the hardest walls, the immune system uses the limited antigen from a booster to actively select for B-cells that produce higher-affinity (tighter-binding) antibodies. 
- The Goal is a "Bionic Grip": Each exposure to the antigen, especially with a booster, pushes the B-cells to develop a "bionic super-grip" – meaning antibodies that bind the antigen much more tightly and effectively. This is crucial for rapid and effective protection against future infections.

submissions.name: Carter Fortune
submissions.slideRaw: New slide can go after the final slide of the chapter 3 amino acid lecture which talked about BCAA benefits.
submissions.explanation: We talked about BCAAs at the end of the amino acid lecture. We only mentioned the benefits of BCAA including protein synthesis and muscle growth, energy production, glucose homeostasis, and preventing muscle wasting. However, excessive BCAA consumption can cause negative effects.
submissions.notes:
“Chronically elevated branched-chain amino acids—especially leucine—act as persistent nutrient signals rather than just building blocks. Leucine directly activates the mTORC1 pathway, which is normally turned on briefly after meals to promote protein synthesis.

When BCAAs remain elevated, mTORC1 becomes chronically active. This leads to inhibitory phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrate-1, which blunts downstream insulin signaling through the PI3K–Akt pathway. As a result, glucose uptake in muscle and adipose tissue decreases, promoting systemic insulin resistance.

At the same time, excess BCAAs overwhelm normal hepatic and mitochondrial catabolism. This causes accumulation of branched-chain keto acids and incomplete oxidation products, which impair mitochondrial function and increase oxidative stress. In the liver, this promotes lipid accumulation and contributes to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

Additionally, high circulating BCAAs compete with aromatic amino acids like tryptophan and tyrosine for transport across the blood–brain barrier, potentially altering neurotransmitter synthesis.

Overall, chronically elevated BCAAs shift amino acids from anabolic signals into metabolic stressors, linking excess intake to insulin resistance, fatty liver disease, and cardiovascular risk.”


BCAAs are signaling molecules, not just nutrients

Chronic BCAA elevation → persistent mTORC1 activation

Overactive mTORC1 inhibits insulin signaling → insulin resistance

Excess BCAAs overwhelm mitochondrial oxidation

Accumulated BCAA metabolites contribute to NAFLD and metabolic disease

High BCAAs can alter neurotransmitter balance via BBB competition

submissions.name: Sophia Kuzminski
submissions.explanation: The old slide shows O3 instead of O2, making it unclear how O2 is bent. Also, it was difficult to visualize the difference between the two configurations because the steric hindrance appeared out of nowhere in the diagram.
submissions.notes: The distal histidine is the 'bouncer’ for the Fe2+ on the Heme group of hemeglobin. It acts as a molecular attic, blocking straight-line binding geometries. O₂ likes to bend, while CO is a linear molecule. That means O2 is at the perfect orientation to make a hydrogen bond with distal histidine, so it wants to be there, while CO cannot form a hydrogen bond with either histidine. Also, the steric hindrance of the distal histidine molecular attic blocks larger molecules from oxidizing Fe2+ into Fe3+ which would not bind O2.  Takeaway: It is the protein environment that helps Fe2+ bind O2 instead of CO.

submissions.name: Gabriela Kobak
submissions.slideRaw: Originally slide 10 but it could also go after slide 10 as an extension
submissions.explanation: I believe that the original slide was hard to understand and would have been conceptualized more easily with an analogy. I feel that the rock climber analogy clearly explains the connection between kd and immunizations and B-cells. I think this slide could accompany the original slide 10 and go after it.
submissions.notes:
- Boosters Create a "Hard Wall" for B-Cells: Think of the booster shot as making the climbing wall much harder by drastically reducing the number and size of available handholds (antigens).
- Survival of the "Stickiest": When the antigen supply is abundant (primary response), even B-cells with moderate "grip" (higher $K_d$) can survive. But with limited antigen (booster), only the B-cells with the strongest "grip" (lowest $K_d$) can hold on and continue to proliferate. 
- Affinity Maturation is Like "Evolution in Action": Just like only the fittest climbers survive the hardest walls, the immune system uses the limited antigen from a booster to actively select for B-cells that produce higher-affinity (tighter-binding) antibodies. 
- The Goal is a "Bionic Grip": Each exposure to the antigen, especially with a booster, pushes the B-cells to develop a "bionic super-grip" – meaning antibodies that bind the antigen much more tightly and effectively. This is crucial for rapid and effective protection against future infections.

submissions.name: Rosalin Watras
submissions.explanation: The original slide incorrectly defined catalytic efficiency as KM/kcatK M /k cat. Catalytic efficiency is correctly defined as kcat/KMk cat/K M , which captures how effectively an enzyme works when substrate is limited by combining turnover speed (kcat) with substrate requirement (KM). The incorrect ratio reverses this meaning and would mis-rank enzyme efficiency. This slide should replace the original Slide 28, immediately after the introduction of kcat and before the discussion of diffusion-limited enzymes, where catalytic efficiency is first applied.
submissions.notes:
PRESENTER NOTES
Catalytic efficiency tells us how well an enzyme works when substrate is scarce, which is the usual physiological condition. It combines how fast the enzyme can turn over substrate (kcat) with how much substrate is required to reach activity (KM). That is why catalytic efficiency is defined as kcat/KM.
STUDENT TAKEAWAYS
Catalytic efficiency = kcat/KM
High efficiency means fast turnover and low substrate requirement
The most efficient enzymes approach the diffusion limit

submissions.name: Arav Mathapati
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, Better Visual/Diagram, Better Explanation/Analogy, Missing something important that is in the publisher's slide deck
submissions.explanation: The revised slide corrects an inaccuracy in the original slide by clarifying that hemoglobin S polymerization occurs primarily in the deoxygenated T state, not the oxygenated R state. It explains that the Val6 mutation creates a hydrophobic interaction that is structurally possible only in the T state, because the hydrophobic pocket is not properly formed in the R state. The improved visual and explanation clearly link molecular structure to disease mechanism. This slide should be presented immediately after or replacing slide 53, which introduces hemoglobin aggregation, to provide an accurate mechanistic explanation.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:


Hemoglobin S polymerizes primarily in the deoxygenated T state. The Glu6→Val mutation creates a hydrophobic interaction that allows HbS molecules to bind together and form fibers. In the oxygenated R state, the hydrophobic pocket is not properly formed, so polymerization does not occur. This is why sickling happens in low oxygen conditions.


Student Takeaways:


HbS polymerizes primarily in the deoxygenated T state.
The Glu6→Val mutation creates a hydrophobic interaction that causes fiber formation.
Oxygenated hemoglobin does not polymerize because its structure prevents this interaction.

submissions.name: Megan Jones
submissions.explanation: The math corresponding to the Levinthal's paradox was hard to read/cluttered among other key points on the slide. I think this slide should come before the significance of the Levinthal's paradox slide (slide 54), to prove the enormous number of possible protein conformations that make random folding implausible. This will further highlight why proteins must fold via directed pathways rather than by trial and error.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: How many conformations would a 100-residue protein need to sample if each residue had just 3 options?" (calculate: 3^100)
Student takeaways: Folding follows biased pathways—constraints eliminate wrong options without trying them

submissions.name: Charlene Kim-Aun
submissions.explanation: There is a typo in slide 2. It refers to a binding curve as "hyperibolic" instead of hyperbolic.
submissions.notes: These are the main takeaways of our lecture for today. We focus on how two different curves, hyperbolic and sigmoidal, explain the relationships in molecular interactions and dive into the workings of myoglobin and hemoglobin.

submissions.name: Jackson Tower
submissions.explanation: The bulk of the information on the original slide is in very small text compared to the size of the whole thing. This makes it difficult for students in the back of room to read as opposed to this new layout. To make it easier to read and more capable of fitting onto the slide in a bigger size, I removed some of the "wordy" language and made the points more direct. Also, the original slide contains a note under the diagram that clarifies a slight inaccuracy; it would be better to just include that clarification within the diagram itself, so students can just screenshot the diagram to add it to their notes without having to also copy over a clarification of "often" or "typically", since now it already says that on the diagram itself.
submissions.notes:
--The KM  value is the substrate concentration at which the enzyme operates at 1/2 its maximum velocity
        --*Also approximately the substrate concentration of the enzyme in vivo.
--Indicates efficiency of an enzyme selecting substrate and converting it to product.
--Enzymes with SMALL KM achieve maximal catalytic efficiency (Vmax ) at a low substrate concentration
--KM is unique for each enzyme/substrate pair
--For certain enzymes under certain conditions, KM can also be a measure of affinity between E and S; approximates the dissociation constant of the ES complex

submissions.name: Julia
submissions.explanation: Your "Soda Fizz" slide takes the abstract data from the original Page 6 and turns it into a clinical/sensory hook. By placing it immediately after the introductory outline, you provide the "Aha!" moment that explains the physiological relevance of Rate Enhancement and Cofactors (Zinc) before the professor dives into the harder math of Gibbs Free Energy.
submissions.notes:
Most people assume the 'fizz' of a soda is just a physical sensation of bubbles popping. However, it's actually a sophisticated biochemical interaction. In the bottle, CO 
2
​	
  is held in solution by pressure. When that soda hits your tongue, it encounters Carbonic Anhydrase IV, an enzyme anchored right to your taste buds. Using a Zinc cofactor, this enzyme is one of the fastest known, reaching the diffusion-limited rate—meaning it reacts as fast as the molecules can bump into it. It converts the CO 
2
​	
  into carbonic acid and protons instantly. That sharp 'bite' you feel is actually a sensory response to the rapid flash of acidity created by the enzyme. Without Carbonic Anhydrase, your soda would just taste like flat, bumpy water

submissions.name: Ariel Wang
submissions.explanation: The original slide defines Km​ mathematically but does not explain why changes in Km matter clinically. This revised slide connects Km​ to real-world drug response by showing how mutations that increase Km​ reduce drug affinity, leading to treatment failure and drug resistance. By linking enzyme kinetics to patient non-response at standard doses, the slide clarifies the functional significance of Km​ beyond equations and makes the concept easier to apply in clinical and exam settings. I think the best placement of this slide would be between after 17.
submissions.notes: Km​ reflects how tightly an enzyme binds its substrate or a drug. A low Km​ means high affinity, so the enzyme is easily saturated at low concentrations. Clinically, if a mutation increases Km, the enzyme binds the drug poorly. Even at normal therapeutic doses, the enzyme isn’t saturated, so the drug appears ineffective. This is one mechanism behind drug resistance and treatment failure, where increasing the dose may not help and can increase toxicity.

submissions.name: Annika Bhargava
submissions.explanation: My overhaul of Slide 56 is superior because it uses a "velvet rope" analogy to simplify the abstract concept of selective permeability. While the original technical diagram accurately labels proteins, students often struggle to understand the energy barrier of the hydrophobic core. This version provides immediate conceptual anchoring by reframing the lipid bilayer as a physical barrier and clearly distinguishing between Channel Proteins, which act as VIP doors for transport, and Receptor Proteins, which act as bouncers checking IDs for signaling. By reducing cognitive load and stripping away complex rendering, it focuses purely on the functional logic of Section 1.4: how membranes delineate the cell to allow for biochemical specialization. This slide should replace or immediately follow Slide 56 to provide a foundation before students reach complex clinical examples like hypercholesterolemia later in the deck.
submissions.notes: To understand Section 1.4, think of the cell not as a fortress, but as an exclusive nightclub. The phospholipid bilayer is the velvet rope—it is a physical barrier that most biomolecules cannot simply cross because of the energy barrier created by the hydrophobic core. However, a club is useless if no guest can enter, so we have membrane proteins acting as bouncers to mediate selective permeability. Channel proteins act like a specific side-door for VIP guests to pass through, while receptor proteins act like the bouncers at the front checking IDs. These receptors recognize information in the extracellular space and 'report' it to the interior without the signaling molecule ever actually entering the cell. This dynamic setup is exactly how the cell delineates its borders to maintain and specialize its unique internal environment.

submissions.name: Nora Lash
submissions.explanation: The original publisher slides (Slides 21–22) are text-heavy and use cluttered chemical diagrams that obscure the mechanical "trigger" of cooperativity. My version is better because it:Isolates the Trigger: Explicitly labels the 0.4 Å movement of the iron atom—the sub-atomic event that drives the entire T-to-R transition.Corrects AI Hallucinations: Manually fixed the heme coordination (ensuring exactly 5 bonds to $Fe^{2+}$ in the deoxy state) and replaced garbled AI text with clean, accurate course terminology.Visualizes the Linkage: Uses a clear vector style to show how the Proximal Histidine acts as a physical lever, connecting the iron's movement directly to the F-helix rotation.
submissions.notes: "Class, look at the iron atom here. In the T-state, it sits 0.4 Å below the heme plane. When oxygen binds, it pulls that iron into the plane. Because the iron is physically tethered to the F-helix via the Proximal Histidine, this tiny 'twitch' acts like a lever. It forces a 15-degree rotation of the entire protein, snapping the other subunits into the high-affinity R-state. It’s a mechanical conversation."

submissions.name: Neha Polavarapu
submissions.explanation: The redesigned slide is significantly more effective because it eliminates dense paragraphs in favor of a high-contrast layout that reduces cognitive load for the audience. By using strategic color coding to represent different antibody types, the visual communicates the core concept of clone diversity instantly without requiring students to read through long definitions. Removing the lecture notes from the screen allows for much larger font sizes, ensuring that the key points remain legible for every student regardless of where they are sitting. The side-by-side structure creates a clear hierarchy that guides the eye naturally from the visual metaphor to the critical trade-off between specificity and robustness. This approach transforms the slide into a powerful anchor that supports your spoken explanation instead of competing with it for the students' attention.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: "Alright, let's look at our two main tools in the lab: Monoclonal and Polyclonal antibodies. Think of it this way: Monoclonal is a sniper; Polyclonal is a search party. Both have their place.

If you look at the left, Monoclonal antibodies come from a single B-cell 'clone.' Because they are identical, they only recognize one tiny specific spot on the antigen: one epitope. This is your go-to for diagnostics or drugs where you need zero cross-reactivity and perfect reproducibility.

On the right, we have Polyclonals. These are harvested from the serum of an immunized animal. Because the animal’s whole immune system responded, you get a 'cocktail' of antibodies hitting multiple different spots on the same target.

Here’s the trap students fall into: You might think Monoclonal is 'better' because it’s more expensive and precise. But if that one specific epitope gets masked or mutated, the Monoclonal antibody fails completely. The Polyclonal is robust: if one spot is hidden, the other antibodies in the mix will still find the target. It gives you a much stronger signal in a noisy environment."


Student Takeways: 
Monoclonal = Consistency: Derived from one B-cell; targets one epitope. Best for clinical applications where specificity is king.

Polyclonal = Sensitivity: Derived from multiple B-cells; targets multiple epitopes. Best for general detection because it provides a more "robust" signal.

The Trade-off: Monoclonals are expensive and difficult to produce but offer "infinite" identical batches. Polyclonals are cheap and fast but vary from animal to animal.

Exam Tip: If a question asks for an antibody that won't change between experiments conducted 10 years apart, choose Monoclonal.

submissions.name: Tivona Dodamgoda
submissions.slideRaw: After Slide 35 (Histidine: The Most Important Charged Amino Acid) This fits immediately after the histidine pKa discussion and before moving deeper into amino acid functional roles.
submissions.explanation: The current slides accurately teach the pH versus pKa rule and highlight histidine’s role in catalysis, but they present pKa values as fixed numbers. In reality, pKa depends on the local environment within a protein, which is a key mechanistic concept in biochemistry and enzyme function. This new slide improves understanding by showing that a charged amino acid is stabilized in water, whereas the same amino acid buried in a hydrophobic protein core is energetically disfavored from remaining charged. As a result, proteins can shift pKa values to fine-tune amino acid reactivity. This connects memorization to mechanism and helps students understand how enzymes actively control chemistry. The slide should be placed immediately after the histidine slide (Slide 35) during the discussion of ionizable side chains and catalysis.
submissions.notes:
“Up to now, we’ve treated pKa values like fixed numbers from a table. But inside proteins, pKa is not constant — it depends on the environment.

In water, charged groups are stabilized because water molecules can surround and solvate them. But if an amino acid like histidine is buried in a hydrophobic pocket, there’s no stabilization for a charged form. A charged group in a nonpolar environment is energetically unfavorable.

So the protein shifts the pKa. Often this makes histidine less likely to be protonated. Proteins use this strategy to fine-tune amino acid chemistry for catalysis. Enzymes don’t just use amino acids — they engineer the environment around them.”

Student Takeaways
- pKa values can change inside proteins
- Local environment (polar vs hydrophobic) affects protonation
- Buried residues are less likely to carry charge
- Proteins tune amino acid chemistry to enable catalysis

submissions.name: Lyden Butler
submissions.explanation: This should replace the slide 40 (or page 40) in the chapter 2 slideshow. I thought my new one is a lot more organized and clear. Since the lectures are pretty fast paced, I think it would be easier for someone to understand on their first try reading it.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes 
Hook: Here’s the rule that answers almost every acid–base question: compare pH to pKa.
- If pH is less than pKa, the solution is more acidic, so the molecule stays protonated.
- If pH is greater than pKa, the solution is more basic, so the molecule loses a proton.
At pH equals pKa, neither side wins — you have equal amounts of HA and A⁻. That’s what Henderson–Hasselbalch means when the log term is zero.
Every one-unit change in pH shifts the balance by a factor of 10. One unit below pKa: mostly HA. One unit above pKa: mostly A⁻.
That’s why buffers only work well within ±1 pH unit of their pKa — outside that range, one form dominates and buffering fails.
STUDENT TAKEAWAYS 
pH < pKa → protonated (HA)
pH = pKa → 50% HA, 50% A⁻
pH > pKa → deprotonated (A⁻)
±1 pH unit = 10× change in ratio
Buffers work best within ±1 pH unit of pKa

submissions.name: Olivia Morin
submissions.categoryRaw: Found a Factual Error, New Clinical/Historical Connection
submissions.explanation:
1) The chemical structure was not of HCG, it was of estradiol. I changed the slide to have the correct HCG structure, since that is what is detected when taking a pregnancy test. I also expanded on the speaker notes to give a brief overview of what the techniques are doing that you mentioned. Personally, I like understanding the context of why we use a technique. 

2) I created a slide about a clinical implication relating to pI, PTMs and Ion-exchange chromatography.
submissions.notes:
1) Hook
“Before we dive into mechanisms, recognize this: you’ll ORDER these tests as physicians. Today you’re learning how they work.”

Key Points: Clinical Tests = Protein Biochemistry
Every major clinical diagnostic test is built on protein biochemistry, especially antibody–antigen interactions.

Pregnancy testing → ELISA detecting hCG
Uses antibodies that specifically bind human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).
A color change (or line on a strip) appears when hCG is present, indicating pregnancy.


Myocardial infarction (MI) diagnosis → Immunoassay for cardiac troponin
Antibodies detect cardiac troponin, a protein released into blood when heart muscle is damaged.
Higher signal = higher troponin = greater likelihood of heart injury.


HIV confirmation → Western blot
Viral proteins are separated by size, transferred to a membrane, and probed with patient antibodies.
A positive result shows specific bands, confirming antibodies against HIV proteins.



Preempting a Common Misconception
Clinical labs are not “black boxes.”
They apply the same protein techniques you are learning: protein recognition, binding specificity, and detection.


Transition
“Now let’s formalize exactly what you should master by the end of this chapter.”

📚 Student Study Signals
Core takeaway:
Clinical diagnostics are direct applications of protein biochemistry techniques.


Techniques you must recognize:
ELISA – detects specific proteins using antibody binding and signal generation
Immunoassay – general antibody-based detection of biomarkers
Western blot – identifies specific proteins based on size and antibody recognition


Exam framing:
Application-based questions
Match the clinical test to the underlying biochemical technique





2) When a Protein’s Charge Becomes a Diagnosis
Hook:
“The protein is present. The gene is normal. But it migrates to a different pH. That shift is the disease.”

Relating Concepts:
Proteins have a characteristic isoelectric point (pI) determined by their acidic and basic amino acids.
Post-translational modifications (PTMs) change charge
Charge changes alter ion-exchange chromatography behavior and isoelectric focusing position

Clinical Scenario: Acute Phase Response & Inflammation
During inflammation, liver proteins (e.g., acute-phase proteins) become heavily glycosylated and phosphorylated
These PTMs add negative charge, shifting the protein’s pI to a lower value
On IEF or ion-exchange chromatography, the same protein now appears in a different fraction or position

Why This Matters Clinically:
The protein level may be unchanged, but its charge state is altered
Diagnostic labs detect pI shifts, not just protein abundance
Explains why inflammatory states change electrophoretic patterns even without changes in gene expression

Preempt Misconception:
Disease doesn’t always change how much protein is present —
sometimes it changes how that protein behaves chemically.

Student Takeaway:
Post-translational modifications can alter protein charge, shifting pI, chromatography behavior, and diagnostic readouts without altering protein sequence.

Exam Framing:
Application:
Predict how phosphorylation affects pI and ion-exchange behavior
Interpret why the same protein appears in a different IEF position during disease

submissions.name: Aditi Shanbhag
submissions.explanation: This slide can serve as a substitute for slide 55 in the slide deck! When I was reading the textbook, I picked up on some details/facts that helped me understand the content better (for instance, despite the active site comprising a small portion of the enzyme, studies have shown that nearly all enzymes are still made up of at least 100 amino acid residues - this can be attributed to reason such as supporting with the scaffolding of the active site, along with housing the allosteric site), so I thought it'd be of benefit to include that in the slide.
submissions.notes:
Presenter’s Notes: 
“Even though enzymes vary a lot in structure, their active sites share some key features.”
Active sites contain catalytic groups — amino acid residues that directly participate in making and breaking chemical bonds. These residues are doing the chemistry, not just holding the substrate in place.

The active site also promotes formation of the transition state, which is how enzymes speed up reactions — by stabilizing this high-energy state, not by changing the overall ΔG.

Structurally, the active site is a three-dimensional cleft or crevice. Importantly, it’s formed by amino acids that may be far apart in the primary sequence, but are brought together through protein folding. 

To create this cleft, the enzyme sacrifices other structural interactions.
A classic example is lysozyme, where residues 35, 52, 62, 63, 101, and 108 come together to form the active site.

The active site itself is tiny, but powerful. Most enzymes contain 100+ amino acids, and the majority of the protein serves as a rigid scaffold that maintains the active site’s shape or provides allosteric regulation.

Finally, active sites are unique microenvironments. There’s often little room for water, creating a hydrophobic pocket, while reactive polar residues are precisely positioned to interact with the substrate through hydrogen bonds and van der Waals interactions.

Student Takeaways:
- Active sites contain catalytic amino acids that make and break bonds
- Enzymes stabilize the transition state to speed up reactions
- Active sites are 3D clefts formed by amino acids far apart in sequence
The active site is small, but the rest of the enzyme forms a rigid scaffold
- Enzymes often have 100+ amino acids, including allosteric sites
- Active sites are unique microenvironments with limited water
- Hydrogen bonds and van der Waals interactions drive tight substrate binding

submissions.name: Isha Shah
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Visual/Diagram, Better Explanation/Analogy, Missing something important that is in the publisher's slide deck
submissions.explanation:
The original material correctly states that enzymes bind the transition state and lower activation energy, but it does not clearly explain WHY binding the transition state lowers ΔG‡.

As a result, students often memorize “transition state stabilization” without actually understanding the mechanism.
submissions.notes:
“Okay, so here’s the big misconception students often have: enzymes do not speed reactions by simply grabbing the substrate tighter.

If they did, then enzymes would bind the substrate with maximum affinity, and the substrate would basically get stuck in the active site.

Instead, enzymes speed reactions by stabilizing the transition state.

The transition state is the highest-energy, most unstable part of the reaction — it’s the ‘breaking up is hard’ moment.

So the best analogy is that the enzyme is like a glove designed for an awkward hand shape.
The substrate is the relaxed hand, but the transition state is the weird bent shape the substrate temporarily takes during the reaction.

The enzyme’s active site fits that awkward transition-state geometry best.

That’s why induced fit matters — the enzyme and substrate both distort slightly so the transition state fits more tightly.

And that’s the key point thermodynamically: the binding energy released when the enzyme binds the transition state lowers the activation barrier.

That’s why ΔG‡ goes down.

And clinically, this is exactly why drugs like statins are so effective — they mimic the transition state of HMG-CoA reductase and bind extremely tightly, shutting the enzyme down.”

✅ STUDENT TAKEAWAYS (Bottom Line bullets)
Bottom Line

Enzymes catalyze reactions by stabilizing the TRANSITION STATE, not by “helping substrate.”

Active sites are most complementary to the transition state geometry (ES‡).

Induced fit helps distort the substrate toward the transition state.

**Binding energy

submissions.name: Lisa Hires
submissions.explanation: This slide was completely bare and "ugly", so I redesigned it to be more effective by adding visual references. These graphics plus speaker notes (which were also absent in the original slide) will provide better context and understanding of the material. This new slide should be presented in place of the other slide in the slide deck (Slide 10, Lecture 4).
submissions.notes:
Speaker Notes:

"Now that we understand the chemistry of the peptide bond, let’s look at the bigger picture. Why are we so obsessed with the specific sequence of amino acids—what we call the primary structure?

1. Sequence Dictates Structure
The sequence isn't just a list; it’s a set of folding instructions. Because of the rigid peptide bonds we just discussed, the chain can’t just flop around randomly. Instead, the specific order of R-groups forces the chain to fold into a very specific 3D shape, like an intricate piece of origami.

2. Structure Dictates Function
In biology, shape is everything. A protein’s 3D conformation creates active sites, binding pockets, and structural anchors. If it doesn't fold into the exact right shape, it can't catalyze a reaction or signal a cell. Structure is the bridge between a chemical sequence and biological life.

3. Sequence Alterations and Disease
Because the sequence is the blueprint, even a tiny 'typo' can be catastrophic.

In Sickle Cell Anemia, a single amino acid swap—replacing a glutamate with a valine—causes hemoglobin to clump together, distorting the red blood cell.

In Cystic Fibrosis, the deletion of just one phenylalanine residue (Phe508) prevents a critical chloride channel from ever reaching the cell membrane.

4. Evolutionary History
Finally, sequences are a molecular clock. By comparing the protein sequences of a human, a monkey, and a mouse, we can map out how closely related we are. Interestingly, you'll notice that the 3D structure is often more 'conserved' than the sequence itself. Nature is pragmatic: it might swap out a few amino acids over millions of years, but as long as the final 3D tool still works, the protein stays in the toolkit."

Student Takeaways:
- Sequence = Instructions: The linear order of amino acids acts as the "blueprint" that forces a protein to fold into a specific 3D shape.
- Shape = Function: In biology, structure dictates function. If a protein loses its shape, it loses its ability to work.
- Small Errors, Big Impact: A change in just one amino acid can lead to severe diseases like Sickle Cell or Cystic Fibrosis by breaking the protein’s 3D structure.
- Evolutionary Link: Protein sequences are "molecular fossils"; comparing them across species reveals how life has evolved and which structures are too important to change.

submissions.name: Kareem Fenaish
submissions.explanation:
This slide should go in the place of slide 35 exactly where it is. The original slide used the text metaphor that Histidine is the "Swiss Army knife of catalysis" , but the accompanying visual was just a standard chemical structure of the amino acid.

The Fix: I replaced the standard chemical structure with a literal illustration of a red Swiss Army Knife. Instead of blades and corkscrews, the tools extending from the knife represent Histidine's actual chemical functions (Proton Donor, Proton Acceptor, Metal Binder, and pH Sensor).

Better because:
 - It connects the dots: The original slide forced students to imagine why Histidine is like a multi-tool. This version shows them. It aligns the visual directly with the text, reducing cognitive load and making the concept instantly intuitive.
 - It creates a "Memory Hook": Students are far more likely to remember a red knife with chemical "tools" than a black-and-white molecular structure. 
-  It Connects the Dots: The original slide forced students to imagine why Histidine is like a multi-tool. This version shows them
 - It Clarifies the versatility of the amino acid
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:

We often call Histidine the 'Swiss Army Knife' of amino acids, but I wanted to show you exactly what we mean by that. Because its pKa is approximately 6.0—right near physiological pH—it is the only amino acid that can easily toggle its tools.

In one situation, it acts as a Proton Donor (the knife blade) for catalysis. In another, it acts as a Proton Acceptor (the screwdriver) to stabilize a reaction. It can also open up to bind metals like Zinc in our immune system or act as a pH sensor in hemoglobin. No other amino acid has this many 'tools' ready to go at neutral pH."

Student Takeaways:
- Versatility: Histidine's imidazole ring allows it to function as both an acid and a base at physiological pH.
- The "Tools": Key roles include proton shuttling (catalysis), metal coordination, and pH sensing.
- The Mechanism: This versatility is possible because Histidine's pKa (~6.0) is close to physiological pH (7.4), allowing it to easily switch charge states.

submissions.name: Lilly Bishop
submissions.explanation: This slide is much clearer, the original slide is very cluttered and difficult to takeaway the message from.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
The Common Misconception: Start by debunking the idea that nonpolar molecules "seek each other out"; they are actually indifferent to one another.

The Initial State (Left): Explain that water molecules must form highly ordered, rigid "clathrate" cages around isolated nonpolar molecules to maximize hydrogen bonding, which is thermodynamically "expensive" due to low entropy.

The Final State (Right): Show that when hydrophobes cluster, they decrease their total surface area. This breaks the cages and "frees" the water molecules to move randomly in the bulk solution.

The Thermodynamic Driver: Emphasize that the release of water increases the total entropy (ΔS) of the system, making the process spontaneous (ΔG<0) even though the nonpolar molecules themselves are becoming more "ordered."

Student Takeaways / Bottom Line
Entropy-Driven: The hydrophobic effect is driven by the maximization of water entropy, not by an inherent attraction between nonpolar molecules.

The "Push" of Water: Water essentially "pushes" nonpolar molecules together to regain its own freedom of movement and disorder.

Biological Significance: This is the primary force responsible for protein folding (creating a hydrophobic core) and the spontaneous formation of lipid bilayers in cell membranes.

Thermodynamic Signage: Because the release of water creates a large positive ΔS, the resulting ΔG is negative, facilitating spontaneous structural organization in the cell.

submissions.name: Miranda Sculimbrene
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Visual/Diagram, I made the slide less cluttered with words.
submissions.explanation: This slide should replace slide 45. I deleted the dense block of text defining basic units. I retained the specific conversion factor (1 kJ = 0.239 kcal) at the bottom. This is the only "reference" information you actually need to interpret the two columns in the table. By clearing the visual clutter at the bottom, your attention is now immediately drawn to the core concept: the relationship between the equilibrium constant and Free Energy.
submissions.notes:
Key points:

Direct relationship: A more negative Standard Free Energy Change leads to a larger Equilibrium Constant (products are favored).

The Reverse: A positive Standard Free Energy Change leads to a smaller Equilibrium Constant (reactants are favored).

Crucial Distinction: The Free Energy Change (actual conditions) is not equal to the Standard Free Energy Change (a standard constant).

Note: Remind students that cellular concentrations rarely match standard conditions.

Logarithmic scale: Small changes in Energy lead to massive changes in the Equilibrium Constant (powers of 10).

Student takeaways:

Trend over memorization: A more negative Standard Free Energy Change means the products are more stable.

The "Zero" Point: If the Equilibrium Constant is 1, then the Standard Free Energy Change is 0.

Check your units: Use the factor (0.239) to convert kilojoules to kilocalories if required.

Exam tip: Don't confuse the constant (Standard Free Energy Change) with the actual driving force (Free Energy Change).

submissions.name: Matthew

In the original image, it has O3 binding on the left and O2 binding on the right and with one of the Oxygens blue like carbon. I fixed it to where there is a double bond between the O2 on the left and a triple bond between the CO on the right.

This structural constraint, combined with a hydrogen bond that specifically stabilizes the O2 molecule, allows the protein environment to overcome CO's natural affinity advantage for the heme iron. 

Student Takeaways: Remember that while free heme naturally bonds tighter to CO, the protein environment (specifically the distal histidine) flips this preference to favor O2. It achieves this by physically blocking the linear shape CO needs and stabilizing the bent shape of O2 with a hydrogen bond.

submissions.name: Adi Barot
submissions.explanation: The new version relates to everyday processes and makes it easier to conceptually understand the central dogma in biochemistry. I think it should be presented in the same position in the slide deck (47).
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
DNA (The Cookbook): The master blueprint that remains protected in the "library" (nucleus).
mRNA (The Index Card): A portable, temporary copy of a single recipe used to transport information.
Protein (The Cake): The final functional product that performs the actual cellular work.
Transcription/Translation: The act of "copying" the recipe to a card versus "baking" the final product.

Student TakeawaysDirectionality: Information flows DNA --> RNA --> Protein.   
Process Definitions: Transcription uses RNA Polymerase; Translation (mRNA to Protein) occurs at the Ribosome.
Cell Differentiation: Different cells "bake" different recipes; selective expression is why a liver cell differs from a brain cell.The Exception: Retroviruses like HIV can reverse this flow, copying RNA back into the DNA "cookbook".

submissions.name: Nathalia de la Rosa
submissions.explanation: The "High/Goodbye" rhyme provides an instant mental shortcut that is faster to recall than a mathematical inequality. This slide should be placed immediately after the first introduction of the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation or the formal definition of pKa. It serves as the "Applied Logic" bridge before moving into amino acid titration curves or protein folding.
submissions.notes:
The Hook: "Think of the $pH$ not as a math problem, but as the 'vibe' of the room. Is the room crowded with protons, or is there plenty of space?"
The Logic: "When the $pH$ is Low, the 'room' is already packed with protons. There’s no room for our guest to leave, so the proton won't go. The molecule stays protonated."
The Logic: "When the pH is High, the room is empty. Our guest sees an open door and plenty of space—so the proton says Goodbye. The molecule becomes deprotonated."
The Transition: "If you can remember this rhyme, you can predict the charge of any amino acid side chain at any pH without ever touching a calculator." 
Student Takeaways
The "Drill it" Rule: pH < pKa = Protonated (High concentration of H+ forces the proton to stay).
The "Drill it" Rule: pH > pKa = Deprotonated (Low concentration of H+ allows the proton to leave).
Key Concept: The pKa is the "tipping point" or "threshold" where exactly 50% of the molecules have said "Goodbye" to their protons.

submissions.name: Shreya Madan
submissions.explanation:
“Fix” Explanation: While the current slide deck lists altitude as a cause for a right shift on the summary graph (Slide 51) and discusses high altitude adaptation in geese (Slide 53), it skips the mechanism of human acclimatization. This new slide fills that gap by visualizing the physiological timeline: it connects the environmental trigger (hypoxia) to the specific biochemical response (increased 2,3-BPG synthesis) and the functional outcome (enhanced unloading). It clarifies why a right shift, which normally implies lower affinity, is actually a survival strategy in low oxygen environments.

Slide placement: insert after slide 51. Rationale: Slide 51 introduces altitude as one of the causes of a right shift. This new slide immediately explains how that happens. It also sets up a contrast with the slide that comes a little later which shows how the bar headed goose adapts in the opposite way. This allows for human vs. bird evolutionary comparison that highlights different biological strategies for the same problem
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes: 
"We just finished talking about how BPG binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin and stabilizes the T-state. Now, let's look at a real-world physiological example of this in action: high altitude.
As you see on the left panel, when you go mountain climbing, the atmospheric pressure drops, meaning there is simply less oxygen available per breath. This causes hypoxia. Your hemoglobin can't load up to 100% saturation in the lungs anymore.
Your body's response, shown in the middle, is quite clever. Over a period of about two days, your red blood cells significantly increase their synthesis of 2,3-BPG. Remember, BPG is an allosteric effector that loves the T-state (the deoxy form). 
The result, shown in the graph on the right, is a classic right shift of the binding curve. By increasing BPG, your body is deliberately lowering hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. This seems counterintuitive, why lower affinity when there's less oxygen around?
The key is in the unloading. While you load slightly less oxygen in the lungs, the lower affinity means hemoglobin lets go of the oxygen much more easily in the tissues. The net effect is an increase in the total amount of oxygen delivered to your starving cells. It's a brilliant biochemical trade-off to keep you alive."

Student Takeaways:
•Hypoxia Challenge: High altitude means lower atmospheric pO2, reducing oxygen loading in the lungs.
•The Adaptation: The body responds over ~2 days by increasing the concentration of 2,3-BPG inside red blood cells.
•Mechanism: Increased BPG allosterically stabilizes the T-state of hemoglobin.
•The Right Shift: This causes a decrease in overall oxygen affinity (a right shift on the binding curve).
•The Benefit: The lower affinity significantly improves oxygen unloading in the tissues, which compensates for the reduced loading in the lungs.

submissions.name: Cody Chhea
submissions.explanation: The current version in the slide pictures a seesaw indicating that pH is heavier than pka. Just from that image alone, it's super hard to visualize that ph < pka = protonated and ph > pka = deprotonated. The one image of the seesaw doesn't necessarily show both scenarios clearly. My version visualizes scenarios of both ph < pka and ph > pka, giving an analogy that can help you reason out why one results in protonation and one results in deprotonation, respectively.
submissions.notes:
1. The Setup
Analogy: Proton (H+) = Steak. Molecule = Scuba Diver. pH = The Environment (sharks & water).
pKa: The threshold where the environment switches from peaceful to aggressive.
2. Left Panel: Acidic (pH < pKa)The tank is packed with free-floating steaks (high proton concentration).
Sharks are full and lazy; they ignore the diver's steak.
Conclusion: In an acidic environment, the molecule is under no pressure and keeps its proton (Protonated).
3. Right Panel: Basic (pH > pKa) The tank is empty, creating a "proton vacuum." Sharks are starving and aggressive; they attack the diver to get the only steak available. 
Conclusion: A basic environment actively strips the proton off the molecule (Deprotonated).

Student Takeaway: pH Lower than pKa: Environment is too crowded to take your proton. (Keep it). pH Higher than pKa: Environment is starving and will steal it. (Lose it)

submissions.name: Sierra Irving
submissions.explanation: This versions images are less jumbled. Furthermore, the text is easier to read from the back of the classroom.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Talking Points

I. Introduction to Fibrous Proteins

Functional Shift: Move from "chemical" catalysis (enzymes) to "mechanical" support.

Key Characteristic: Highly repetitive primary sequences leading to simple, elongated secondary structures.

Biological Roles: Protection, elasticity, and tensile strength.

II. Alpha-Keratin: The Coiled-Coil

Basic Unit: Right-handed α-helix.

The "Twist": Two helices wrap in a left-handed direction to form a coiled-coil.

Analogy: Like the individual strands of a rope providing more strength together than alone.

Disulfide Stabilization: * Covalent cross-links between Cysteine residues.

Hard vs. Soft Keratin: Ratio of disulfide bonds determines rigidity (e.g., hair vs. tortoise shell).

III. Collagen: The Triple Helix

Distinct Structure: Not an α-helix; it is a specialized Triple Helix.

The Gly-X-Y Repeat: Mandatory sequence for stability.

The Role of Glycine:

Occurs at every 3rd position.

The only residue is small enough to fit in the sterically crowded central core.

The Role of Proline/Hydroxyproline:

Rigid rings force the chain into the proper helical pitch.

Clinical Note: Hydroxyproline requires Vitamin C; lack of it leads to Scurvy (collagen failure).

IV. Closing Concept: "What Breaks One, Enables Another"

Proline Paradox: It is a "Helix Breaker" in α-helices but a "Structure Maker" in Collagen.

Mutation Impact: Swapping Glycine for a larger amino acid causes Osteogenesis Imperfecta (Brittle Bone Disease).

Final Takeaway: Sequence dictates structure, and structure dictates pathology.

Student "High-Yield" Summary

Keratin: α-helix → Coiled-coil → Disulfide bonds (Strength).

Collagen: Gly-X-Y sequence → Triple helix → Glycine in the center (Flexibility/Toughness).

Comparison: * Keratin = 2 strands, covalent stabilization.

Collagen = 3 strands, steric stabilization.

submissions.name: Naomi Mesfin
submissions.explanation: The sentence under the header didn't make sense, as it wasn't accelerating protein structure, it was accelerating protein structure methods. This could stay at slide 62, as I just fixed a grammatical error.
submissions.notes:
Core takeaway: Protein sequencing methods have advanced from years (Sanger) to minutes (MS). AI-designed proteins are
the next frontier.

submissions.name: Ebtesaam Abdul-Qudoos
submissions.explanation: My visual is better because it shows a clearer version of what is actually happening in the cell during phagocytosis. The original visual was kind of hard to understand and also was showing the process happening in a 3D manner, which I felt further confused the visual of phagocytosis. Additionally, the original visual had some scrambled words that took away from the overall image.
submissions.notes:
As seen in the visual, phagocytosis is able to bring large materials into the cell by essentially engulfing them. Lysosomes then act as the incinerator and digest the material brought into the cell. 
Student takeaways: Phagocytosis and lysosomes work together to bring in and break down/recycle large materials to turn into useful resources for the cell.

submissions.name: Jacob Kirshner
submissions.categoryRaw: Better Visual/Diagram, New Clinical/Historical Connection, Better Explanation/Analogy
submissions.explanation:
The current slides explain that oxygen binding moves the Fe²⁺ ion only 0.4 Å and triggers the T→R transition, but they do not visually show how such a small atomic movement produces a large conformational change in the entire hemoglobin tetramer. This makes it difficult for students to understand the mechanical linkage between oxygen binding and cooperativity.

My new slide improves this by showing a step-by-step visual sequence connecting iron movement → histidine movement → helix shift → tetramer rotation → increased oxygen affinity. It also includes a mechanical lever analogy, which helps students intuitively understand how small atomic movements can produce large structural effects.

Additionally, the slide adds a clinical connection to carbon monoxide poisoning, showing how pathological stabilization of the R state prevents oxygen release to tissues. This reinforces the physiological and medical importance of cooperativity.

This slide should be placed immediately after the slide showing iron movement into the heme plane, because it directly builds on that concept and explains how that atomic movement produces the T→R transition.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
When oxygen binds, the iron atom moves only 0.4 angstroms into the plane of the heme. This movement pulls on the proximal histidine, which is connected to an alpha helix. The helix shifts position, and this structural change propagates through the hemoglobin tetramer, triggering the T to R transition. This increases oxygen affinity at the remaining binding sites, which is the basis of cooperativity. This mechanism is clinically important because carbon monoxide locks hemoglobin in the R state, preventing oxygen release and causing tissue hypoxia.

Student Takeaways:
• Oxygen binding moves Fe²⁺ only 0.4 Å
• This small movement pulls on the protein backbone
• This triggers a large conformational change in hemoglobin
• This increases oxygen affinity at other binding sites (cooperativity)
• This mechanism enables oxygen delivery to tissues
• Carbon monoxide poisoning prevents oxygen release by locking hemoglobin in the R state

submissions.name: Esha Jain
submissions.explanation: Personally I learn better when there is a simple analogy or story I can connect the topic to. Here I introduced the analogy of origami to explain the different levels of proteins and think it is helpful for students to remember the different steps that take part in protein assembly.
submissions.notes:
Primary structure
“Think of the flat origami paper with the crease pattern printed on it. This represents the amino acid sequence, which contains all the information needed for folding.”

Secondary structure
“Next are simple, repeating local folds, like accordion folds or spirals. In proteins, these are alpha-helices and beta-sheets formed by hydrogen bonding.”

Tertiary structure
“All of the folds come together to form one complete 3D origami figure. This is the overall shape of a single polypeptide and determines protein function.”

Quaternary structure
“Finally, multiple fully folded origami figures assemble into one structure. Each subunit is functional on its own, but together they form the active protein.”

Student Takeaways (what students should remember)

Primary: amino acid sequence = folding instructions

Secondary: local, repeating folds (α-helices, β-sheets)

Tertiary: full 3D shape of one polypeptide

Quaternary: multiple polypeptides working together

submissions.name: Shreya Shanmugan
submissions.explanation: I think my version is better because it actually expands upon an analogy to a concept, to help remember it better. So I would present this slide after the slide that introduces teh concept.
submissions.notes:
Presenter notes: Imagine two villages: Village R (Reactants) and Village P (Products).
The "No Enzyme" Path: Villagers have to hike over a 10,000-foot jagged peak to get to the other side. Very few people make the trip each day (Slow Rate).
The "Enzyme" Path: A bridge is made connecting the two towns directly. Now, thousands of people can move between villages every hour (Fast Rate).
Equilibrium ($K_{eq}$): At the end of the day, the altitude of Village R and Village P hasn't changed. The bridge doesn't move the houses; it just moves the people.
Bi-directionality: The bridge works exactly the same way whether you are going from R to P or P to R. It accelerates both directions equally.
Activation Energy ($\Delta G^\ddagger$): The height of the mountain peak represents the energy barrier. The lbridge represents the lower energy path provided by the enzyme. Student Takeaways: Enzymes are "Bridge creators": They change the route, not the destination.
Two-Way Street: A bridge allows traffic to flow faster in both directions.
Altitude is Fixed: The energy difference between Reactant and Product is independent of the path taken.

submissions.name: Daniel Xu
submissions.explanation:
This slide adds a clinical connection to the concept of allosteric regulation by showing how mutations that lock enzymes in the active state can lead to uncontrolled cell growth. While the lecture explains T and R states and mentions disease connections, it does not clearly visualize how loss of regulation contributes to cancer.

This new slide should be placed after the section introducing allosteric enzymes and mutations affecting their regulation, before moving into additional regulatory models. It reinforces the importance of regulation by connecting enzyme behavior to real-world pathology.
submissions.notes:
Allosteric enzymes normally act like switches that move between low-activity and high-activity states depending on signals in the cell. Mutations can disrupt this balance and lock enzymes into the active state. When this happens, pathways may remain permanently active, even when the cell does not need them. In growth and signaling pathways, this constant activation can drive uncontrolled cell division, which is a major feature of cancer.

Student Takeaways:
• Allosteric enzymes regulate pathway activity by switching between states
• Mutations can lock enzymes into the active state
• Loss of regulation can cause constant pathway activation
• Dysregulated enzyme activity is linked to cancer development

submissions.name: Dade Prince-Shittu
submissions.explanation: This version is more effective because it takes the "Broad Specificity" of an Oxidoreductase  and gives it a narrative. While the original slides define the chemistry, the musical chairs analogy helps students visualize competitive cnhibition and affinity  without getting lost in the math. It highlights that the enzyme’s 3D cleft is a limited resource that can be strategically "occupied" by a high-affinity molecule (Ethanol) to prevent a lethal reaction (Antifreeze oxidation). It should be presented around slide 13.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes
The Clinical Tie-in: Transition from the definition of Oxidoreductases (Slide 13) by explaining that Alcohol Dehydrogenase (ADH) is a Class 1 enzyme with broad specificity, meaning it can bind both "safe" ethanol and toxic antifreeze.

The Analogy: Describe the 3D cleft of the enzyme as a single "Musical Chair" where Ethanol and Antifreeze compete to sit; Ethanol is the "VIP" with higher affinity, allowing it to win the seat through stronger weak interactions.

The Antidote Mechanism: Explain that "flooding the system" with Ethanol ensures the chair is always occupied by a VIP, preventing the ADH from oxidizing antifreeze into lethal glycolic or oxalic acids.

Student Takeaways
Mechanism of Competition: Competitive inhibition occurs when a "safe" molecule outcompetes a toxin for the enzyme's active site based on concentration and binding affinity.
Induced Fit in Action: The induced fit principle explains how the enzyme’s 3D cleft physically molds around the preferred substrate (Ethanol) to facilitate a safe reaction while blocking a harmful one.
Kinetic vs. Thermodynamic: This clinical treatment is a kinetic intervention that slows the rate of toxin processing; it does not change the fundamental thermodynamics Delta G of the reaction.

submissions.name: Smera Shanmugan
submissions.explanation: It shows a clearer image of how an enzyme works by looking at it on a graph
submissions.notes:
Visual reinforcement: Without enzyme: Reaction must overcome a high activation energy barrier . With enzyme: Reaction follows an alternate pathway with lower activation energy
Changes: Activation energy (ΔG‡) → reaction happens faster


Does NOT change: Free energy difference between reactants and products (ΔG°′)


WHY do reactions occur? → Thermodynamics (ΔG°′ determines favorability)


HOW do enzymes speed reactions up? → Kinetics (lower ΔG‡)

Student takeaways
Enzymes change rate, not equilibrium


Lower activation energy = faster reaction


Reactants and products are unchanged


Memorize: Enzymes do NOT change Keq

submissions.name: Connor Dean
submissions.explanation: Adding a clinical/historical connection strengthens this section because it links the core concept of biological unity to real-world scientific discovery and modern medicine. Students often memorize definitions without understanding why the idea matters; this slide bridges that gap by showing how the principle applies to human health and research. The new slide should be placed early in the chapter (around slides 6–10) immediately after the foundational definition of unity so that students see an applied example before moving into detailed mechanisms.
submissions.notes:
Presenter Notes:
Introduce the clinical/historical example as evidence that shared biological processes across species allow scientists to study disease, evolution, and treatments using model organisms. Emphasize that unity in biology is not just theoretical — it explains why discoveries in bacteria, mice, or fruit flies translate to human medicine.
Student Takeaways:
Unity of life means shared cellular and molecular mechanisms.
Clinical advances often come from studying conserved pathways.
Understanding evolution and common ancestry helps explain modern medical research.

submissions.name: Owen Wells
submissions.explanation: The original visual had arrows coming out at odd angles and did not clearly show what was happening an how the enzymes and products were changing.
submissions.notes:
The ping pong reaction! In this diagram you can see the actual ping pong mechanism!! You can see how each substrate is required to modify the enzyme so that the new enzyme can modify the substrate.
Student takeaways:
Substrate binding modifies an enzyme to create a substituted enzyme intermediate. The intermediate then binds a new substrate and produces a new product then returns to its normal enzyme state.

submissions.name: Mishti Mittal
submissions.explanation: This version is better because this diagram shows an actual visualization of size exchange chromatography. In our current slide deck, it just says that larger proteins elute first and smaller proteins elute last, with some reasoning, with no visual of how this works. My diagram contains an analogy with different types of balls to explain this concept, so that students can remember this idea better, particularly that larger proteins elute first, instead of confusing it with smaller proteins eluting first, which they might originally think. This new slide should be presented after slide 21 in the chapter 6 slide deck.
submissions.notes:
The Paradox: Ask the class: "Who wins a race through a tunnel? The mouse or the elephant?" Usually the mouse, but in this specific case, the elephant wins.

The Setup: The column is filled with "Whiffle Balls" (porous beads with internal tunnels).

Small Proteins (Red): They fit inside the holes. They get stuck exploring the internal maze (the "Scenic Route"). They are slow.
